Comparing the "River Safari" with "Singapore ZOO" parks I must say, as opposite to many reviewers before, that I like the River park more than "ordinary" ZOO.

First of all there are Giant Pandas there. Also the Squirrel Monkey forest is quite unique - the closed area with free-ranging monkeys that come really close to you without any barrier inbetween. Watching them play from close distance is a great fun.

But, apart from that, the River Park offers something, that I have not seen before. There is a number of aquariums with fresh water fish and animals there. Unfortunately the number of aquariums is not very high, but still the selection of fish (didn't know there are fresh water fish of such size!!!), crocodiles and other animals is quite impressive. All of that presented in areas devoted to the biggest rivers in the world!!!

You can see different sea animals in many places in the world. The exhibitions for fresh water ones (at least of that size) are not so popular. This is why River Safari is such an interesting Park to see.

In my opinion it is the Night Safari and River Safari Parks that make Singapore ZOO so unique and interesting.

title: Relaxing
content: It is a good place to visit, to relax (very spacious) to watch the pandas' actions or just to watch the large fishes swimming but really, if you combining the Zoo and this attraction, you will end up exhausted! By the time we hit the 6th hour, we just wanted to sit down. Best to combine Zoo and Night Safari or River Safari and Night Safari but not the both - with excellent weather, it was too much for us as the Zoo has added quite a number of new attractions!

title: Hit and misses
content:
To be honest, without Jia Jia & Kai Kai this river safari might turn out be a ghostly safari.

River boat ride SGD$5

Kinda disappointed,the ride is less than 10 mins and the animals were hiding under the shelter from the scorching hot sun... we saw the flamingoes and another animal (can't rem the name). Some of the animals weren't even at "home", basically we were looking at the greens more than animals.

Jia Jia & Kai Kai:

They were kept in an air conditioned room, surrounded by cameras. If you're lucky you could get to see both of them having their lunch. Their neighbour lives a red panda. It's super adorable that I took countless of photos.

Panda restaurant:

A casual dining eatery to fill your stomach. I suggest you pack your lunch. The eatery is forever full house and the Q for getting food is ridiculous. We Q up to 40 mins just to get 2 bowls of noodles.

Surprisingly, the noodles was tasty and springly. The prawn dumplings were fresh. And the drinks filled in a reusable tumbler.

Overall experience:

Visit once is enough

title: Worth it just for the Pandas
content:
River cruise is a new attraction as only opened in 2012 it's worth a visit but if you want to spend time here don't book a trip via your hotel as they pick you up at 12.30 only to take you in the wrong direction to Chinatown to pay and then the opposite side of the Island via coach and you will be lucky to arrive by 2pm and the bus returns back at 4.40pm!
Worth a visit to the Pandas but felt sorry for them, after seeing them last year in Chengdu happy in as wild conditions as they are going to get these looked very bored pacing around their small enclosure.
Best to combine with the night safari, the river park closes at 6pm and the night safari opens at 7 (recommend queuing from 6.30pm) to be on one of the first four trams which depart shortly after 7.30 at dusk as difficult to see animals then rather than in total darkness, and flash photography is not allowed at any time. the team takes 40mins per circuit and finishes in time for the first night show at 8.30 the bus back to the hotels departs at 10.10pm but park does not close till midnight.

title: Awesome experience
content: I wasn't intending on doing this in addition to the zoo but while waiting in line they had advertisements on the televisions overhead playing what was inside the river safari and I was completely sold. You do need to pay extra to get in but it's only $50 for entry into the zoo and river safari. The exhibits are based around some of the great rivers of the world including the ganges/mekong and amazon rivers. The aquariums are magnificent and the information given is short and sweet. I also love that they emphasise the impact that humans are having on these ecosystems. Whether it's made a difference or not is another question. Definitely a must see if you are coming to the zoo. I didn't go on the amazon river cruise - it seems more geared towards children so I can't comment on it. They really save the best for last though, the underwater forest exhibit is simply breathtaking!

title: Nice zoo
content: This is basically in the same area as the main Singapore Zoo but is a more water/river themed zoo than the traditional zoo. If you want to see the pandas, you need to come here, they are not at the main zoo. The landscapes are also very nice here. They break a lot of the regions in this zoo down by what part of the world the animals are from.

title: Totally great experience!! Singaporeans: it is worth your visit
content:
I am a singaporean and was initially very very apprehensive as to whether to visit the river safari because i received so many negative comments abouy the place. I finally decided to give this place a try.. and i must say that my family had a blast of a time here!!
Well, my family hated the sea aquarium in sentosa. We found it too cold, crowded and lacking a special touch.
The river safari, however is different. They might not have as many species of fish as the sea aquarium, but it was extremely interesting to group the fish/mammals according to their living habitat. It was a very good learning experience for my family with consists of 2 children, 4 and 5 yrs old.
The amazon ride was too short for us as we totally enjoyed the experience. The staff were also very strict about the height restriction of a minimum height of 1.06m before allowed on the amazon ride. Luckily my 4yr old daughter made the height limit.
The other boat ride taking us on a round of the reservoir however was boring . Nothing special to look out for and we would definitely give it a miss on my next trip there.
There was also a huge tank similar to that of the sea aquarium for visitors to ait and enjoy the enormous manatees swimming. It was awesome.
Overall, my family would definitely be back.. This time i would be bringing my elderly parents on a wheelchair with me as the place is very wheelchair friendly.

title: Very good
content: First time here since it opened. Very nice. Worth coming back again, even just for the always cute pandas!

title: Spacious, less touristy, breezy and well-sheltered
content:
Thumbs up for the 2 pandas and cute little fire foxes. This place feels a little bit like the Sentosa SEA Aquarium (Which i did not enjoy, except for the Jelly Fish)
If River Safari includes the Jelly Fish similarly to Sentosa SEA, personally I would think you can give Sentosa's SEA a miss!

title: The Pandas is our sole reason for visit
content: I dont find the place special, indeed the concept is wonderful but it's quite tiring.. The pandas on the other hand was the reason why we visit this place. There are red pandas and giant pandas.. You can even be as close as 1 meter with the red pandas..

title: River life is more than just a river!
content:
I wasn't sure if I wanted to try River Safari initially as there were quite a few very negative reviews on River Safari on Tripadvisor. But everyone sees things differently so we decided to go and try it. We were glad we did as we had such a fantastic time. We bought a 3 in 1 Park Hopper ticket which enabled us to go to Singapore Zoo, Night Safari and River Safari for $83 which was a great value. There are many more different Hopper Tickets so I would recommend to have a look at the website and buy them online prior to the visit so that you can avoid the ques when you arrive to the parks.

We already have visited Zoo and Night Safari but we still had a great time there learning about different fresh water lives. I have never seen so many fresh water fish in one place before and it really was interesting. The place is divided into a few different sections to focus on different rivers from South America to Australia to Africa. Each river has completely different habitat and comapring them was quite fascinating.

There was also an area where you can see Panda and Red Panda. They were absolutely gorgoues and it can easily be the highlight of your visit.

The Amazon boat ride was fun too. Some reviewers complained that they couldn't see anything or the ride was too short. For me, it was a fun experience. Yes it is true you may not be able to see everything they may point out but we could still see majority of them. You just have to really look for it! The ride itself was probably about 10 minutes but so it really depends on how you see whether you think it is too short or not.

The park is not as big as Zoo or Night Safari so you may not need as much time as the other places. We spent around 3 hours including having a little snack break. We still got to see and experience everything but you could take longer time and go slower if you wanted to. If you are in Singapore for a day or two, then I would go for Zoo or Night Safari and leave River Safari for another time. If you are staying in Singapore for longer, you could allocate a day for each places so that you can really enjoy them without being too tired which we did. I know some people tried to squeeze all 3 places in one day and they all complained how tired they were and couldn't really enjoy it. It's good to leave some place for a next visit so that you have something you can look forward to!

title: More than a (short) boat ride
content: We only decided to visit this attraction when lining up for tickets to the zoo. It was different to what we expected as we assumed it was a ride on a big boat through different areas with animals on display. The boat ride, while pretty good, only lasted 10 minutes and half the animals couldn't be seen as the boat passed their enclosure. The other issue we had was the lack of signage giving directions to the panda enclosure (you'd think it would be their main attraction?). We had to ask two employees and ended up walking in through the exit doors. We found out later that we missed out seeing a lot of other animals as we didn't go the right way due to poor signage. FYI - to get there walk along the bridge over the river and turn left along the boardwalk before you reach the cafe / gift shop. Not cheap but worth the visit.

title: Very small but interesting
content:
The place is tiny, can finish walk within a hour.
The animal not a lot, main purpose is the see panda but Jia Jia and Kia Kia are so shy!!! Other animals are mostly imported from zoo. Not much to wow.
The layout is easy to walk around, safe for kids. Convenient for old fork with wheel chair as all flat flooring.

title: Good place for children
content:
I went there with my friends to attend our best friend's wedding. Before the wedding, we gave a visit to River Safari Singapore.

Quite interesting, lots of species and story telling involved in this place. Recommended for your family trip. Your children will love the Dugong section :)

title: Nice to visit especially during hot or raining day
content: We bought a double pass with entitled us to visit the singapore zoo and the river safari. Since it was raining heavily, we decided to skip the zoo and visit the shaded river safari. It is more like a giant aquarium that have different theme. The safari boat ride is pretty disappointing as we are not able to see half of the animals during the ride.

title: Enriching day to spend at
content:
Visited this place 3 times since their opening as am lucky to get free tickets though company :-)

Was abit dissappointed with the boat rides as it was really a small section.

@ the panda zone with the red panda and with our Star of attractions Jiajia[ female ] and Kai Kai [ Male ].
it really depends on your luck to see JiaJia as she's so shy that out of the 3 visit I went, had only saw her once.
Love this aquarium area where I could just sit there and relax looking at them swimming around.

Overall, in Singapore a small country this is definitely a place to visit!

title: Amazing river life
content: A nice attraction with lots of fishes from various rivers like Amazon, Yangtze, Mekong , Ganges etc Highlight were the cute pandas in air conditioned comfort Huge aquariums and shaded walks is comfortable. Not to be missed if you visiting the Zoo next door !

title: Worth it to see the Pandas!
content:
A very popular location as the River Safari and Singapore Zoo are in the same location. Easy to get to by taxi or bus. We didn't arrive till nearly midday, which would explain the huge queue at the ticket office as people queuing to buy tickets for the Singapore Zoo as well. I ended up at the back of a huge queue, but was greeted by a staff member who pointed out the sign that tickets can be bought online and then the email shown to the staff at the gate. I did say to the staff member that I have a UK phone, but she said it was fine as the Zoo/Safari has free Wifi (best signal I've come across at any attraction here!) Followed the online steps, just selected what I wanted and entered my card details. Didn't want to wait for my emails, so showed my receipt to the same staff member who took me to a ticket booth, printed off my tickets and voila! Moral of the story is book in advance!

The Pandas are a must see, lovely sight. Seeing the female Panda is hit or miss so I would suggest going in the morning I was told...oh well!

A calm walk around the 'park', nice places to eat for lunch, nice merchandise, which is very tempting (cute Panda toys etc...not cheap though)

The fish are huge and it was nice to see 2 large crocodiles and as you exit the Panda gift shop, you should be able to see a huge Polar bear, which is part of the zoo exhibit swimming around.

There are places for lunch, I would recommend the restaurant inside River Safari as you exit the Panda gift shop (apologies, I can't remember the name) nice food there.

There is a taxi pick up point which can get busy so be prepared to wait, but taxis are fairly frequent.

Lovely trip for younger kids, not a mass of things to see, but the Red and Giant Pandas are definitely worth it.

title: Pandas were nice but the boat ride not so
content: The pandas are the main attraction for this place so make sure to visit them and takes pictures and videos. You can skip the boat ride since for S$5 it was not worth the price. The trip was too short and we were not able to appreciate the animals along the ride since they were probably hiding. Singapore Zoo was way better.

title: Skip the boat ride
content:
The layout of the river safari is quite nice. It's green and peaceful and a nice contrast to the buzzle of the city.

Other than the pandas, which are really special, the rest of the river safari is not very exciting, however:
Many many fish, but since these are river not saltwater fish, also not the most interesting ones; have seen more beautiful and colorful fish in diverse aquaria.

The boat ride on the river is really a joke, very short and rushed, you don't have a chance to see the animals (blink once and you missed it). Not worth the money nor waiting for it in line. Also wondered why you would e.g. put the jaguar (or was it a leopard? Don't know-we had about 5 seconds to look), one of the more spectacular animals to see in the park, not in the part of the park which you can explore at your own speed. Like this you have no chance to really admire this animal.

With regard to the pandas, while it is very nice to have a chance to see these animals, it gave us a double feeling:
You are instructed when entering to be quiet around the pandas, but nobody is there to enforce this. The young girls walking around silently with notice boards to remind the visitors to be silent are simply ignored by the crowds, so that seems pretty pointless and ineffective.

Also, we were surprised how small the enclosure of the red pandas was and how many people were standing around it, even trying to touch the animals. One of the red pandas made a pretty stressed impression, walking around endlessly and leaving its mark, not sure if this is normal behavior.

title: Nice for a Late Afternoon Visit
content: We went late afternoon after visiting the Singapore Zoo (basically connected to the zoo). There weren't as many tourists when we went around 4pm. The panda's were really neat to see. We did the boat ride as well which we really enjoyed. It was a quick visit but worth it. We did the iVenture pass so it was worth the quick visit.

title: Nice afternoon visit
content:
Visited this rather new attraction of Singapore on a weekday afternoon. Having heard much about this place from our friends (mostly young families), our expectations were high.

This place is more like an aquarium really, displaying a diverse, and some really valuable, collection of marine life in various major rivers around the world. Don't fret if you are not a fan of fishes, there are two lovely pandas waiting for you there.

Overall, the experience was good. The heat was somewhat unbearable though. Thank god for the air-conditioned panda enclosure!

title: Packed, not a lot to see, lame ride, but the Pandas were cool.
content:
First off, this should just be part of the zoo without extra cost other than the "ride". The idea is that it's a zoo attraction with a theme of different rivers of the world. I loved the Singapore Zoo and Night Safari from previous trips, so I had to come.

I went on a Saturday morning and spent $25 total, including the ride. Unlike a zoo, which is pretty open, the initial portion of the River Safari is a pathway with exhibits on the side that you have to follow. The day that I went it was so crowded that there were tons of people crammed up in front of the viewing areas for the exhibit that you had to wait or push your way in. It was shoulder to shoulder, so for some of the exhibits, I just lost my patience and moved on. For many other exhibits, more even than a typical zoo, the animals were impossible or near impossible to find.

Again, seeing the different animals of the different river areas was pretty cool, but for many of them there were just fish and things that you could see better in an aquarium or, again, a zoo. Honestly, I don't remember seeing anything particularly unique along the main part of the trek until we got to the pandas.

When I got to the pandas, which doesn't take long at all, because there aren't many other exhibits, there was a very long queue to get in. So you wait and wait a video screen of the panda’s arrival. When you finally get to the front, they advise you to be very quiet and respectful, blah blah, but when you get it it's, again, ridiculously crowded. The first things you see are the red pandas, and they're awesome! They weren't very lively that day, but it was nice and cool in the building and they seemed pretty relaxed.

The next part was the first of the Pandas, and he was actually out and about. Seeing him was difficult since there were so many people crowding around the sides, and people were NOT being very quiet. There were lots of loud kids... The other panda was a bit shy and stayed further away. The pandas were pretty interesting though and were probably worth the trip.

Next up was a gift shop with more Panda junk than you can imagine, and then it was time to eat. The cafe had a 30 minute line and the food wasn't exactly stellar, but not as overpriced as what you would expect in the states. After that, there were a few more exhibits, and then the ride.

The Ride was like a log ride, but short and not any splashes other than the initial descent, then a slight chance to see some animals. It was a joke. I would not recommend it. It was about 5 minutes and I barely saw anything, most of which I could have seen from the exhibits.

The only other really good part was the squirrel monkey area, where you could go in and hang out with the squirrel monkeys. They were cute and active, so this was also a good point.

Final thoughts: If you can get discounted tickets, you've never seen pandas before, and you go on a weekday when it's less busy, then this might be worth it. Otherwise, go to the Singapore Zoo. There's a part of me that wants to say, "Stay away" based upon my principal belief that this should be part of the zoo - especially the pandas (doesn't make sense to be part of a river exhibit really), but I can't completely say that. I did have some fun.

title: Some amazing sights
content: We had an afternoon visit of 3 hours to River Safari and we really enjoyed ourselves. There were lots of amazing animals to see - pandas, manatees and flamingos being some favourites. My reservations were: 1. many of the animals were only seen briefly on the 10 minute Amazon River Quest boat ride and my 3 year old was not tall enough to ride. 2. I didn't feel that many of the animal's enclosures were as comfortable as those in the Zoo. It's still definitely worth a visit, though.

title: Very good attraction
content: It was a nice place and mostly covered. The bridge walk was relaxing with the breeze and so was the boat ride. The highlight was few minutes spent with the Pandas. They are lovely sight and well kept in conducive environment. Our only purpose was to see them. The other attractions are good too... We liked to see the information about river Ganges.

title: Peaceful River Safari
content:
We went to the River Safari on a Thursday morning. We caught a taxi (just over $20) and were there by 9.30am. I had thought about pre-booking to get our choice of time on the boat ride, but decided to play it by ear in case the weather didn't look good. I could choose any time for the boat ride and decided on 11am. We walked through the various river exhibits with only one or two other small groups of people around - so peaceful for a major attraction in Singapore! When we got to the panda exhibit you could see that sometimes there is a huge crowd as they have ropes set up to deal with the queues. We walked straight in and spent about 10 minutes watching one of the red pandas run madly around his enclosure, including out onto a branch that was only slightly above our heads. We then moved on to see the giant pandas. Unfortunately the female was in her den and remained there the whole time (you can see her on the web cam) but the male panda put on quite a show. He was lying down looking sleepy, but the keeper threw some bamboo in and he lumbered over to it and then lay oh his back facing us as he enjoyed his meal - so gorgeous! We then crossed the bridge over the reservoir to get to the boat ride. We were 10 mins early, but went straight on. As others have said the "boat ride" is more like a gentle theme park ride that lasts 10 mins. However, unlike others, we saw plenty of birds and animals, including the jaguar roaming backwards and forwards right up against the glass near us. It's a shame it doesn't go slower, but I suppose when it's busy they have to push people through. Of interest, when we were crossing the bridge, we saw some real cruise boats with "River Safari" written on them anchored in the reservoir. The staff told us that these will be operational within the next 6 months.
Moving on, we went through the enclosed small monkey forest, where you can see and photograph at very close quarters - plenty of them to spot running on branches etc. Next is the flooded Amazon exhibit whioch is similar in design to the large aquarium at SEA Aqurium at Sentosa. So peaceful to sit and watch the huge mannatees(spelling?) and all the other river creatures - it's quite mesmerising. We left after 3 hours, having thoroughly enjoyed all the exhibits and creatures (especially the pandas). I must say this attraction outweighed my expectations.

title: Amazon Flooded Forest is amazing!
content:
Went with my wife on a Tuesday afternoon. Be prepared to see some really amazingly mysterious creatures from all over the world! Was taken aback by size of the indian gharial (alligator).

We love the pandas enclosure (partly because it's air conditioned!) and stayed there for sometime to see Kaikai & Jiajia from China. Do not expect too much from them though. There is the beautiful fire fox as well.

Next up the Amazon River Quest. We booked a time slot online and were there early, the kind staffs there accepted our request to join the ride earlier. We find the ride too short and too fast. Could have been longer and slower.

The last and best part of our journey is the finale at Amazon Flooded Forest, which makes our trip all the worthwhile. The giant aquarium here took my breath away. I loved the manatees, red-tailed catfishes and arapaimas in the gigantic blue glass. We can even walk up and see the view from top.

Would certainly recommend River Safari because of the main attractions, Pandas enclosure & Amazon Flooded Forest. Worth the money. 5 stars.

title: nice experience
content: nice to see the new and the old combinations of the building near the river , a good experience overall

title: A bit expensive for what it offers
content: We visited again as the first time we went, the boat ride was not yet operational. I must admit it was disappointing as we did not see some of the animals as it moved on too quickly for us to catch sight of them. Considering that you would prob need a max of 2 hours to walk through the whole park , we felt it was a bit overpriced. Singapore Zoo offers more value got the price you pay. Good points: it is disable friendly with lots of ramps. In addition most of the exhibits are under shade, giving a little respite from the tropical heat. Our favourites were the panda exhibit, it helped that it was air conditioned . And the large aquarium with the manatees . It was soothing to see them serenely swimming about . Disappointments: Ice cream cart was not open on a hot hot day. Only ice cream available was an expensive looking small tub of sorbet when my children were looking forward to a Solero! More water coolers would be good. I would suggest if you would like to visit this attraction to combine it with either the Zoo or Night Safari. Trekking out all the way just for this is not worth your while.

title: It's an okay add on.
content:
Since we were spending all day to do the zoo and night safari, we decided to do the river safari park as well. The pandas were great, as was the spider monkey area where you are in an enclosure with them. Honestly, the amazon riverboat ride was very hokey - it went way to fast to see anything, and lasted 10 minutes. Not worth doing, especially when you have to pick a time in the morning and arrange everything around that time! We spent a less than 2 hours in the River Safari park before going back to the regular zoo.

So, in one day we did all three zoos - so it is possible - but it made a for a long day! We certainly loved the zoo best, and if you have time for just one - make it the zoo! The other two parks appear to be them capitalizing on the success of the original zoo.

title: Ok
content: We arrived with much anticipation. Everywhere you look in Singapore the River Safari is advertised - showing pictures of boat rides and wild animals. It was a little more subdued than that! The boat ride is only a small part - perhaps 10 minutes only and a little too fast - it was easy to miss the animals. Highlights were the manatees. What amazing creatures. Don't miss the feeding at 5 pm. The pandas were beautiful too. Allow perhaps 2 hrs max here.

title: Great Place To Visit
content:
Took a friend to visit the River Safari. A bit on the high side for at most a two hour visit; but then again, things in Singapore are expensive. Nevertheless, River Safari is quite a great tourist attraction for those intending to visit Singapore.

The attractions are mainly a lot of fish, some crocodiles, some monkeys and the star attraction is the Giant Panda.

If you are on a walking tour, then it would take you about an hour to get through the place. Either way, do have fun. I love the dark "cave" where you can just stare into the water and see the giant fishes and just get amazed at the creatures there.

title: Still needs some time to make things better
content:
Visited the Singapore River Safari earlier today and it was a nice experience. Was there with my wife and 2 kids. We went without any expectations and therefore were pleasantly surprised with a few things. Firstly, we liked how the Safari was organised by the different rivers in the world and personally I learned quite a bit about that during this visit. We really liked the red panda as well as the 2 panda bears. The good thing about the River Safari is that you can make your way through the whole park with a roof over your head which means you don't really need to be out in the sun much (excellent in a hot country like Singapore).

What I wasn't too happy with were:
1. The Amazon River quest boat ride had a height restriction of 106cm and above which meant that my little one who turns 2 later this year could not get on the ride. This is ridiculous as the majority of visitors to the River Safari, Zoo etc are family with young children. As a result of this restriction, the whole family ended up not going on the boat ride and we missed out on numerous attractions. This restriction should definitely be removed as each parent should be allowed to hold a young one on our lap.

2. A lot of the animals on showcase were unique especially the upside down cat fish, the Indian alligator with a funny snout, red pandas etc, however we left that place feeling that we wanted to see more. In one of the exhibits, we actually saw angel fishes being on display... the normal kind that you would see for sale at any aquarium shops. I believe it's because the River Safari is still relatively new and ought to be given a bit more time to develop and improve.

3. Being set up in such a hot and humid country, I believe water fountains or refilling stations are essential. We saw a few stalls and vending machines along the way but they were selling either ice cream, flavoured water or carbonated drinks.

4. There needs to be another alternative place for dining. We had lunch at the Panda restaurant and it was packed as. The prices were a bit on the high side especially the Panda pau for $2.90 each (lol!) but you'd expect that at a place like this.

Overall it was an enjoyable day and would take up 2-4 hours of your day depending if you're with your kids and how long you stay at each attraction. However, there are obvious areas to improve as mentioned above.

title: Nice but go to the others first
content: The River Safari park in Singapore is located next door to the Singapore Zoo and Night Safari. It's a decent size park with heaps of easy access walkways and lovely scenery. The boat ride is definitely hit and miss- it would be possible to miuss out on most of the animals depending on where they were in their enclosures, but it reasonably priced so worth a go. I have been to all parks out of the four now and if you were going to do just one I would say go to the regular zoo, one of the best ever that I've been to, and the second choice would be Jurong Bird Park which is really spectacular too.

title: Scenic, Serene And Family Oriented
content: During early June 2014, I brought my New Zealander Friends to the River Safari. Their country possesses a lot of natural beauties. Singapore is a small tropical island with high humidity most of the time. At the River Safari, we are brought into another world of its own. Suddenly, you don't feel the environment to be small. It was airy and the open river sight becomes scenic and serene. The fishes, reptiles, birds and animals are well documented based on different regions and their living and eating habits. There is a short boat trip which is good for family or friends to sit together and enjoy the river sight and the animals or reptiles to be discovered. I wish it was slightly longer. No feeding attraction like the night safari or zoo. Handicap friendly. Last but not least, we saw the lovable Panda. No KungFu Panda chopping around. We end with a good lunch at the chinese restaurant. Most of all, my friends enjoyed the visit with many pictures to bring home.

title: The non river safari
content: This is an open air aquarium with a number of river themes and regional fish. The big attraction is two Giant Pandas there is also an Amazon cruise which is a canal with some animals along the banks Go to the night zoo instead unless you love Pandas

title: Wouldn't bother if going to zoo/night safari
content:
Although interesting with some good animals and marine life (pandas!) the river safari isn't worth a visit if you're going to the zoo or night safari (do both!).
If you do go, make sure it's first thing in the morning or late in the afternoon as the animals are very quiet in the peak of the hot days. Obviously this doesn't effect the fish!

title: Cute animals everywhere
content: It wasn't any other zoological garden. The river safari in Singapore is special because it consists of animals that live near rivers or water, such as the pandas, many different types of fish, foxes, bears and even red pandas. Especially their enclosure containing pandas and red pandas. Visitors can see those animals up close, and red pandas are free to roam around, but they won't let you touch them because they are scared. But I failed to visit it early enough to take the boat ride which would have let me see more animals. They really should make the boat ride available throughout the operating hours and not on a first come first serve basis

title: So much Fun!
content: Though the boat was mechanical, it was definitely an awesome experience. Different wildlife from the amazon were showcased and the most exciting part was the Jaguars! It's my first time to actually see some of the wildlife in the flesh and would love to do another round the next time. Don't skip it, it's worth the extra coz inside the River Safari complex are the very cute Panda bears!

title: Well-sheltered from the rain
content:
First time to the attraction and it was raining quite heavily when we got there at 10am. However, except for the boat ride, the trail is completely sheltered, so no problem with that!

Eventually the skies cleared up and we got on the boat ride. Unfortunately, the ride didn't live up to our expectations of a "River Safari". The ride was way too short and to compound matters, we found the boat travelling too fast for us to "spot" the animals at each station.

Overall, it's more of a walking kind of attraction. We did learn something about the major rivers of the world. But the pandas were kind of out of place in there. No complaints though. They were cute.

title: River Safari Singapore : Take Note (with Children)
content: Visiting River Safari Singapore is like walking through a large aquarium. As the name suggests, there are lots of fish and pretty big ones too... to excite the kids. Not forgetting the Pandas! However do take when bringing your kids, the Safari has a river ride (which they charge in addition to admission fees) that takes you round another part of the park. This ride however restricts children who are below 1.06m tall. So if you have young ones, do take note!

title: Go if you're under 10 years old
content: A very small area designated to each of the largest rivers in the world. Some animals were in hiding, couldn't see them. If you're going for the boat ride, go for an earlier one, so you can leave the park earlier. It takes around 4 hours to cover everything if you're a snail-speed walker. Oh, there's giant pandas to see too.

title: Great fun until the flamingos.
content:
This is a very well set out and huge themed zoo. We had to revisit the next day because the river boat ride was being serviced. Advice is to call from your hotel first.
The Amazon boat ride is really only a minor aspect and we were flat out spotting any wildlife as most of it was either hiding or not there. The Flamingo exhibit really stunk something awful. Maybe they should flush the pond more often. The 2 standouts for us were the walk in monkeys and the aquarium exhibits. If you only have one day then don't sweat it if the boat ride is unavailable. 90% you can see on foot. There is no inner transportation.
btw The best and cheapest way to get to the zoo is by MRT to Ang Mo Kio then by bus from the interchange linked to the train station. On day one we tried it via Yishun. Tourist info said bus to within 800 metres of Zoo entrance but it was more like 2 kms...lol Via Ang Mo Kio is the go.

title: Not up to expectations
content: We have been to Singapore many times and have visited most attractions. However, the expectations we had of the River Safari were based on the amazing experiences we have had at the zoo etc. and were unfortunately not met here. From our impression of the marketing brochures, we were expecting a type of 'river cruise' through the various river themes, but the River Safari is conducted on foot, peering into tanks and reading signs. The pandas were wonderful, and we were lucky enough to see them out and about in their enclosure, but once they went into their houses to eat, many visitors would not have had the opportunity to see them at all except on a tiny CC camera. The only boat ride was the Amazon River, at extra cost. It was a mechanized theme ride that rushed through the various habitats so quickly that one was lucky to see an animal, let alone take a pic of one. There were two attractions we thoroughly enjoyed however. The spider monkeys and the up close view of those great little animals was most enjoyable. The other highlight for us was viewing the otters, amazing fish and huge manatees in their enormous tanks. The hand feeding of the manatees was an unforgettable sight. Overall we were a little disappointed with the experience and won't be returning.

title: Enjoyed ourselves very much
content: Our second time here. Great way to spend a morning. Slightly crowded on a Saturday morning but still enjoyable. Exhibits are breathtaking and informative. Park is beautiful, layout well-thought, lots of shaded areas. We also loved the boat ride. Overall, highly recommended.

title: Amazing
content: With River habitat displays and animals from around the world also a boat ride along the Amazon River Quest a very enjoyable day.

title: Relax, enjoy the nature
content: My girl kept asking for this & I saw quite a bit of fb posting by the youth. So decided to pay a visit during a saturday. We found out that buyibg online was cheaper so we used our smartphone to book it, received an email & that can be used for scanning. Need not print out hardcopy. Boat ride need to separately purchased. Highly recommended if u r going w kids. It's a little bit like a mini themepark ride, that explains the steepness of the ticket price as such ride defintely required maintenance. I feel like it's a very educational trip. Efforts can be seen in displaying,explaining and designs accomidate to the natural surrounding. Love the various exhibits. Food is also not extremely expensive but crowded. My girl loves the trip, will be back to spend time w nature.

title: Fun!
content:
This was our first time in singapore and only stayed 3 days. We didnt get to go to all three theme parks - river safari, night safari and the zoo. They're all next to each other.

We only got to go river and night safari. I think the night safari was overrated. I personally thought the river safari was much cooler. We did decide last minute to go to the river safari, but I was a little disappointed that the river cruise was sold out. From memory its only $5 a ticket but you walk around and see everything anyway

If you're up for it, ask the hotel for directions to get there by train and bus. Its a lot cheaper and the transport there is awesome. Always runs on time.

title: Nice small jewel surrounded by nature
content:
We visited this place with our teen aged daughters and loved the 2.5 hours we spent there exploring this park.

We had booked our tickets online including the boat ride slot at 10am. We reached there sharp at 9am when the park opened and went straight to the Panda enclosure which is located at the end of the park....a 10min walk from entrance without stopping and looking at anything on the way. That was the best plan as literally we were the only people there and could enjoy watching both pandas munching on their bomboo shoots. We spent almost 30 mins there with hardly anyone else.

The boat ride was very enjoyable and since we had prebooked our time slot; there was no need to wait.

After completing these two activites we visited rest of the exibits; stopping and enjoying the sights. The underwater fish exhibits were veey nice.

By 11am the park was crowded and we noticed there was a long queue to visit ghe panda enclosure.

Overall a good experience and from there we visited the zoo next door and spent rest of the day enjoying there.

Vijay

title: Panda is jjang!!! (Great)
content:
I got the ticket for adult 1 day, for around S$25. Cheaper than Singapore Zoo ticket.
I went there on weekday, so not very much crowded, but of course the weather is kinda hot. Bet you have to prepare hat/cap, UV, and sunglasses.
I bought the ticket online, and they offered the boat ticket for S$5 the same price as if you bought the ticket on the spot. This boat has around 12 persons capacity, and going around some spot of the River Safari about 10 minutes (around 15% of it).
So mostly you have to walk around the safari. As the title, you will find river animal mostly. Fun to see them, and take pics. Many of them are the 1st time for me to see directly. There's a cute crocodile, like a mini one.
And above of all, the main attraction is the Panda! Kai Kai and Jia Jia! They ARE so adorable! Walking around their path, and eating bamboos while relaxing. You could see them from a very near spot. The panda conservatory is really cool! The temperature is low (so kinda cold) but isn't freezing, it's comfortable. Maybe they have to match the temperature with China as the Panda's home. So after you got sweat from the outside, it's really good when you got in the Panda's conservatory.
And there's Red Panda before you meet the Panda, which just beside the Panda. Kinda looks like koalas, because the sleep on trees, just like hanging there. The fur is so clean, and looks soft, made just wanna touch it (because so near). Just like a walking plush. Wanna hug them!

title: Rivers of the World
content:
Nestled between the Singapore Zoological Gardens and the Night Safari, River Safari is a river-themed Wildlife Park that is distinctively unique.

In our lifetime, few of us would probably have a chance to come up, close and personal with the land and aquatic animals from the great rivers of the world. River Safari with its collection of 200 species of freshwater-dwelling sea creatures as well as land animals that make the rivers their home, is certainly a place worth a visit in that aspect.

Personally, I have visited quite a few wildlife parks, aquariums as well as zoos but am still amazed at the number of creatures that I got to see for the first time at the River Safari, such as the Alligator Gar, the African Dwarf Crocodile, Tigerfish, Chinese Giant Salamander, to name just a few. The star attraction is doubtlessly, the Giant Pandas, Kai Kai and Jia Jia but personally, I find the pair of red pandas simply irresistible and absolutely adorable! I've seen red pandas on nature documentaries but in flesh, they look even cuter than on film.

The River Safari, is a weather-friendly destination, as it is almost entirely sheltered except for the Amazon River Quest which is a 10-minute boat ride along a Amazon rainforest setting. The cost of this ride (S$5) is in addition to the admission tickets to the park. Do note that there is a min height requirement of 1.06m and the ride is NOT for those who are unable to transfer in and out of the boat unaided. Also, there is no guarantee that riders would be able to see all the animals featured during this ride, which might be hiding at some obscure corners, sleeping soundly somewhere or simply too well camouflaged to be spotted. The fact that the boat moves relatively quickly makes the task of spotting some of them even more challenging. If you're short of time, or are faced with a long queue/sold-out tickets, it wouldn't matter much actually to give this a miss. On the map, it seems to be a large part of the park but in reality, it is not. In fact, I went for the ride and it didn't leave much of an impression. (It was 10 minutes of "where are the animals?, where are the animals?" And before I knew it, it was over!) Perhaps I chose the wrong time slot (1.30pm) when most of the animals were enjoying their siesta? For those who must try it, maybe an early morning time slot or a near evening time slot would yield better prospect of spotting the animals.

The highlight of River Safari, for me, is the Amazon Flooded Forest which is the world's largest freshwater aquarium. It was truly an eye-opener to witness how the the annual flooding of the Amazon rainforest would look like with its inhabitants, through this special exhibit. It is difficult not to be awed.

There are two eating outlets at the River Safari, namely, River Safari Tea House (where we had our lunch and tea) as well as a more casual fast-food style outlet "Mama Panda Kitchen" with both indoor and outdoor seating. Very near this outlet, one can get a chance to take a glimpse of Inuka, the polar bear (which is housed in the Zoo next door) swimming in his tank through a window in the wall! One can also see the white rhinos (also located at the zoo) from afar whilst walking on the bridge that links the Panda Outdoor Viewing Gallery and the Wild Amazonia.

As the park is just within 5 minutes walk to the Zoo, there are other options such as KFC, Ah Meng Kitchen, Ben and Jerry's very close by.

For those who drive, it's a good idea to park at the multi-storey carpark than the open surface lots, even if it means a slightly longer walk to the attraction, because given Singapore's hot and humid weather, it's always great to climb into a 'cool' car rather than one that feels like a sauna. Parking charges are S$3 for the first hour, S$2 for subsequent hours up to a maximum of S$8.

Those traveling by public transport can opt for either bus 927 or bus 138 as well as bus 926 (which only runs on Sundays/public holidays). At the bus bay, there are also special buses for those intending to go for the Hippo-Duck tour after a visit to the park. There is a taxi stand as well.

Also, do purchase the multi-park Park Hopper tickets if you intend to visit the Zoo, Night Safari and/or the Bird Park besides River Safari. There're 2-in-1, 3-in-1 and even 4-in-1 multi-park tickets that translates to good savings. These tickets are valid for 30 days so there is no pressure to cover them all within a day. It is also a good idea to purchase the tickets online. This means not only enjoying a discount but also saving valuable time queuing at the booth itself. Purchasing online is super easy and fast. Just make sure you key in a valid e-mail address to which the electronic tickets would be forwarded. Faced with a long queue at the booth, my husband purchased the tickets online using a smartphone and a credit card, whilst standing just outside the entrance. Then all we'd to do was to show the electronic tickets (in the phone) to the staff and get them scanned before being let in.

title: Surprisingly Educational and Well-designed
content:
I was not expecting much from the River Safari as it was just a ticket included in my package. I had been expecting for he S.E.A Aquarium more. However, when I showed up at the place, I was taken aback.

I was surprise at tanks size. It went from this surprise to another. The tank for Mekong River and Amazon River were amazing. I really loved the huge catfish, the lazy yet huge dugong. They were very lively at scene too. I enjoyed the walk through squirrel monkey forest. They were very nice and energetic. It was a very good way to educate children to blend themselves into the nature. Ooh, don't forget to check out the otters, very active and cute.

The sign boards were very informative, almost every information we need from the river. It is a good way to give your children practical lessons on wildlife. This could be a perfect choice for school trip and field trip, so as to raise awareness in protecting the nature and the environment. The sign boards were designed really nice, especially, the sign board for "Don't feed me, your food will get me sick" in the Squirrel Forest.

I could not visit the two pandas as the line was long, and I don't have enough time left for other attraction. You could really spend 2 hours here. They got attractive merchandise too. Make sure to buy the tumbler for only S$7, on sale now.

In sum, I enjoyed myself here, it was a getaway from the urban life and a good place to enrich your knowledge on mother nature.

title: Interesting, Well-Designed & Informational "Wild-Life" Experience
content:
A well-designed route which leads to an educational & enriching experience.

Although the pandas Jia Jia & Kai Kai were the main attraction, most of the other exhibits are

Take note of the bridge linking the 2 sides over a body of water. On one end there is a "colony" of storks. Ever so often, a stork or two would take flight & perch themselves on the top of small trees at the other side.
The small trees are near to the visitors.
It is quite easy to capture the flapping of the stork's wings - quite a rare moment of nature.

Tip: The queue for the boat ride is a rather long one. Advisable to purchase beforehand rather than do so at the premises.

The exhibits/enclosures are designed such that you can be very up close & personal with the animals, eg red panda, spider monkey.

The trained staff also do bring out some exhibits (bearded dragon, American hedgehog, etc) & allow visitors to have physical interaction, eg pat & stroke them.

There are many informational storyboards to educate the visitors.

We enjoyed the attraction very much.

Half a day is just about sufficient to cover the place.

title: Worth a visit
content: Nice place to see marine life up close. The gigantic glass tank above the walk through tunnel enhanced the experience. And they have 2 red panda and 2 black and white pandas. Stay for their feeding time if you can, they are so adorable.

title: Pandas!
content: We went after the zoo around 4.30 midweek so got plenty of good panda photos minus crowds :) the ride is not that long so u can wait for each other if u have a baby since little ones cannot go on the ride.

title: A bit of an unfortunate day
content:
We went to River Safari on the 15th June, which was a bit rainy and your typical garden-variety hot humid Singapore day. The exhibits are very interesting, combining an aquarium and a land zoo into one cohesive location. It's a bit crowded, but nothing surprising considering how popular the place is. Going to this particular part of the Singapore Zoo triad with infants/toddlers is a bit difficult, since the Amazon River Quest boat ride (which makes up a large chunk of the park) has a 1.06m height restriction. Unless you want to leave your child alone, it is a great idea to have someone who is willing to wait for the rest of your group and keep him/her company. This leads to the fact that we were drenched due to a massive downpour during the boat ride. A tarp "roof" to cover the boat during the rain was much desired, as umbrellas are not allowed (presumably so the animals are not harmed). If you want to go on the boat ride, you should book the boat ride about an hour to 90 mins after the time you enter the park. This gives you plenty of time at the aquariums and the panda exhibits that you will encounter en route to the River Quest entrance. The panda conservatory is very nice and air-conditioned, at the very least. The panda was sleeping in a corner and people, including us, were crowding to photograph it.
Once back outside of the panda room you will cross a long bridge which offers a stunning view of the real natural Singapore. It is sad Singapore is building so many artificial "natural" areas when the country itself has amazing natural beauty.
After the boat ride, you will visit a squirrel monkey "forest" and another aquarium called the Amazon Flooded Forest, probably the best part of the trip. A large group of at least 10 giant manatees were in the aquarium. It was their feeding time, and pans full of heads of lettuce were thrown into the aquarium, and they were all fighting to get a share; definitely a pleasant surprise to see.

title: Rare species on display
content:
The river safari is great for an "add on" to the zoo. Total time to see everything is only about 2 hrs to 2 1/2hrs. The walk is on a set path way and leads to the one "ride".....The aquariums along the path are well set out and very interesting.
BUT the ride is not that exciting. The boat takes you past several enclosures, but it's hard to see some animals and even harder to get pics as the boat doesn't stop....
The best part is the huge aquarium at the end... full of incredible species including about 10 MANITEES.... they are beautiful and wonderful to watch in the water.
Along the way there are opportunities for closeups with certain animals and even touch a few...so watch out for the keepers walking around with black microphone bags.
Only one restaurant and a few expensive drink stations... so best to take your own drinks.

title: Not as excited as expected
content: I have been to Night Safari, Singapore Zoo. I have seen the brochure and excited. I went there with my son and daughter. The Safari is not as big as expected. The idea of separating by river is cool. But the boat trip is not nice as expected. Difficult to see the animals and not so enjoyable as Night Safari. Overall, I think going to Singapore Zoo and Night Safari is better but you have gone to them all. River Safari is a choice but do not expect much.

title: Left wanting more!
content: We were a little disappointed because there more more fish than animals on show, although one aquarium in particular was the largest I have ever seen., I had hoped to see more of the furry variety .Luckily after completing the circuit and not catching a glimpse of the pandas, we went back a second time and for a few minutes, they sat and ate whilst everyone hurriedly took photos. They were a joy to see. The boat ride was over so quickly it was a shame. I have been to the zoo before and enjoyed it, but this time my sole intention was to see the Pandas and I am so happy I did. I think it was a little expensive for what is actually there.

title: Average. Boat ride is bordering scam.
content: Wide selection of fishes and marine life. Variety can be improved though. Some of the fishes did exhibit visible signs of stress due to poor water maintenance. There are a sore lack of of native aquatic plants in all exhibits. Forget about the boat ride. Other than a few flamingoes and a jaguar, there is nothing to see on the 10mins ride. Not worth queuing for it.

title: Put it on your itinerary
content: I had heard about the place but wasn't sure what it really is. This place is one of the best fresh water aquariums in the world. The way they have organised it unique with every famous river has its own section with its own environment and habitat. The panda enclosure is fabulous and the amazon river ride is amazing.

title: Good to visit...
content: Overall ok, but not managed to take the river cruise as fully booked due to school holidays. A good place for kids even adults to learn :)

title: Good but not exceptional
content:
A pleasant walk by the reservoir (which looks like the river).

Essentially an aquarium with river themes.

Highlight are the pandas, whose enclosure is air-conditioned and so very comfortable.

We did not go on the boat ride, as there was a long queue.

A good attraction, but not exceptional. The night safari and the zoo are better.

Worth a visit if you have half a day to kill.

title: A bit disappointing
content: I prefer the zoo and the Night Safari. The river safari is a bit small in my opinion, but it is sheltered, good for families with young children and elderly.

title: Skip the boat ride
content: I went for the manatees and pandas and they didn't disappoint. I went on a Sunday around lunchtime, there was quite a queue to get the tickets, but it moved quickly and efficiently. The exhibits were clean and the water in the tanks was so so clean that you could see even minute details on the fish and animals. I saw the male panda in his enclosure and the female panda is shy and so you'll be lucky to see both out and about. You do get funnel through the pandaemonium of merchandise afterwards, should you need panda slippers, this is the place to get them. The manatees were phenomenal, we got there just as they were being fed, they were so beautiful and there was so many of them and so many windows to see them through too. The viewing deck on the top of the tanks was really cool and gives a great view of the otters if you didn't see them in the tunnel. The river ride was short and not worth the extra $5, it was really hot and you speed past the enclosures. Your feet are the only part of you to get wet despite the small raids. The flamingoes are very pink, which is great, but unless you need to see the jaguars I would suggest you give it a skip.

title: A learning journey
content: It's like taking a trip down the various rivers.. The Amazon, Ganges, Murray , Mississippi , Mekong and Yangtze ..featuring the species found and it's unique features. The highlight would be the 2 pandas, if you are lucky to see it. Not many eatery once you are inside, so timed yourself to end the tour near lunch hour , where you get more choices at the exit.

title: It rained...
content:
We were excited. We paid and we're ready. But it rained!!!

It was very informative. We saw a lot of different animals including the panda which I like. But unfortunately it rained so hard that they canceled the river cruise. Good thing the area is equipped with different restaurants to relax and wait.

We spent a lot of time traveling via MRT on our way there from Carlton City Hotel. Then took a long bus ride back. Got to the hotel around 11:30 PM.

Will definitely go back and try again... no rain pls.

title: Erm......it is just another Zoo
content: Pretty much the same except, there are new additions llike pandas, piranhas & themes about various jungles like the amazon etc. Expect so much about the boat ride but end up dissapointing. Fret not, place are well covered by shelter. Eateries are good. Overall, well done but still preferred the original...

title: River Safari
content:
My family and I went to River Safari on 12/06/2014. It was a rather warm day. Nevertheless, we had lots of fun. We enjoyed ourselves a lot. My boys love the different rivers theme. They get to know more about different rivers in the world. Which is the longest, deepest rivers....... We saw lots of fishes. Some of the enclosures are air conditioned which is nice as the weather is very hot here in Singapore.
The river cruise is only 10 mins, too short. River Cruise fee is not included in the entrance fee. Children must be at least 1.06m to thake the cruise. Those who want to get a little splash should ask for the front seats.
The pandas are so cute. It's so enjoyable watching the pandas, especially in the air conditioning encloure. There are gift shop selling souvenirs but a bit pricey.

title: More informative than entertaining
content: This is a very good attraction, just not as entertaining as the bird park and night safari. It contains a lot of interesting information but is more focused on different habitats than animals. I appreciate that most of the park is covered from the sun. One major area for improvement is the boat ride. It reminded me a little of the jungle cruise at Disney World. I appreciate the effort it took to plan the ride, but the boarding and disembarking process was surprisingly inefficient for Singapore. This process took more time than the actual ride! I think this attraction is worth visiting once but not if you only have limited time in Singapore. I recommend taking water and snacks, since dining and concession options are very limited. If leaving by taxi, I would pre-book as the line gets very long.

title: Informative and Fun
content:
River Safari is a part of Singapore zoo. We went there using MRT and Bus. Alight at Ang Mo Kio MRT station and catch bus #138 for the zoo.
It's advisable to buy tickets for Zoo+River Safari Combo. First go for River Safari.
We got to know many interesting facts about the mighty rivers of the world like the Ganges, Nile, Amazon, Yangtze, Mekong. We also saw Red Panda and White Panda! You get an option for a boat ride in River safari. It's okay but cheap so you can as well buy those tickets. We could see animals living near river shores.
Overall, a very good experience!

title: Not as good as the ZOO but has pandas!
content: I have visited twice since the River Safari has opened. There are few interesting animals you can't see at the ZOO like beavers and of course the pandas. You can also learn about different rivers around the world and ride a boat on a small river. The boat ride is not essential as it takes about 7-10 minutes and if you are not very lucky you might not see many animals on the way. I also like to stop at a cafe by the panda enclosure for a chocolate custard panda bun and some lotus fried chips, yum :)

title: Great day out
content:
We spent the day at the River Safari and the zoo. My adult son is a huge panda lover, so it was a delight to see these lovely animals close up. We went on a Tuesday, so the queues weren't too bad. The actual river safari, which takes around 10 minutes, could have been better designed, but that is a minor gripe. The actual river exhibits were very good and showed fish and mammals that I haven't seen before, even though I've visited numerous aquaria throughout the world.

Well worth the visit.

title: Not as great as it sounds
content:
Very disappointed with the river safari. Not a lot to see in there, and even less on the boat ride (which is an additional $5 per person). The boat ride is basically a "log flume" ride from an amusement park, without the thrills. You go past some animal enclosures and you're lucky if you see half of them. It doesn't help that there is no option to try to see these animals unless you go on the boat ride!

Only positive from this place was the Red pandas and Giant pandas - I'm sure they are only placed in the River Safari to make sure people have to visit the Zoo AND the River Safari. Pandas in a RIVER safari? Yeah right.

title: Disappointing
content:
Its a difficult (if not impossible) task to represent a major river's ecosystem if all you have is few fishes+reptiles. And that's where the River Safari fails. Each of these rivers are the lifeblood of their respective countries (Congo, Nile, Mekong, Ganges...) and each is represented in 10-15 metres of space; showing the above mentioned fishes+reptiles. One just does not get a feel for this
The boat ride is really bad - its about 10 mins long & a lot of animals were not to be seen.
The pandas have an enclosure of their own and are nice to behold. There was a short show with iguanas & a kite, which was also good. The Flooded Forest exhibit was good too.
Restroom facilities are inadequate, so go to the loo just before you enter.
Thankfully, I did not pay for the tickets,(I got a free pass for me & my family from my employer) which was the best part of this excursion (its still a pretty penny by taxi from the city centre)

title: Safari in the River
content: Newest attraction around Singapore Zoo and Night Safari. Many interesting zones. Don't miss the super cute Panda and take a ride along the river.

title: Once, is enough....
content:
A shadow of what the Singapore Zoological Garden and Singapore Night Safari has to offer. Disappointing trails and almost below average River Boat ride. For the price that you pay, it is just "average" or worse, "disappointing".

Some saving graces though: The monkeys (which run free in some enclosures which are open to public) and the Red Pandas (which are SO CUTE!).

If you can spend beyond 3hours here... you MUST be a real animal lover. Or just a slow-walker.

title: Nothing special. . . a bit disappointed truthfully
content:
I was a bit disappointed to be honest.

I had pre-booked everything online (online discount), including the 'boat ride'.

The exhibitions are okay, the zoo is definitely more exciting.

The Boat Ride was very disappointing in my opinion. Make sure you get there at least 45 mins before hand so you can look at the animals on the way to the boat ride and don't need to rush. (which is located pretty much in the middle of the Safari).

Ok for dates, although the restaurants there suck.

title: Overcrowded in school holidays. Avoid
content: I am sure off peak it is better but in school holidays I could not move and in the heat it was extremely uncomfortable. The giant pandas were well done but again the crowds were relentless. Best exhibit was the manatees.

title: Love the pandas!
content: It's advisable to go here if you're travelling with kids. There are a lot of animals to see especially the cute red pandas and the black and white ones. Be sure to try the Mama Panda Kitchen as it serves cute Panda Pao's which are really cute to eat and $5.50 coffee. Quite expensive but is really worth a try.

title: Very clever marketing !! Not worth
content: We absolutely did not like this place ... only think good here were the cute pandas... but we felt it was a waste of money !!! Not recommended ... It just another zoo ... and mind well to book boat ride in advance as it's usually full....

title: Average Attraction
content: Singapore River Safari is situated next to the Singapore Zoo. Transport to the attraction is convenient, you can either drive there, of take public buses or taxi. The park was built to house the 2 giant pandas loaned from China in 2012. The size of the park is only a third of the zoo next to it and the ticket is priced at SGD23.00 with additional SGD5 for the river boat ride. With SGD5, I think the boat ride is a rip off as it finished in 10 minutes and the speed of the ride was so fast and we hardly able to properly admire the exhibits along it. The park attractions are mostly covered and shielded from rain and shine. The food in the Panda Mama Kitchen is surprising good for a park attraction especially the ramen.

title: nice day out
content: My second visit. Tuis time the amazon river quest ride is open but I did not get on it because there is a min height of 1.06m which none of my children have met, no worries about rain or sun because the entire place is covered with a sheltered walkway and airconditioned at the very end where the manatees are. Love the pkace and is a wonderful half day out. We concluded the ebtire walk in abt 3.5 hours.

title: Great esp for the pandas
content:
A great mini version of the zoo, the highlights being the pandas.
It has a lovely theme running throughout,which is very educational and informative
The size of the park makes it ideal for little kids.
The panda cafe was great for a snack, both the gyoza and wonton were very tasty

title: River Safari -
content:
Do’s and don’t’s.
DO wear some comfy walking shoes. This place covers 12 hectares/30 acres so expect to cover some ground.
Also DO take some water with you. It's a hike and on a humid day you'll need something to sip on.

DON'T go with a tour group.
Of all the things we did in Singapore we spent more time traveling to and from this attraction than any other.
In addition to that Chinatown is the mustering point for a number of tours so by the time you are picked up at your hotel, pick up other guests from their hotels and then dropped at Chinatown then sorted as to what site you’re visiting and then buy your ticket there’s another ½ hour gone so, in reality 1 & ½ hours of your morning or afternoon tour is taken up with travel and logistics.
We found that our group split up very quickly once we got to River Safari and because we knew we were on a tight time frame it added some stress to the trip that we didn’t need, constantly trying to find the other group members.
We could and would have spent more time here but ended up going on a “speed tour” and didn’t see nearly everything that we wanted to.

Anyway, to the highlights
The River Safari features enclosed areas that are themed to 5 different major river systems from around the world with plenty of vantage points both above and below the water line.
There are a huge number of animals on display and the manatee was probably my favourite.

I’m still struggling to work out what river system the polar bear comes from!! :-)

The Giant Panda Forest is a special climate-controlled display with conditions that are programmed to change through the year to duplicate the seasons they would experience in the wild.
There's Red as well as your standard B&W pandas!!
This display had only been open for about a year when we visited but I would have expected that there would be better management of the public because the viewing areas are fairly limited for the giant pandas, which most people seemed to want a picture of, and it was difficult to get up close.

OK!! The theme park ride.
If you have no expectations then you won’t be disappointed.
I’m saying that because this thing from what I’m told is NOT working more often than it is.
I’m going on what our tour guide told us and apparently it had been out of action for a number of months just prior to us visiting and it broke down again when were there, costing us more time on an already tight schedule. We eventually got on board and there are some great animals to be seen but enclosures are very small so I did feel sorry for the animals.

Overall the River Safari was good but I wouldn't recommend going on one of the package tours unless you go in the morning, take your time, and then make your own way back.

title: I love it so much a highly recommend place to go
content:
a handicap friendly Safari , staff are friendly and helpful, I bring my old parents there and they find 2 wheel chair for us .
We enjoy the whole trip . everywhere are sheltered so even raining still can enjoy our walk.
I love the small money run over and come toward us within contact range
the Panda are so active, clean and lovely
Specially the raccon is so cute
you can also find different cocodile , fish in different part of the world
The stars are Otter and Mermaid( what is that -find out by yourself)

title: Worthwhile trip...educational too
content: The walk around the safari is well-sheltered so even on a hot day, it was a pleasant stroll. Don't have to worry about being in the hot sun. The river cruise was a disappointment though....the speed could have been slower to give us more time to spot some of the animals and/snap photos.

title: River Safari
content: Quite a nice to place to visit with kids because they can get to know more about the sea animal and of course panda. Just that the river boat ride not so fun because too short journey and nothing much to see.

title: Boring.
content:
Went there because we got free tickets from our company. I was with my husband and 2 children, 6yo and 2yo. Got boat ride tickets also but my 2yo and I couldn't go on it because of height limit. So there's NO way at all to see the animals that you can see if you had the boat ride, which is reallyreally ridiculous. At least have a walkway, so famillies with small children can still see.

No halal food available at all. It's like being in a zoo at China, with all the China-themed restaurants inside.

Don't waste money. Don't bother going. We spent barely 1.5 hours in it.

title: Wow
content: Get in early between 9am to 10am to see the pandas in action. The panda will be moving around and eating during this period, and will "sleep" after that. So make sure that this is the first stop of the day.The red panda is essential active all day long. As for the river safari boat ride, its about 8 mins, and you can view travelers' experience on youtube. Personally, it depends on your luck to see the animals, but for me, the animals were "hiding".

title: Very Informative and Engaging Experience For Children
content:
We had taken a trip down to the newly opened attraction in Singapore - River Safari. The theme park is very educative for young children as they get to view a variety of Aquatic animals from all over the world. The entire safari is neatly grouped in continents and acquatic creatures are housed accordingly. There is a big variety of species and it is a very engaging experience. The Plus point is to watch Giant Panda and Red Panda in the enclosure. And.. the short boat ride is also very interesting.

Overall a good expereince and is very informative for the children

title: Not up to expectation
content:
I went to the river safari because my company gave me 2 free tickets. Thankfully, I did not pay for the tickets because it was such a huge disappointment. The boat ride was sold out when I got there at 11 am and the other attractions did not justify the price of the tickets.

I would give it a miss unless there are free tickets as it is absolutely not worth it.

title: Disappointment Safari
content: Went during the week, the boat ride was closed. Boat ride is an extra $5, so we were not charged for it. However looking at the park map, half the animals are along the boat ride. So we did not get to see half of the animals there, we were very disappointed.

title: Boat ride disappoints
content: The short boat ride and the need to book a slot do not justify the time, effort & cost. There isn't as much to see. The name 'river safari' conjures something big and exciting; what one saw during the boar ride is neither. Indeed the highlights are the Pandas (including the red version), which is a better fit with the zoo proper.

title: Family visit to here
content: Visit this place with my 3 teenager sons. Surprisingly all of them enjoy this place very much. This place is definitely worth a visit. The aquarium is very impressive. Book online to avoid disappointment on the river boat tour. You get 20% discount on the ticket too if book online.

title: Short distraction for the kids
content: The themed sections was good info-tainment for the kids. By the time we finished visiting all the sections, they were tired and called it a day. Particularly loved the cute pandas and the Amazon flooded forest.

title: Mystic and wonderful place!
content: Must see at 8-9pm as most animals are awake. The tour train is a great experience and one gets to see different species of Fauna. Keep about 2 hours for the tour + Dinner. Dont miss out on the shops around especially one place where you get foot cleansing massage from several little squiggly fish!!

title: An amazing River-themed Wildlife Park
content:
When my husband informed us that he had 4 complimentary tickets to River Safari, my daughter and I were less than keen. We were sceptical about what to see there and figured that we would finish exploring the whole place within an hour. We were definitely wrong because we ended up spending 4 hours there.

River Safari, Asia's first and only river-themed wildlife park, is nestled between Singapore Zoo and Night Safari. When we reached there at 11 am, we had already missed the timing of the boat rides and had to settle for the next available boat ride at 2.30 pm. As such, it is wise to go to the park early and book the boat ride time slot at the ticketing counter as there are limited seats available and are issued on a first-come-first-serve basis.

There are two zones in the park - Rivers of the World and Wild Amazonia. There are 7 rivers to explore at the Rivers of the World zone, namely Mississippi, Congo, River Nile, Ganges, Murray, Mekong and Yangtze rivers. The Mississippi river, is home to the beavers, alligator gar and paddlefish. All exhibits are in a glass viewing gallery so that we can come up close and personal to the water creatures. We spotted the African dwarf crocodile at the Congo River and learned that this crocodile is seldom hunted because its skin is too rough for good quality leather. We were amused to see the Tiger Fish with its sharp teeth exposed as it has no lips. River Nile is the longest river on earth and houses the giant Puffer fish, which when alarmed, will inflates its body to scare away predators. Ganges River has the Indian Gharials and we spotted two ferocious ones lying beside each other. Mekong River is the 7th longest river in Asia and is the most productive river in the world. Here we saw the Mekong giant catfish and the giant freshwater stingray, both were very impressive in size. We also learned that the scales of the giant Siamese carp are used to make shuttlecocks. Yangtze River is China's longest river and we spotted the Chinese giant salamander and the rare Yangtze alligator here. We also learned that the shallow waters of the rice fields are homes to a variety of wildlife such as the lesser adjutant stork, cattle egret and elephant trunk snake.

Our next stop is the Giant Panda Forest, which is always popular, with long queues. This place is home to the Golden Pheasants, Red pandas and the adorable two resident Giant pandas, Kai Kai and Jia Jia. We were fortunate to catch the Giant pandas in action as they were awake at that time. Kai Kai was happily eating his bamboo leaves and was simply basking in the adoration and attention by the visitors. It was hilarious to see his playful antics as he rolled on the grass after his meal, as an insect had bitten him. Finally, he went to his bamboo resting place to take a nap and it was such a blissful sleep. Jia Jia, on the other hand, is shy and was strolling for a short while before she retreated to her den.

As we strolled along the viewing deck to the Amazon River Quest, which is located at the Wild Amazonia, we took several shots of the scenic and calming view of the Upper Seletar reservoir. We took the boat ride to the Amazon rainforest for more sightings of the animals and spotted the collared peccary, Brazilian tapir, jaguar and the Carribean flamingos but I wished the boat had stopped at a few designated stops for us to take photos as it is difficult to take photos from a moving boat.

The common squirrel monkeys at the Squirrel Monkey forest live in troops and are excellent climbers and you can hear their lively chatter at this tropical forest. The monkeys were leaping from trees to trees. There was a sign to warn us about urine wash and we experienced urine droplets from the trees. We found out that the monkeys rub urine on their bodies to mark trails for troop members to follow and we were fortunate that we had our hats on.

Our final stop is the Amazon Flooded Forest where we saw the electric eels, the red-bellied piranhas, Royal Panaque catfish, graceful manatees and the playful Giant river otters at the aquarium exhibit.
