The River Safari the animals that could be seen were great and the fish and other creatures were well displayed in the the other extensive display areas however, the poor signage and long wait did nothing to overcome our dissapointment with the 10 minute boat ride!

title: Very good wildlife park
content: This park has a lot of beautiful aquatic animals. Many of them are endangered. I went to River Safari when the boat ride hasn't opened but I had a nice day. the queue are just 15 minutes, not one or two hours as they said. Nice park.

title: Thank goodness for the pandas
content:
Must say that the river safari ride itself is over hyped - more 'small world' than safari! Lots of walking and not the ambiance of the zoo or night safari. That said the aquariums are pretty special and the pandas go a long way towards making up for other shortcomings.

I'd suggest combining the river safari with either the zoo or night safari for best experience.

title: Overated
content:
The highlight of the River Safari are the pandas, Jia Jia and Kai Kai. We waited abt 1hr in the queue for less than 10min boat ride, definitely is a waste of time. Animals here are 10% found in the big rivers like the Amazon, Ganges, Yantze River etc, so they said. Overall ticket is overpriced for the unimpressive experience. The staff were nice and friendly though.

If given a choice to go to the Zoo, Night Safari or River Safari, I would rather choose the Zoo then Night Safari.

title: Panda, manatees & river ride
content: Adorable red panda, amusing panda, awesome manatee and cool river ride pretty much sum up the experience for me. Plenty of shades and air conditioned environment helps in the hot humid climate.

title: Not worth your money or time
content: It was disappointing especially being one of the Singapore wildlife reserves Park and after the very successful zoo and night safari. The full prices of about S$25 and S $18 for children are certainly overpriced especially when compared to these other parks. Although you book a seat in advance for the boat ride, you end up waiting about one hour as there is only one boat loaded at a time, so be prepared to be in the que when you turn up at your alloted time. The boat ride lasts for only 7 minutes and we saw less than half of the animals as the boats do not stop and animals are not always visible. It's a joke. They should have left theme park rides to people who do theme parks and should have stuck to what Singapore wildlife reserves parks do best-that is animal exhibits, conservation and animal breeding. Management should fix the issues quickly as we overheard many saying they would not come back. Unfortunately the negatives overshadow the large aquariums that seem to be lame replicas of the aquarium in sentosa. Bring the manatees back to the main zoo. Make that the best zoo in the world. No, there is no need to give River safari a try. Spend your time next door at the zoo or night safari instead.

title: The new Panda enclosure is brilliant
content:
Singapore zoo really is the best In the world in my opinion. The new river safari park is brilliant. (Although the river boat ride is terribly naff, so don't be too upset if you miss out, because you need a ticket when you enter! It is just a boat ride through a few enclosures and you can see them all without the boat!)
The panda exhibit is brilliant and huge. Jia Jia and Kai Kai are adorable. Jia Jia is shy and might be in her cave, but she did come out. It is so fabulous seeing them so well cared for. Great merchandise too.
The squirrel monkey exhibit lets you wander around a large enclosure and get very close indeed. It tells you not to approach them, but the monkeys loved my shoes and kept coming over to investigate. Brilliant. They are very very cute. Also, don't miss the feeding of the manatees or the polar bear (the polar bear enclosure is actually visible from both parks as it links both)

title: Rip off place; overrated
content:
Trust me, if you're not in line by 8:30 am, you're not getting on the boat ride, which is the ONLY reason to go on a "river safari". we decided to try to get on, and they said there is no way to get on without a ticket reservation. We had been given some false information, so they agreed to let us go sort of standby. They said it would be another 15 minutes. After waiting 90 minutes, we gave up. The line didn't move a single inch in 90 minutes.

The rest of the place wasn't that great, other than the tank with the manatees in it, which was quite spectacular. Only one panda was available to see, but it was a nice setup, and they don't allow too many people in at once, so it makes it a bit better.

Gift shop was typical Singapore zoo rip off: $33 to $36 for a simple t shirt. do the math. Total rip off. The river exhibits weren't that interested, and way too crowded to see much up close or comfortably. Admission price is not worth it, and the only real attraction is to see a live panda. Nice, but not worth the effort, heat, costs, crowds, rude pushy people, etc.

title: An interesting day
content: We spent half a day at the river safari, that is plenty of time to see everything there. They have a huge array of fish from all over the world as well as other animals. My favourite enclosure was the squirrel monkeys where you walked through their cage and they came right past you and crossed your path. The boat ride was good but was much shorter than we expected. There are some good animals to see on your ride though. The Giant Pandas were lovely to see. There are very few places to eat in the park and we didn't see anywhere to buy water etc. except at the eating places so make sure you have plenty with you.

title: Go for Panda and not the boat ride
content:
Boat ride is really boring and doesn't live up to its hype. The ride is very simple and does have a minor 3 bumps and thats it!!

The best part and value for the money spent is to meet the Panda and that's obviously a great experience and the only experience.

title: DON'T BUY THE TICKET IF NO BOAT
content:
When i get there, the staff inform me that the boat are totally full, but when i go to the pier (around 4:30 PM), i see no one in the queue and no boat at all. :(

DON'T BUY THE TICKET if there's no boat service on that day, else you'll spend 35 SGD with only few animals to see.

title: amazing river theme park
content: Amazing theme park. Went there couple of months ago. Nice to see Panda Jia-Jia and Panda Kai Kai. Amazing animals from different countries.

title: Panda's are the highlight
content: If you like fish you will love it of course from it's name there is a clue it shows different species from the rivers of the world. The panda's were a bonus and we were lucky enough to see them. Unfortunately we didn't actually get to do the river cruise we didn't have enough time to queue, to be fair they did warn us that it would be a long wait and they didn't start running the cruise boats until about midday for some reason which was a shame as there was a few more animal species we missed, but for us it was worth the entry to see the panda's alone.

title: Waste of time and money
content:
We got there at 3pm right after the zoo, and even though we bought the ticket, we could not board on the cruise because it was already fully booked.
The person at the entrance told us the cruise was just 15% of the park so we wouldn't miss much, the fact is that half of the park is watchable only from the cruise...
Could not get some refund as well.
So in the end it's just a long empty walk. Only noticeable thing is one dirty panda.
Go to the zoo and only the zoo. Or jurong bird park. The rest is crap.

title: Don't expect too much
content: Having previously enjoyed the night safari, we were anxious to try this new experience. The concept is good, the pandas are gorgeous but the boat ride, which was what we looked forward to was only a 10 minute ride. Disappointing. Best done as part of a zoo visit or the night safari, don't go just for this.

title: VERY BAD!!
content: I went there with my wife and 2 kids (4 and 2 1/2). After a first very long queue, they told us that our daughter (2 1/2) is to small for the ride!!! "It's a bumpy ride" they said... So my wife stayed with her. The ride is 15 minutes, nothing interesting to see at all and no bumpy rides... Nothing dangerous for a child accompanied by their STUPID... But its Singapore, the country where people are afraid of EVERYTHING . So almost 1.5hrs queue for a 15 minutes ride... Where you can see 3 monkeys, a jaguar, some birds and some wild pigs... DONT GO THERE!!

title: MUST-GO
content:
You will not only meet animals and fishes in endangered but also learn about them and their environment.
Dugongs eating fishes shocked me as we had only seen them eating vegetable.

One thing you should not fail is to check the time-table of the shuttle bus services backing to your Hotel or City.
Otherwise, you will queue for a Taxi and wait for a long time.

title: Can be better!
content: Failed to get a boat ride first time round; tried again when we went there a second time, still no boat ride despite being there very early! A great disappointment - this is something the management should be addressing. We ended up walking all the way. Overall it is a very spacious park; we went there on a quiet weekday morning. It was pleasant. The main attraction being the pandas, other than that, honestly, nothing much to look at. You could have seen other animals next door at the Zoo.

title: If Pandas are your thing, don't miss this!
content: Try to be at the Giant Pandas pens at approx. 3-3.30p.m. when they are fed- with luck the shy little female will be enticed out - to complete the Panda experience there a Red Pandas as well! This is a new attraction, comprising eight river habitats e.g the Yangtze, Mississippi, excellent signage accompanies the walk through exhibits of of flora and fauna plus manatees, crocodiles and fish in the aquarium areas. Finish your trip (book for later in the day to avoid crowds) with the river ride, you may see some big cats if you're lucky!

title: Not perfect but GREAT!
content:
Advice who want to go RS (River Safari) BEST day would be Friday. Better on weekdays. Avoid weekend.

Reason:
Weekdays (Mon-Thu) would be a better day to go due to less crowd BUT high chances of maintenance in some certain area.
Weekend (Sat & Sun), To avoid disappointment, pls try to avoid this 2 day, High chance of NO slot for The Amazon River Ride and they will open queue for the Panda section due to high demand on Panda bears.
Friday is the BEST day to go. If u wanna enjoy the whole RS, Best time is 10am since RS open @ 9am. A lot of slot for The Amazon River Ride. NO maintenance is done due to start of the weekend.

*Reminder: PLEASE bring your own water! $$$ there so freaking exs and hot weather from around 11am-1pm.

title: Not as good as Singapore zoo or Night safari
content:
This place is situated right next to Singapore zoo and night safari, so in short u can do 3 things in 1 day, morning zoo, then river safari then night safari.
Overall this place is just OK, with lots of various aquariums of different kinds of fish categorized into various areas.
Panda thing is also just OK OK.
I think a total of 3 hours is more than enough for this place.
There are no shows per say in this park like in zoo or night safari so u can visit any time. Even the boat safari (which is too much hyped) us just OK OK, nothing great. All in all just OK experience.

title: from a logistical point of view...my verdict is FAIL!
content:
queued up for 30 minutes, the staff told me, BUY TICKETS ONLINE. my response? I told them their online ticketing DISALLOWED SENIORS ABOVE AGE 60 FROM BUYING THE DISCOUNTED TICKETS thus i had no choice but to waste time queuing up because of the FLAWS OF THE TICKETING SYSTEM :(

when i arrived at the BOAT RIDE@ 10am, it was SHUT DOWN due to full capacity, WHAT KIND OF ZOO OR ATTRACTION builds a boat ride which can only handle a limited ride load?!? Terrible, unacceptable & 100% i am NEVER GOING BACK TO THIS PLACE UNTIL THE MANAGEMENT realises that it is unacceptable to run the RIVER SAFARI in this manner!

left the place disappointed, disillusioned & with shock that wildlife reserves is continuing to give this kind of sub-standard visitor experience to hundreds of visitors like me =(

title: New and exciting
content:
It is a brand new venue and suitable for all ages. I brought my kids here and even though it is very far (took around 1:30 hours by train + bus), the trip was worth it.

They have a wide collection of river animals including the giant manatees and Giant Panda. My kids love them! They also have this boat safari which was still free and my little girl just made the minimum height requirement (1.06 meter). The ride was exciting as we went through shallow stream and some small waterfalls!! It is safe but expect a little splash here and there. And no, it is not scary at all.

Totally worth it.

title: Pandas worth the visit
content: Combined River Safari with morning at the zoo. The boat ride was closed for maintenance on the day we went - the girl told us it was only a 10 minute ride so we opted not to come back another day. Was very interesting but for us the highlight of the visit was the opportunity to see a panda! There were no queues at all and we had an uninterrupted view of the male panda as he lolled about the enclosure eating. Got some great photos with plenty of time to take them as hardly anyone else there. I think we were very lucky as we could see the roped off areas for crowd queue control all empty.

title: Absolutely disappointing
content: With the amount of hype this attraction has been receiving, one would think it would be amazing place to visit. Well it is amazing. Amazingly bad! I don't know if they rushed to complete the park but the overall feel of the park is 'cheap'. Its funny how the normally white and black pandas are black and brown here. There's only one part of the park that I truly liked. The manatee exhibit! This says a lot about a supposedly multi million dollar tourist attraction. My advise is to save your money and visit the Singapore Zoo which is just next door.

title: Go Early. Book Early
content:
that is essential. There's a feeding session starting from 9 a.m. from the start of the safari. so you get to catch something. Don't go expecting to see quick moving animals or animal shows.
This is the RIVER safari. So a lot of what you see are in the water. (not exactly responsive to humans!)

Book your slot for the Boat Ride early (do it online before you go!, the queue to book at the counter is long!!) The boat ride is short, and really nothing much to shout about. But it is an ride to see and check out a few stuff up close.

The best part for us was the Amazone Forest. It was an amazing exhibit. Very educational. But again, I must stress. There are no animals that are responsive to humans there. Everything's in the water.

title: Definitely good for one visit
content:
We went on a weekend and having been told to anticipate long queues, we tried to be there early. We could only be there around 9.45. There is a separate queue (took us about 25mins) for the river ride which is basically a timestamp. The river ride lasted only about 10 minutes and it is the only way to view some of the animals such as the anteater, jaguar, iguana and the flamingos. The ride itself was enjoyable and pleasant. If you are seated in the front row, expect to get some minor splashes. It is not enough to soak you to the bone, but you'll need to keep away your cameras and phones, etc from time to time.

The flooded forest was amazing, I like the high glass and it was nice to see the manatee, among other aquatic animals. The river otters were nice, graceful swimmers and we stopped there for quite a while. Several fish species (including piranha) were to be seen and they were very interesting.

My personal favourite was the squirrel monkey. The rivers themselves were very informational. There is a fair bit of info and to digest all that, one should plan for quite some time. If visitors are not interested in diverse fish species and other aquatic life forms or do not stop to read the info panels, they will be done in an hour and will return with the impression that "it's just fish".

Coming to the pandas section, there are the red ones and the giant pandas. We were fortunate enough to see all of them. I was told that sometimes one or both the pandas are resting/sleeping in their enclosures. During our visit the male was resting and chomping on some bamboo shoots and carrots. The female was endlessly pacing, so basically there were good photo opportunities in seated as well as moving postures. We also got to see a bit of the polar bear swimming in his own enclosure. Was a sight worth seeing, a polar bear (or any other beast of that size) swimming underwater.

In summary, I would recommend it to people who are interested in diverse plant, animal and bird species and also have some world geography idea. A little bit of prior research is needed to know what is in store and whether that matches one's expectations and interests. There is not much of a point driving up/ taking a bus from Choa Chu Kang/ taking a cab here and standing in queues for hours only to give a cursory glance at something that arouses no interest.

title: The JK Pandas
content:
* At first we thought the pandas were at the zoo but it turned out they weren't there.

* So we went to River Safari and found out there were pandas there. This is the highlight of our trip.

* We missed out the boats because they were fully booked but it didn't matter because it took me 30 mins to finish walking the whole River safari. The most worthwhile time is looking at the pandas.

* Then we waited till 7pm for the Night Safari which everyone was waiting for it in the evening.

title: waste of time and money
content:
went there early, like 9 am. no crowds at all, not even for panda viewing. we were told complimentary boat rides start at 12, and so we booked our slots for 12. but then, by 10 am, we had toured the whole park. so we walked another round, had a snack and proceeded to the boat ride waiting area. we were shocked that queue already started at 11.10 am. and we ended standing in the queue for 50 minutes before we could get on the boat. nothing great, but at least, we could finally rest our legs.
children agreed this will be our first and last time to river safari. in our opinion, river safari was a colossal failure compared to the zoo and night safari, which we went so many many times as still find good to go.

title: Horrible- don't waste your money!!
content:
I'm usually give quite positives reports, but not in this case!! This is quite frankly a waste of time and money. The day didn't start well when the coach from Vivocity never arrived. After several calls to be told " it's on it's way, it's broken down, it's been replaced" we gave up and got a cab. Probably should have done that in the first place as only 3SGD more for the 3 of us. The other family waiting, who has small kids, gave up and went home to swim. We should have done the same!!
The attractions are very mediocre and the displays are very boring. Had to keep reminding myself that this whole place has only recently opened. Looked like it was outdated already.
Arrivingl late, of course there were no tickets left for the boat. This was a shame as it's the only way to see some of the animals. The red pandas were great, but the panda's generally were disappointing. The female one is so shy, that she spends most of her time hiding under her bed in her cage, which is relayed to the public via CCTV......the park has no water fountains anywhere, so on a hot day the only option is to buy water from the store, so make sure you take your own.!!! Oh and at the end of the day we had to join the taxi queue and wait 90mins for a cab along with zillions of other people including tired little children. Not a park official in sight to try and organise the random arrival and disbursement of taxi's....couldn't figure any other way to get back to the city. Give this attraction a miss!!!! The night safari is fantastic!!

title: You can give it a miss...
content:
The River Safari was touted as the latest and newest attraction in Singapore. First of all, only two ticket booth and you have hundreds of visitors queuing to get the tickets. Next you will need to join the queue if you want to take the 10 mins Kiddy Safari Ride as you need to book a timing to go for the ride.

The main attraction is the pandas and with kids and noisy tourists around, the pandas seemed stressed and hide in the enclosure rather then coming out.

The Safari ride is over-rated. It's just a 10 mins kiddy ride along a 4 feet wide drain, but the wait would be an hour or so.

title: To to the night safari or zoo instead
content: I have brought my kids there twice, hoping to catch the boat ride. Both times we got there in the morning but the boat ride was already full for the whole day. From the other reviews I read, it sounds like we didn't miss too much. Nevetheless what's the point of designing a park whereby quite a number of animals can only be seen from the boat ride, but that ride does not have the capacity to cater to all your visitors? To add insult to injury, they still charge the full price for the tickets even if the boat ride is full for the day! The saving grace is the pandas which is a good attraction, although be prepared to brave the huge crowds to see them. The flooded forest is nice too, although the question you need to ask yourself is whether you would pay this price and fight your way through the crowds just for that. My advice - go to the zoo or night safari instead...

title: River Safari Singapore more like an Aquarium Museum
content:
I went to River Safari for the first time, to my surprise, the welcoming place is the fish in the aquarium. To my disappointment that the boat has already fully booked and no way of using the boat for sight-seeing.

Indeed, an unforgettable place to go to see the 02 Panda and the Squirrel Monkey. That will worth of all..

It not a big area, hence, 1-2 hours will be able to finish the whole area other than queuing up to see the Panda. i will not go again if i have another opportunity.

title: What a waste of time and money.
content: There are three star attractions here. The Pandas, the Manatee and the Jaguar (I think, it's one of the big cats). The Jaguar, and other secondary star animals (like the giant ant-eater) could be seen only from the boat. It was impossible to get a ride on the boat. They should have known that there will be more people visiting the park than could possibly fit on the boat throughout the day. Plus, some poor sod who got his ticket for the boat ride at 11:30 AM for the last boat ride at 5:30 PM would have to wait 6+ hours at the River Safari before he could get on the boat. Terrible organisation and planning. Very disappointing, as it seemed to have so much potential. They should integrate it into the zoo.

title: NOT a safari and hugely understaffed
content:
We were so disappointed with our experience, particularly as the Night Safari (which we visited on a previous trip) was fantastic.

First off, if you decide to visit this attraction after reading my review then I strongly suggest you book ONLINE and print out your booking to ensure fast entry. We arrived at 11am and we queued over ONE HOUR just to get our entry tickets on a Friday morning after Christmas. There was only one person selling tickets on the desk and the poor girl was being worked to the bone. In fact, the whole place was hugely understaffed and because of this people couldn't find anyone to answer questions and kept interrupting her which delayed the ticket queue even more. By the time we finally bought our tickets we were feeling irritated, hot and unhappy and my back and feet were hurting from standing for so long.

Worse still, the Amazon River 'Safari' was sold out and had been before we'd even arrived in the queue, so the main attraction we wanted wasn't available to us.

When we finally got in we were surprised to find that what we entered was a series of aquariums, not dissimilar to a sea life centre. The fish/mammals on display were not impressive and we'd seen most of them before in smaller aquariums. The 2 crocodiles looked miserable in their small, glass box. When we entered the Panda enclosure there was a huge queue again just to get in so we decided to skip it completely having been already fed up with queuing for the day.

All the restaurants had queues going out of the doors, so again we went hungry and skipped eating. At 1pm we walked past a couple of mobile hot food and drink stalls and their display cabinets were empty - hot food was sold out. I almost treated myself to an icecream but then saw the prices, laughed and turned away.

We walked past the queue for the Boat Ride and, despite the fact that these people were lucky enough to have tickets, they were still queuing for ages.

The only bit we genuinely enjoyed was the monkey enclose as we were able to walk amongst the creatures and they were such fun to watch.

We were so relieved when we finished the tour and came out of the exit!! We couldn't get home fast enough, even though we had to then queue half an hour for a taxi.

All in all, this might only be fun for very small children. I cannot see how many more people would have a good time here. It pains me to be so negative, but I feel you should hear the truth!

Go to the Night Safari instead - that's wonderful.

title: Misleading advertising equals very disappointed
content: This was very different to what I was expecting. From all of the advertising it looks as though you go on a river safari and see all of the animals from a boat. So not the case. The river safari is actually a walking loop that showcases the different rivers and their wildlife around the world. There is a huge lineup to see the panda's. There is a theme park type ride that takes you around a little water channel but you don't see much and only goes for about 5 -10 mins. I think they need to re-look at their advertising or rename the river safari as a journey through the rivers of the world. Very misleading!!

title: Disappointing
content:
My husband and I and two children visited the RS on January 7, 2014. We arrived by approx 10 am and we're informed that the boat tour was closed for maintainance. Given the fact that 20% of the park needs to be seen from the boat we were expecting a discount on our tickets but none was given. This was very disappointing and we were surprised by the lack of good basic business practice: if you can't provide guests the full experience, offer them a discount or some other form of compensation.
Our experience in the park itself was underwhelming for what we paid for the tickets. We have been friends of the zoo for 9 years and have always found that to be a worthwhile investment. We would not join as members of the RS unless a very good discount was offered.

We found the staff in some cases to be uneducated about the animals in the park. When I asked a group of staff members if there were any river dolphins in the Yangtze River section (as displayed on signs), I was practically laughed at for my seemingly ridiculous question....not very professional. Our young kids were told to be quiet by the staff attending to the pandas even though they were just quickly passing through! Needless to say, we felt very unwelcome in this exhibit and so we left quickly.

So these are a few negative experiences we had for you to consider. Of course, there were some positive ones too. I wonder what the future of the RS will be if it's competing with other more fabulous Eco-parks in Singapore....

title: Go to Singapore Zoo for a wow experience rather than this one
content:
I am an avid fan of Singapore Zoo, so I expect this one gives me the same experience. Unfortunately, this isn't the case.
The animals are too few, the fish are so-so (I understand that since it bears the name 'river', it shows river animals, which is nowhere as attractive as sea fish in terms of colors and shapes.
The River Boat ride that they boast, turns out to be an average. This time they still give free charge for the rides. But if they want to charge it on top of the entrance fee? I don't think I will want to ride it.
Prefer Singapore Zoo 10 times than this one.

title: Not as good at the actual Singapore Zoo
content: We did a Singapore Zoo/River Safari combo and in comparison, the River Safari is not worth the visit. Nothing much "River" about it and the Amazon quest boat ride (that we had to queue for despite having booked a time slot?) was a total joke - over in two minutes, barely got to see the animals. The star attractions, the pandas and the manatees, are of course a delight but it feels like a ripe-off that they are not part of the zoo. Great way to milk out an extra 25$ in entrance fee... The rest of the time we walked around looking a fish - if that´s what you want to see, go to S.E.A. Aquarium instead.

title: Go & See The Pandas & Manatees
content:
We went there on Boxing Day with all the expected crowds The exhibits were fabulous and realistic. We found that the setup very unique & well designed - especially the walking patio which was excellent in rainy condition. The pandas & manatee was the highlight - will be our main reason for a 2nd visit.

Boat ride was full but that's does not deter us in any way. Do bring along some snack as the restaurant is a bit pricey & less option (there is only a chinese restaurant and a panda themed fast food joint)

I do agree (not all) that there is some need for certain issues but it aint that bad....

title: nothing really special and too much crowd!
content: We went there during the peak season of Chirstmas. We knew how heavy the traffic will be so we went there early. 8:20 am we arrived and there were already que for the boat ride. Bring lots of cold drink, and I saw a lot of people having their pack sandwich while queing at the entrance. I was lucky as I got into one of the booth selling group tickets and got a booking for the boat ride without having to que up at the entrance. I didn't really enjoy much of the park since there was just too much people around. I like the area of the aquarium where you can see the sea otters and the mantee because it is airconditioned. The river boat ride was just ok, nothing special.. too few animals to see and nothing really interesting. The whole park's animal were good since it is a bit different from other zoo's animal. The lineup for the panda was just terrible so we didn't go in anymore. I've seen the panda in China before so didn't feel it was something worth queing. By 11am we left the place already as the crowds were just too much already and we had browsed through the park already. It is also very hot and humid during the day so be prepared with that. Overall nothing special and the boat ride is just not worth paying for if they do ever decide to put a premium on that.

title: Pandas are cute, rest of day wasted!
content: You must be able to walk/wheel chair the entire time. Very few seats to rest, toilets are soooooo far from each other, one place to buy food half way through the safari. Only worth going to see Pandas, but I heard others say that often they can't be seen. The River ride was a 1.5 hr wait on your feet in the heat, for ten minute ride that went so fast you couldn't see the animals. Singapore Zoo has a long way to go before this attraction is worth the time and money.

title: Feeling Cheated
content:
The concept, design, and environment were good, some of the animals in the safari were an interesting bunch probably not seen anywhere else in Singapore.

However, the crowds were crazy even at 11am. The worst was that at that time, the boat ride was already fully booked. Given that everyone has to pay the same entry price, a large number of people being unable to view about 35% of the animals in the safari (on the boat ride) is extremely unfair. The entry price should be lowered and a separate fee should be charged for the boat ride. This was a huge negative point for us. Not being able to see the jaguar? Feels like a big missing out.

As you'd expect in such a location, the price of food is exorbitant. The long slow queues were a downer as well.

title: moderately attractive but such a long queue!
content:
probably my bad as I went there on a end-of-year Sunday.

the first queue started with queing for the boat cruise time slot (we booked our tickets online but couldn't book the boat slot. $25 for admission. cheaper if u purchase a package that visits other attractions like zoo/bird park/night safari), that itself took 1 hour and by the time we reached our turn it was 11am and we got 3.30pm slot (think last boat ride is 5pm).

got in, the first part that u'll run through would be the different animals/fishes for the various rivers. first impression it looked like any ordinary zoo but when u reach the huge aquariums it really is very impressive. the fishes are so fat that i swear they probably weight half as much as i do.

the 2nd queue starts at the panda observatory. have to queue to get in as they kept the pandas in an air-conditioned observatory. that itself probably took half hour plus. the 2 famous pandas from china weren't really visible, one lying on its stomach sleeping and the other sleeping in its den (only visible via CCTV). the ones that are more attractive were probably the red pandas.

the 3rd queue starts at the restaurant. in the entire river safari there's only one restaurant. there're 2 small kiosk that sell drinks and chips. wish they have more food stalls that has hot dogs. coz queing for the food is a pain. the food weren't fantastic. it is so call 'szechuan' cuisine but essentially chinese food la. i guess they tried to do it as a fast food chain but this is really very hard to operate as a fast food chain with the type of food they had. so advice would be: bring your own food from outside, there're places that u can sit in the open air and eat.

the 4th queue starts at the boat cruise. our boat slot is 3.30pm and the paper slip states we should be there 15 mins before. we waited from 3.15pm all the way to 4pm in order to get into the boat. the boat seats 10ppl, each row of 2 ppl. i didn't think it was impressive, there were animals that we couldn't see. the boat ride itself took roughly 10 mins.

the aquarium with the manetee is absolutely breath-taking.... if i ever go back it would probably be for this.

i'll give credit to the staff there though, helpful and organised. handled the crowd brilliantly.

title: worth a visit
content:
Smaller compared to Zoo. The only disliked will be the going for Panda visit required long que and we didnt manage to get the boat ride since over crowded and over booked.T

The good point will be whole place are under sheltered area which are much better than the Zoo. Not so hot if on sunny day.

title: Feeling cheated
content:
The River Safari is not worth the time or money, period. Go only if you have free or heavily-discounted tickets.

The nice:
- Sufficient shelter and covered walkways so you can hide from the sun or rain.

- Err… I’m hard pressed to think of something else good, and you can read from my other reviews I always try to look at the positive and negative.

The not nice:
- Food is very, very, very, very expensive. Only two places you can buy food from and they are no better from food court food. One set meal costs $15.90, and it’s not filling too. Add on other food or drinks you need to buy multiplied by other family members’ food you need to buy and you get the idea. (Hint: bring your own food)

- The animals are nothing special, really. Once you have been inside the zoo, you’ll think the animals in the River Safari are about the same. Even the much-hyped special animal exhibits are not worth the hype e.g. the piranhas are housed in a small glass ‘container’. There are so few of them. Looking at them, anyone can be forgiven for thinking they are just… fish.

- As for the pandas, it greatly depends on the time you go. When I visited the pandas when they first came, all I saw was one black-and-white stuff toy’s backside. This time round, at least they were awake, up and about. But then, Kai Kai was so stressed by the ooh-ing and ahh-ing of the visitors that he retreated into his enclosure and refused to come out. No doubt you pay a small price to see a panda compared to flying all the way to Sichuan, but, it’s a hit-or-miss chance you have to take.

- And then the ‘largest freshwater aquarium,’ no doubt it’s different from the aquarium at S.E.A. Aquarium, frankly, the latter is way better, and cheaper too. Unless you are a ‘fish fan’ and particular about freshwater vs. sea water, go for S.E.A. Aquarium.

- The Boat Ride is the biggest rip-off. It’s an 8min ride. Most of the time you cannot see any animals because they’re either hiding somewhere or they are hiding somewhere, and obviously you cannot stop halfway to look for them. Some of the animals were transferred from the zoo e.g. jaguar, so, if you have seen them before, there’s nothing new. The Boat Ride was complementary when I took it. I don’t know when they’re going to start charging for it. Don’t pay a cent. Not worth even an extra cent from the main admission charges.

Conclusion: if not for the fact I had free tickets, I would have come back feeling very, very, very cheated. Even then, I still felt cheated, that I have wasted the day there instead of taking my family somewhere else.

P.S.: I read many comments here about long queues and long waiting times. My family was a victim too (1hr queuing to buy lunch, 1hr queuing for the boat). However, I bear in mind that we were there during the school holidays and everywhere is crowded during the school holidays, so it’s not fair to complain about the queues and waits.

If I had paid full price for everything (food and tickets) I’d have spent about $210. I don't think it was even worth $21.

title: Rivers of the World
content:
The sheltered walkways all around the park allow us to stroll leisurely in the shade. My favourite attractions are Amazon flooded forest, the Panda gallery & the Amazon river quest boatride.

Do arrive as early as you can, about 8.30am-9am so as to secure your desired time slots for the Amazon river quest boatride. Collect your complimentary boat tickets at the entrance. Yes! It's complimentary for now, so do come soon in case the boat ride becomes chargeable!

From the entrance, visitors can choose to turn left or right to start their walk. Most choose to go left. I suggest right, as there's very little crowd on the right. Best of all, Amazon flooded forest is the very first attraction on the right!

As for the panda exhibit, there's a snake like queue at 12 noon. I strongly suggest you visit the panda before 11.30am. There's a panda restaurant selling panda buns. Again, visit the restaurant early to avoid the crowd.

We finished 2 rounds of walk around the park in 3 hours. So it's possible to visit the river safari in the morning, then the singapore zoo right after. The entrances are just side by side. In fact, you could end the night with a visit to the night safari right beside the zoo too! Remember to buy the park hopper tickets for discounts.

title: The least interesting zoo/aquarium in Singapore. Very bland
content:
As the most recently opened zoo in Singapore, the expectations were high, especially after a very exciting advertisement campaign.

Unfortunately, the River Safari is currently disappointing.

The good: very modern infrastructure where almost all the walking paths are covered, protecting you from the rain and sun. The manatee exhibit is gorgeous, the spider monkey enclosure is fun, and the red pandas are very cute.

The less good: many enclosures feel rather empty, with very few animals visible. While a lot is made about beavers in the first exhibit, there aren't any available. The park is rather small compared to the other Singapore zoos, and feels very clinical. Food/drink options are underwhelming.

The bad: the advertisements for the "Amazon River Quest" shows a small boat on an exotic river, surrounded by plenty of animals. The reality is a Universal Studios-style barge capable of seating 19 people, speeding through a concrete channel, with animal enclosures left and right. The barges run so fast that it is impossible to spot more than 10% of the animals that are supposed to be there.

The boat ride is currently free, but you need to book your time slot in the park, queuing 3 times: once to book your slot, then to enter the attraction a few hours later, and then inside the attraction. You are only allowed one ride per day per person, so you can't go back to try and see what you missed the first time. All the queuing will probably add up to 2-3 hour for an underwhelming 5-10 minutes ride.

We enjoyed our stay in the park - it is nice - but think that it could have been so much better. I don't think we'll return unless it is improved dramatically.

Make sure you do not come on a busy day - call them in advance to check how long the queues are expected to be that day.

title: Shockingly disappointed
content:
Reasons
1 this is quite a walk from singapore zoo ,
2 1-2 hrs que for 10 mins boat ride
3 rest of the zones of river safari very basic
4 nowhere mentioned that the ride will b just 10 mins

Worst I ever visited . Not worth spending money

title: Nice but the long awaited boat ride is a laugh
content: Nice addition to the Singapore Zoo and Night Safari but the long awaited boat ride is much ado about nothing. Manatee and otter aquariums are stunning. The cramped and refrigerated Panda exhibit disappointing. The much advertised boat ride was a laugh. I suggest you don't consider it when they start charging you separately for it!

title: The boat ride seems to be always full !!!!!
content:
The main attraction of the River Safari which is the boat ride was full for the entire day!!! So we missed half of the animals.

However, the other sections were pretty decent and we got a chance to see the Panda bear which made the trip fruitful. The fishes are also nice especially the Mekong catfish.

U can skip it if the boat ride is full and see the Singapore Zoo instead which is close-by along with Night Safari

P.S - There are various combo offers which can give you access to all 4 attractions namely Jurong Bird park, Singapore Zoo, River Safari & Night Safari at a better rate. The Singapore Zoo, River Safari & Night Safari are in the same premises whereas the Jurong Bird park is at a distance of 20 kms hence covering all 4 parks in a single day is virtually impossible. Choose your combo passes wisely

title: Disappointed
content:
We went to the River Safari through Tour East. We were there for around 2 hours which was mostly spent at queuing and riding the boat ride which wasn't really that good. There was even a problem in the ride where the boats piled up at the loading station. Good thing there was a platform to our right so that we could go down because we were three boats away from the loading station.

If you plan to ride the boat, don't sit in front because there is a small drop at the start which will get your pants wet. But nonetheless the whole park was a disappointment.

title: The boat trip is painfully frustrating.
content:
Its quite nice,
BUT the main attraction is the boat ride, which has many animals not visible on foot. And its is terrible! Here is the issues:
1. You have to book a boat ride,... usually 4 hr's after you arrive is the earliest available.
2. You arrive 15min before your time slot and the queue is long... then you get put into another queue which is long... so that then you get put in the 3rd queue.... in total queuing was 1hr, and I think we were on a quiet day.
3.the boat ride is only 10min long (after 1hr queue)
4. All the 'speed up' sections get you moving so fast you miss 2 of the 3 species in the area. The only animals you see are the birds. The unique animals like howler monkeys, ant eaters, Mara are missed because you don't have time to look to left and right.
5. Photography is virtually impossible. Because of the speed and how animals are changing species left and right so fast its just frustrating.
6. They really should put a walking path through these animals, because on the boat you miss them.

title: Overpriced - only go very early, otherwise avoid
content:
We went to River Safari on Dec 29th 2013 and were disappointed to learn that we had no chance to join the main attraction of this place: the river ride.

As others have commented, it is always full. An employee explained to me that they have 14 rides pr day (every 30 minutes). Each ride can take around 200 people, so only 2800 people get to enjoy this ride each day.

This ride makes up 50% of the whole River Safari, so if you cannot take it, this attraction has an extremely low value for money. We were informed that we could come back the next day which was not possible as half of our group left the following day.

I would suggest that the management of this attraction considers 2 possible actions to avoid disappointing many more people:
1) Increase number of boats from 14 to 28 (why is there only a boat every 30 mins) to accomodate more visitors
2) Half the ticket price for the River Safari and then start charging for the river ride. At least this way, all the people who get on the boat pay for it while people who miss the boat will feel that the ticket price is fair.

Bring your own food as there is only 1 restaurant half way through the park and here prices are also much too high compared to what you get.

The only thing I enjoyed during our visit to the River Safari was the aquarium with the Manatees. Very impressive.

title: Irony of Star being biggest turnoff
content:
This River Safari concept is great but the premise is too small to feature such diverse theme. As a result, it is like a Jack of All Trades but Master of None. In fact, you can cover this attraction entirely in an hour. Still, the attraction is tourist-friendly with covered walkways in most parts.

Ironically the main star of the attraction, the Amazon River Ride is the biggest turn-off!
It is not child friendly (at least 1.06m tall) and no modified boat for wheelchairs. It was listed on the website as "limited in number" but to me, it seemed like everybody who queued will be issued a ticket. Unsurprisingly, crowding is the top complaint in TripAdvisor.

At the entrance, I queued for 30 minutes to get the complimentary tickets to the ride. I was given a time-slot about 2 hours later so we did a leisurely walk through the entire attraction. Then, we started queuing at the River Ride entrance for 40 minutes. Past the entrance, there was no sign of any boats but yet another 30 minutes queue. The staff did a great job organizing people into boats but I wished the speed of the ride was slower.

A few tips for a better experience:
1. Book tickets online - the scanners can read the barcodes of the e-tickets on your smartphone (no need to print).
2. Go as early as possible to get the River Ride tickets; do the ride before the queue starts to form.
3. Don't buy the Ice Slush (Lime or Mango flavor), you are better off drinking mineral water.
4. Do this attraction early in the day, then go to the Zoo and finally, if you have the energy, do the Night Safari.
5. Don't go during mid-day because of the crowds and to avoid watching sleepy animals. Yes, even the fish looked lethargic!

title: River Safari was a great surprise
content: To start off there are 3 zoos (the zoo, river safary and bird park) + the night experience so a total of 4 options. Due to time restrictions we opted for the zoo and river safari. The zoo was ok, I meam we have visited Auckland, San Diego, Werribee, Taronga zoos so unless there were dinasours alive it was going to be difficult to get impressed. A great surprise was the River Safari zoo, which is themed based on great rivers around the world, something I haven't seen before. The amazon boat ride is a must do but needs to be booked in advance as it sells out really quick

title: Victim of its success
content:
Going in the middle of the school break between Xmas and NY was not a clever idea. The River Safari was totally packed at 10am and the boat rides were fully booked for the whole day so we missed half of the animals.
Jia Jia and Chai Chai the pandas were also out of reach unless you were prepared to queue for a good hour and a half.
The park is victim of being recently opened and of not being able to cater for the high demand. Surely things will get better in a few months and off peak.

title: Great experience!
content:
Brought my 2 kids and my mum to river safari in April 2013. At that time the river cruise is still not opened so won't be able to comment on that. We went on a weekday so it wasn't crowded.

Pros:
1. The walkway is all covered so no need to worry if it's too sunny or raining.
2. The whole place is stroller/wheelchair friendly / good for kids
3. The panda themed restaurant is nice, try their panda pao and cappuccino , very cute and taste good too, price also reasonable
4. Loves the manatee and panda. Very nice to see, and it's air con...

Cons:
1. It is relatively small compared to singapore zoo, so the entrance fees are considered steep.
2. The animal show is totally a waste of time. The bench to seat is very minimal and the show is not interesting at all. It is more like for kids to get close encounter with the animal but u can only do that when there is less people. During peak time, can hardly see the animal cause there is no stage and very minimal seats.

Overall, still quite fun as the kids love panda and I love manatee. Can really spend time sitting down n watching them
:))

title: Left feeling cheated
content: One of the newest attraction in Singapore, I decided to check out River Safari on 30 December. Upon reaching the destination, I was horrified to see at least 80 people queuing for tickets. It was a good thing that I could quickly go online and buy the tickets on the spot, hence no dramas. We were told that the boat ride in the safari was full. Not knowing the significance of that, we thought that it was still alright to visit as we were happy to walk instead of riding a boat. My first impression of the place was that there wasn't much animals / fish to see. The theme of the safari was river animals of course, but most of them were focused on fish which was really not quite exciting. In addition, the place is really small. It was only when we walked to the boat ride area then we were told that there were some animals that could only be seen during the boat ride. After checking the map, I realised that it meant that we miss out on seeing quite a number of animals. I felt really cheated as even though the attendants did emphasize the boat ride was full, but they failed to notify visitors that we will miss out on many animals if we do not take the boat, which was the single main and most important thing to point out. At SGD25, that was a total rip off. We finished the park in less than 2 hours. I will never go back again and will not recommend anyone to do so as well.

title: Too many lines! Avoid the River Safari Boat Ride – an hour in line.
content:
The River Safari section of the zoo requires a separate ticket and overall it is very well presented.

There was an even larger line for the Pandas that I estimated to be at least an hour long so we skipped them. This was a big disappointment.

We got tickets for the boat ride at 1:30 pm. We arrived at 1:15 pm and did not get into the boat until 2:20 pm. It was a short, boring ride. Sitting on a boat and going quickly past animals is not a good way to enjoy a zoo.

Be aware that the bird park is 30 minutes away. We did not realize this when we booked the combination ticket.

title: Great setup premises wise but lack of value for money as no interest for the visitor
content: If you must choose between this and zoo, I will take zoo at all time. The place main attraction river ride is always sold out, the facility for kids like stroller, pull wheeler like in the zoo either not available or costly, so it is not very kids friendly. There is no feeding time like zoo, there is no place to put stroller if you bring your own for the panda exhibit, really as if it doesn't want kids to be there. For Singaporean zoo over value for money especially with the NTUC, while river Safari is commercially driven!

title: Not a good experience
content:
Wouldnt really recommend. Crowded, and nothing very special at all. The pandas were sound asleep, and one wouldnt come out of it's den. And having to queue three times to get on the boat ride (not including the one to get tickets for general admission) was just quite ridiculous.
Unless you really run out of things to do, and/or really love watching sleeping pandas on TV (yes, one of the pandas was only viewable on a small CCTV), give this a skip. Not really worth the time.

title: New concept, obviously growing but a good start
content:
We packaged this visit with a Park Hopper to include the the Zoo and Bird Park, so it became very good value.

The layout was easy to follow, and made good attempts to have quite a world wide experience of river inhabitants. The Pandas were active and a delight.

The river boat ride was efficiently organized, and staff kept passengers flowing. For a very popular part if the park, it appeared well managed. The ride itself was ordinary, providing a different way to see certain exhibits. Downside is that you only get a short view of those exhibits, and there did not appear to be a way to revisit most of those on foot.

A good theme, which can only improve with age.

title: $25 you got to be joking.
content:
River safari

Prebook the ticket online to save time for lining up at the main gate. Catch the tourist bus from the city for $5/pp per trip. From bus stop B12 right across from Mandarin Gallery.

The exhibit divided into different world rivers system; Mississippi, Congo, Ganges, Mekong, Nile etc. at the end is the star attraction of the show, the Panda couple (Kai Kai and Jia Jia). Unfortunate Kai Kai was sleeping and Jia Jia is in her den. Took us 30 mins to get into the Panda forest.

At the end of the Panda forest is a Mama Panda kitchen and crossing the bridge will take you to;Amazon flooded forest exhibit, squirrel monkey forest (a walk through and yes the squirrel monkeys are quite take and will come right up to you) and boat ride (at this time the ride is free but need to pre book ticket online).

Overall the attraction is basically an extension of the zoo. I have seen pet shop aquariums stock more fish and bigger specimen then the River Safari. Personally I don't think it worth the $25/pp. The boat ride was ok and make sure you stay away from the front few rows or you will be drench.

title: Hardly worth the visit or the price
content:
This is a very limited attraction. Visitors are limited to raised walkways from one so-called region to another. This park is supposed to represent the great rivers of the world.

The Mississippi river at the start has the look-and-feel of a Disney or Universal Studio theme park, and it goes downhill from there, literally and figuratively. Africa's Congo River, Egypt's River Nile, India's Ganges, Australia's Murray River, Vietnam's Mekong, China's Yangtze River are mostly fish tanks of various sizes. Yes, it's a glorified aquarium with limited views especially when the park is crowded - not difficult since the walkways restrict movement and there are hardly any places to sit and rest.

15% of the park is accessible via the Wild Amazonia boat ride but access to this ride is by booking seats - usually full by 9.30am!

The chief attractions of interest are the Giant Pandas (if you don't mind the queue - the queue to join the queue snaked all the way to the Mekong River exhibit, preventing others from viewing those tanks!); and the Amazon flooded forest which feature otters and manatees in a gigantic tank. The jury is still out for the boat ride since we couldn't get on it.

If you plan to visit: go way early and head for the Visitor Information Center to book a seat on the ride (the queue grows fairly quickly and you may even end up getting a late slot, say 3pm!). Then, make a beeline to the Giant Panda enclosure. Once you've completed these two, take your time to see the others. The Squirrel Monkeys are cute but can get aggressive if they see food on you. The otters are graceful in the water. The manatees are so laid back - nice!

I think the park is built as an excuse to make money for the upkeep of the pandas. There isn't much to see in terms of variety of animals (fish and more fish, with the odd beaver, polar bear and alligator or so); and not much to do to engage young children.

title: Clever Marketing - Don't fall for the hype
content:
Verdict - Don't fall for the hype - it's basically a glorified Aquarium.

The highlight of the place is the squirrel monkey open enclosure.

But BEWARE! Don't get too close to them. One of them bit my daughter on the hand!!! They have lost their fear of humans. It could have been serious. If this wasn't Singapore, I would have sued. It is a serious potential health and safety risk.

Clever marketing gives the impression that it is a "safari", playing on that word. But don't be mislead. It is nothing like the Night Safari, which is excellent. There is a fraud boat ride, for which you probably have to line Up to separately book for up to an hour. The ride itself is unremarkable.

I would not go again and I certainly would not recommend it to a friend. You would be better off with the zoo and night safari.

title: Badly Run - Hire More Staff to Enforce Safety of Both Animals and Visitors
content:
My experience at River Safari was pretty disappointing after years of appreciation for the general quality of the Singapore Zoo. Besides the incredibly long line for the Boat Ride, which we begrudgingly had to skip (I was told by a staff member that the system of reserving tickets on-site only was 'fair;' I don't think it's any fairer than allowing reservations online, seeing that by 11.30am they'd run out of tickets for the day. We were also told there was no stand-by line, even though it didn't seem like every boat was full. These improvements shouldn't be too difficult to implement), I had concerns about the lack of manpower throughout the park's exhibits.

On the whole, there should have been a lot more staff positioned around the park. Every so often we encountered a docent standing by an exhibit, but most of them didn't seem particularly efficient in the (extremely important) task of crowd control, to the point where I was concerned about safety. In the Spider Monkey Jungle, where visitors walk through a large, contained enclosure full of spider monkeys, I witnessed many people ignoring the signs posted at the entrance saying not to touch, get too close to, or otherwise provoke the monkeys (they can bite). A family had pushed their baby prams within centimeters of a group of monkeys (who, I should add, looked really interested in the baby...), and one man tried repeatedly to touch the monkeys, until I pointed out that they apparently attack humans. Throughout this incident, no staff were in sight; only later did a young girl docent appear, smiling meekly and nervously. Surely when letting crowds of humans loose into the territory of untamed spider monkeys, more supervision is required than expecting people to read signs? Many tourists don't read the languages on the signs, and anyway, many people just don't read (as that family proved).

Another example of overall negligence: at various tanks, including the huge manatee window, tiny "No Flash Photography" stickers were pasted in obscure corners of the glass. Was anyone paying attention? Of course not. Flashes went off every second. Post a docent at that extremely popular tank to enforce these rules.

Obviously this makes for an off-putting experience for visitors, but I was worried it was affecting the animals - the red pandas, for example, have their enclosure basically in contact with the walkway, so they can easily come within a couple meters of a visitor; the big group of people crowded around them seemed to be aggravating them as they were pacing continuously in anxious, stressful circles, eying us humans the entire time. The one thing I ask from a zoo - much less one as prestigious as Singapore's - is that I don't come away distressed and concerned about the animals' emotional and mental health. I can't say the River Safari convinced me, and that was the most upsetting part of the whole trip.

title: Better to visit other places
content: This place opened to much fanfare. However, I would say the only major attraction to the River Safari are the pandas. Apart from the pandas, the other animals on show are not that interesting. A visit to the zoo would be more worth it.

title: Not worth the money
content:
Arrived about 30 mins after park opening and the queue for the boat ride (River Quest) was absolutely horrendous.
Wasn't prepared to stand in it so walked around the park.
Pandas were cute (hence the 2 point rating), took abt 75 mins to walk around by which time all River Quest tickets had been taken for the day so felt rather cheated.
Felt there were insufficient eating/refreshment venues inside, although you get a re-entry stamp to go to eat in the ticketing area just outside the park.

title: It's just not ready and badly planned
content:
The walking half of the park is good, the pandas are great. But then there are the ques and the boat ride. In total we qued about 2 hours for a 5 minute boat rude in which we saw 5 animals. Pretty disappointing.
TLDR; Do the walking half, don't bother queuing for the boat ride.

title: Not that great
content: To me the name is misleading. The rive safari is a mix between a zoo and an aquarium. Done well but if you visit it after the Singapore zoo you're bound to feel let down a bit. The Zoo, River Safari and Night Safari are all in adjacent campuses and we did all of them is a single day. I would recommend doing just the zoo + night safari and skip river safari if you like. Gives you more time to explore the zoo that way.

title: Don't go here..
content: My family and I had terrible experience here..it's the worst attraction in singapore..there's very little to see..animals are very few..the ventilation system inside and outside are poor..it hasn't been prepared for high season..very crowded..there's no enough amazon boat..how come??? it never happens in another attraction in singapore..and the mineral water vending machine was broken..it took 4 dollar and nothing came out..we have to go to mama panda restaurant (around 150 metres) to get our refund..in a very crowded restaurant too..luckily we can get the refund..

title: Worth a 2 hour visit
content:
Visited the River safari this week with the kids and they loved it. It is co-located with the famous Singapore Zoo and the night safari and owned by the same company. It may be worthwhile to buy the bundle tickets where you get admission to both the zoo and river safari as the river safari is much smaller compared with the zoo and night safari. Unlike the other 2 attractions, the river safari is well designed with lots of covered walkways. There are some places to sit and rest but no many place for 'picnics'.

Try to arrive at this attraction early (say before 10am) as the timed river quest complimentary tickets issued at the visitor services centre runs out by about late morning. The tickets are for a ride on the river quest boat (lasts about 5 minutes or less) which feels very much like a slow ride in one of those theme parks. Don't fret if you miss the ride. You would get to see jaguars and some other land animals but you wouldn't miss much.

For my visit, I happened to chanced upon a free guided tour where the guide explained the highlight and unique feature of each species and this was timed with the feeding. This experience really made the river safari come alive. There are also many places to look at the fishes and I like the manatee enclosure which had a big underwater glass wall for visitors to look at the gracefulness of these creatures.

Food was expensive and it made sense to eat somewhere else. The park allows for re-entry so be sure to get a stamp on your arms when you are exiting the park.

All in, it is a small and good size aquarium that would be good to spend two hours out of the sun while admiring the many fishes, crocodilians, reptiles, birds from around.

title: It is better to spend your money elsewhere.
content:
Overall experience: 2.5/5.
Other than the 2 pandas, there is no reason to visit River Safari. The Zoo and S.E.A. Aquarium have better displays.

The Amazon River Quest boat ride is so-so, nothing exciting or fantastic. Despite all the hype, the ride - scenery and "river" - is too artificial. Seating in the boat, I do not feel a single element of cruising down a river, not to say the Amazon River. Small selection of life in the Amazon are simply placed along the less-than-10-minute route.

Currently one pays $25 to enter River Safari and the boat ride is complimentary. Guests have to book a slot for the ride and it is limited to 3000 a day, while "stock" lasts. If it rains, one will have to forfeit the slot - no refund/replacement.

Fees may increase in the future. Frankly I will not pay extra just to take the boat ride. And with a $25 entry ticket, I would advise tourists
to spend the money on good food (which Singapore is famous for) or to visit the Zoo or Resort World Sentosa.

Anyway pandas in Singapore are limited to the two small mammals - one simply eat and sleep whole day (Jia Jia), the other walk in circles or hide in her cave (Kai Kai).

Overall, the entry fee of $25 is, in my opinion, not worth the spending.

title: Fun half-day but not for the river ride
content: We arrived here and were informed that the river cruise part of the zoo is free until further notice, but the que to enter the ride is over 2 hours. We wandered around the zoo before deciding to try our luck at the huge line. we waited for well over 1 hour and 45 minutes and finally got to go on the boat. We were a bit disappointed however, as you couldnt see very many animals form the boat. The rest of the zoo ( that you walk around) was however outstanding, with the manatee tank and panda enclosure being a prime attraction. Would thourougly recommend.

title: River safari Sigapore. Do not be fooled.
content: Brochures depict tourists in a boat admiring animals. It is a walking safari with an opportunity to jump on a boat if time permits. Avoid the organised tours as they only take you to and from the destination. It is cheaper and more satisfying to make your way to the zoo, buy a combined ticket to the zoo and to the river safari 2 minutes away. The zoo is good value and if you like walking do the river safari afterwards. The main feature on the river safari is giant Pandas on loan from China. You wiil need about 5 hours at the zoo and 2 hours on the river safari.

title: Fun Morning at the River Safari
content:
we recently visited the River Safari on our trip to Singapore, and enjoyed it immensely, it's easy to get being adjacent to both the Zoo and Night Safari, and a fun and educational experience for all ages, you walk through direct exhibits reflecting the great rivers of the world, including the Mississippi, Yangtze, Congo and the Murray, before reaching the Amazon where you both can walk and ride the (newly opened) boat ride, animals you can see include Giant and Red Pandas, Manatees, Spider Monkeys, Anaconda, and Jaguars.
As the amazon boat ride has only recently opened it's very popular, and often books out by midday, so it's recommended to arrive early to secure a spot.
All in all an entertaining and highly recommended venue.

title: A worthy sequel to the award-winning Singapore Zoo and Night Safari, but avoid the public holidays!
content:
It can never be imagined that such a small tropical island of Singapore can boast wide-ranging species from diverse climates. Its existence as an attraction warrants a visit based purely on this unique aspect of Singapore.

The animals that we see in River Safari comes mainly from the riverine environments with the majority from the mystical Amazon. It is not everyday that you get to view the Paddle Fish, gigantic arawanas, playful manatees and even a huge anaconda. River Safari has really outdone itself, not surprisingly given the standards set by its partner zoos. A great wonder is the huge freshwater aquarium where you get to observe the manatees and other riverine creatures in a "natural environment. It was pretty surprising to note that the perennial flooding in the Amazon can be as deep as 8 metres! It is also interesting to note how River Safari has taken advantage of the adjoining Seletar Reservior, enhancing the riverine feel of the whole attraction. Go to see how they actually built a big climate-controlled enclosure just for the Pandas (and red pandas).

Some pointers to note:

1) Do not visit the place during weekends and public holidays. I know it's really a point that need no reminding for regular travellers, but it is important enough to avoid a 100-metre queue to the ticket counter. Purchase online in advance if possible.
2) There are basically 3 eating venues within the attraction and they are not grouped together. These venues serve food that are expensive and, unfortunately, almost unpalatable. Better to eat before entering the attraction where you can find KFC, Ben and Jerrys and other cafe at the entrance of the Singapore Zoo. Pack it in too if you want but take note, there's not that many picnic places or sitting area within the attraction.
3) Do make it a point to go early in the morning when the animals are more active (including the Pandas). Go in the afternoon and it is not surprising to see most animals being very lethargic and hiding in their cubby holes.
4) Most part of the attraction is sheltered so no headwear needed, really.
5) You may want to make it as a joint visit to the Night Safari if you go there in the late afternoon.

I may be a Singaporean, but the existence of this attraction did not lessen my wonder for the determination by Singapore Wildlife Reserves to to make it happen. So do visit!

title: Go early!
content:
We just came back from a visit to the River Safari. It is extremely crowded due to the festive season. To beat the crowd, we bought our tickets online and arrived half an hour before park opened.

We managed to get tickets for the first Amazon River Quest ride batch between 10 and 10.30 am. They start issuing tickets for the ride around 8.45am. 15 mins before park opened.

Upon entry, we went left to the Amazon flooded forest to see the giant manatees and the piranhas. Great choice as we were among the first inside and had uninstructed view of the fishes in the tank. This turned out to be our favorite exhibit together with the pandas. The spider monkey enclosure was next. Those monkeys were really cute. We were done by 9.30 and went to wait for our boat ride. It was the right decision as a queue started forming around 9.35am.

We got into one of the first few boats. I was prepared for a boring ride after reading all the reviews. But as it was early, all the animals were active and the ride was pretty enjoyable.

After the ride, it was off to the panda enclosure. There is a queue here as they control the no of people into the enclosure. But it was a short wait about 10 mins only. The panda is very cute. Kai Kai was eating his bamboo! Jia Jia stayed indoors and never came out. Apparently she prefers to hide inside away from the crowds. I don't blame her.

After that we went to the mama panda kitchen for brunch. The panda buns very cute and quite nice but very ex. 5 of us spent close to $100. When we were eating, we notice the restaurant filling up by 11am. I guess it will be packed by noon.

When we were done eating, we notice the queue for the panda enclose has become extremely long. As we walked down to the Mekong River, Murray River, Ganges River, River Nile and Mississippi River exhibits, we notice the crowds getting bigger. Luckily the exhibits thereafter were mainly fishes so it was ok. Glad we were already done with the major attractions.

We left the park just before 11 noon. The crowd at the ticket queue at the zoo which sells both the zoo and river Safari tickets were horrendous! The queue for the River Quest ride was all the way to the side of the zoo. It is also very hot by noon time and I won't be surprise if some animals will be in hiding in the afternoon.

All in all an enjoyable visit. But I am sure it would have been less enjoyable if we had to wait in long lines and jostle with the crowd to see the exhibits. At $25 for adult and $16 for kids, it is pretty expensive considering that the park is significantly smaller than the zoo and night safari. We were done in 3 hrs from 9-12.

title: Oh well..
content:
Visited RSS on Sat 21 Dec 2013.

Weekend crowd. Waited 1/2 hr in line for tickets... another 1/2 hr in line to see Kai Kai (Jia Jia no show) Another 1/2 hr for boat ride.
Very disappointed ...ride about 15 mins only....expecting river cruise but if you've been to USS n took the Madagascar ride, you get the picture.
Whole area approximately 1/4 of the Singapore Zoo.Saving grace is the covered walkway, shelter from rain & shine. The otter antics & gorgeous manatee in their giant tank...could have stayed there for hours if not for for the screaming children allowed by their insensitive parents to run around and treating the enclosed space as their playground:(
If you are animal lovers like us, would strongly recommend to spend the morning @ the Zoo then hop to River Safari after lunch for the full therapy. Put on good walking shoes and happy clicking for the perfect shot!!!

title: An unpolished gem
content:
River Safari is a very unique themed park – one that supposedly blends aquarium life with the excellent collection of animals that the world-class Singapore Zoo already possesses. While the theming of the park is easy to navigate and highly informative, the high price ($25 for now; $35 from next year onwards!) as compared to the existing Singapore Zoo, Bird Park and Night Safari, as well as the hyped-up marketing, seem to set high expectations for the park. Unfortunately, it left me pretty disappointed – 1) I was unable to access the much-talked about Amazon River Quest as they had stopped people from queuing as the estimate of the queue was 3 hours long; 2) the park was pretty small – I managed to view all the exhibits within 1.5 hours! Imagine that – methinks that even if you had viewed all the information panel and had taken an extremely leisurely pace, you would have completed the park in 3 hours anyway.

For more, see pictures and read my journal entry on: http://travellah.wordpress.com/2013/12/17/river-safari-an-unpolished-gem/.

title: Great way to kill a few hours
content:
We had a morning to kill before a flight and decided to see the Panadas at the River Safari. A quick 15 minute $20 taxi ride later (from Orchard Rd) we were there.

Lots of fish and wildlife associated with rivers around the world. The manatees were a real surprise as were the giant otters.

Loved the spider monkeys

Sadly for us on panda was asleep and the other was in its den, so not much action there, but in can at least say I've seen a live panda.

Tickers cost $25 per adult and if you want to do the cruise you need to select a specific cruise at time of booking and when we were there it was booked 3 hrs in advance, so get there early. It's not essential to the experience though.

title: River Safari
content: This is by far the simplest park to walk through and see within the Singapore Zoological Gardens (Singapore Zoo, Night Safari and River Safari). Each section of the park has a theme based on different rivers around the world, from the Nile to Ganges and Yangtze, and many more. As the name implies, most of the creatures are mainly aquatic, with the exception of the pandas and monkeys. A little disappointed though with not being able to get on the Amazon boat ride as it was fully booked (on a Monday too!). The Amazon flooded forest section is definitely the best part of this park as it play host to the largest number of dugongs and manatees in Singapore. You can even see the interaction between these creatures and the divers during feeding time - it's quite a rare sight!

title: Really well done and fairly unique.
content:
We really enjoyed the River Safari experience and found the aquarium displays superior to those at The SEA aquarium on Sentosa ( thought lacking the colourful saltwater fishes). Comparing this attraction to the neighbouring zoo and night Safari is to do it a disservice. You won't be able to experience the same things at either of the other two. Also it's best to think of this as a River Habitat experience rather than any sort of Safari.

The boat ride adds little to the animal experience ( unlike the tram ride at the Night Safari) and seems to have been added to lend some credence to the "Safari" element in the attractions title. It was free when we did it, so no complaints, the the kids enjoyed the 'ride'.

The Pandas are another attraction though a tenuous link to a River! I felt that they would have been better off at the zoo, leaving the the River Safari for more waterborne creatures.

Most of the River Safari is covered or has covered walkways so it relatively rain friendly compared to the neighbouring attractions. Also the scenery and views of the natural surrounding is great. Not much in the way of dinning options with the the attractions but plenty by the main entrance nearer the zoo ( re entry is allowed). There were regular tours by park rangers who walked from one enclosure/ tank to another describing the fish, pointing out bits you might have missed and also presenting interesting facts about them. It's free to join and we found it added greatly to the experience.

We visited on a Friday during the School holidays, and purchased the 2 in 1 combined Zoo and River Safari tickets at 9 am and there was no queue to purchase tickets and we got the first time slot for the Boat ride too which was at 12 noon on this day. Purchasing tickets to two neighbouring attraction allowed us to pop between the 2 so we could catch the times shows and have something to do before the boat ride.

Fairly unique, we have never visited a river themed attraction before, it kept us all interested so it five stars from us.

title: Don't just go there for the pandas/boat ride
content:
I visited the River Safari wondering if the pandas there were like the pandas at the San Diego Zoo (always sleeping), and yes, sadly, the one I saw was (I couldn't even see the other). That being said, there's a lot more to be seen than the pandas, despite how everything in the park seems to have been panda-fied.

For starters, if you like fishes and reptiles, the alligator gars and the snapping turtles are always delightful to see, especially if you managed to catch them during feeding hours, as are the various species of catfish. There are many other fishes, half of which I probably can't name, but they're mostly big and great to observe just swimming around.
