A couple of birds reside here and there, too, but it is a "River" safari and Singapore does have a Bird Park in another part of the island.

I honestly wasn't impressed by the pandas, but another inhabitant of the panda forest, the red pandas, provided loads of photo opportunities for visitors. They scurried around, lazed on the trees for a bit, generally ensuring that those visiting had at least some photos other than a sleeping giant panda's butt. There wasn't much of a queue when I went to the exhibit.

The Amazon River Quest Boat ride, on the other hand, had a ridiculously long queue. Even though we reached the River Safari just past 11am, the only available rides were at 4.30pm. The queue wasn't properly handled outside the attraction, where a show was taking place, so visitors got confused about the queue and some even jumped the line, leading to some frustrated bloke shouting at them (to no avail). After queueing outside, there was another queue on the inside as each "boat" could only take a certain number of passengers. I say "boat" because it is hardly a boat, it's more like a partially submerged amusement ride. Be careful with your expensive cameras, cause ride does accelerate downhill a bit, and water can splash inside. The ride took more than half an hour to queue for, but only lasted about 10 minutes. And you might not even get to see some of the animals as they might be sleeping/hiding. Quite a bummer.

The best part of the park, in my opinion, has to be Amazon Flooded Forest. The main attraction is the huge tank full of manatees happily swimming around together. I could spend hours just sitting there watching them.

One good thing about the River Safari is that there's pretty much shelter everywhere, unlike the zoo, so the only worry about wet weather is the availability of the Amazon River Quest ride. If you're going there to take photos, though, you might have to fight it out with legions of smartphone/camera-toting kids in front of the various exhibits. Hopefully it's just the local school holidays.

As some other reviewers have noted, it might be best to buy the tickets online so as to avoid having to queue at the attraction itself. Overall I'd give it 3.5 (a Good, not Very Good) but tripadvisor doesn't allow that. And I was impressed enough with the place to feel it deserved more than an average. If you're interested in going to the zoo, or other parks like the Night Safari/Jurong Bird Park, there's a special park-hopper package you can get which will help you save more than a couple of pretty pennies.

title: Pleasant but not amazing!
content: I visited on a Saturday so this attraction was very busy with locals. In typical Singapore style the place is immaculate and the exhibits are very well laid out with covered walkways taking you through different geographical river experiences. If you are not very interested in fish then this is probably not for you! However, there are some very cute creatures along the way including otters and of course the pandas. It was fantastic to see a panda so close, happily eating his bamboo oblivious to all people and cameras. I also enjoyed seeing the spider monkeys and the manatees. The river safari boat trip was not open when I was there so I cannot comment. Getting back to the city was interesting! There was a huge queue for taxis and when in the queue I was approached by a man who said he had a mini bus and would take me to the city for S$35 - about S$15 more than the taxi fare. There were several other tourists in the bus all paying S$35 so this driver did quite well from the trip. Although I felt a little ripped off we got back to the city quickly and I felt it was worth it as I was only in Singapore for a day and did not want to waste it in a queue.

title: River safari
content: River Safari is unique and nice place, the atmosphere is very nice, the scenery beautiful, Kai Kai and Jia Jia are very adorable, and the giant "dugong" aquarium also very entertaining, though it's not as what we expected as we saw in the advertising, since it's new, many fishes are still small and unfortunately we can't joint the boat because of too many visitor and they already reach maximum capacity, but overall it's one of must visit place while in Singapore.

title: Underwhelming attraction
content:
Visited on a Monday during the school holidays, it's very packed. Fortunately I manage to avoid the queue by buying the tickets online. You need to proceed to the visitor services counter to book a boat ride slot else you can't ride at all.

The specimens on display were river creatures and frankly, it was underwhelming since the zoo is just next door. The pandas were a joy to watch and I think many found reprieve for the heat with the air conditioned enclosure.

The big issue I have is the lack of food eateries inside and the big loop you have to go round just to exit and eat at KFC outside. The panda themed cafe was super packed and definitely unable to handle the crowds. We had to back track through the Ganges, ,Mekong rivers enclosure to exit and have lunch. You will get what I mean by looking at the layout on the map.

The boat ride which was pretty hyped about was disappointing. It was very brief and the animals were having their naps during the afternoon. Save for a couple of gentle slopes and splashes, it's not worth queuing for. And I won't want to pay the full price ticket just to get onto the ride.

The things I like were the sheltered walkways, manatee enclosure and giant viewing tanks. There it's very elderly and stroller friendly.

title: River Safari
content:
River Safari was not upto the expectaion. Comparatively zoo and night safari was much better than this. Only pandas was good and nothing more.... Boat ride was really very poor... Actually they said to us boat ride was booked fully and there is no vacancy but later when we enquired in the visitors information counter they gave us the tickets ???!!!! ........

In short river safari is not worth of spending or sight seeing.......

title: Waste of time and money
content: Visited the river safari seduced by the publicity. Queued up for 1 hour to be told that due to technical problems there would be a wait of at least another 2 hours. Decided to leave the queue and went to view the giant pandas. The enclosure is amazing, seeing the pandas so close with great photo opportunities. After viewing the pandas, we noticed that the queue for the river safari has gone down and was at last moving so decided to rejoin it. Queued for another 2 hours for an experience which was equal to a forth rate Disney ride. It lasted less than 5 minutes and was such a let down. IT REALLY IS NOT WORTH QUEUING FOR. You hardly get a glimpse of the animals.

title: Asia's first and only river-themed wildlife park
content: A new concept to see the wild life. Meet over 5,000 aquatic and terrestrial animals representing 300 species at this place. At River Safari, one can explore eight river habitats (Mississippi, Congo, Nile, Ganges, Murray, Mekong and Yangtze) and meet river giants and megafishes such as the giant river otter, giant salamander and the critically endangered Mekong giant catfish. Visit giant pandas Kai Kai and Jia Jia (gift from China) at the lush Giant Panda Forest -the largest panda exhibit in Southeast Asia. Also sharing this climate-controlled bio dome are the rare red pandas and elegant golden pheasants. It is surprising to see white bear in ice cooled water pool through a glass window. Be amazed by the world's largest freshwater aquarium at the Amazon Flooded Forest along with Squirrel Monkey forest.

title: A lot to improve for the River Safari
content: As compared to Zoo and Night Safari, expectation is high for its sister and neighbor. But it will not be worth to spend the admission ticket price for the current situation at River Safari. Boat ride is yet to open and 35% of the site is yet to be opened with attractions. Hope this will be better by mid 2014?

title: Unique but incomplete!
content:
It was a great experience and the safari was well maintain clean with a beautiful lake. But too bad the amazon river quest boat ride has not operating till Dec'13.
Furthermore, me and my sis have a glimpse of polar bear from Singapore Zoo, and it has a huge aquarium that will attract you too!
But because of the boat ride has not open for public during my visit in Nov'13,so it's really a waste and i don't think i will go there again just for the ride.

title: The boat ride was an absolute waste of time!
content:
My family and I went to the River Safari this morning and was told that the newly opened River Boat Ride would only starting at 12pm. So we took our time visiting other parts of the RS and like most kiashu Singaporeans, decided to go to the boat ride waiting area half an hour earlier to avoid the crowd. We were so wrong. By the time we reached there, there was already a long line of people waiting patiently there. It took slightly more than an hour before we could even see the 'boats'. Sitting in our 'boat', we imagined really going on a mini 'quest' (as coined by RS) and exploring realistic habitats of exotic animals... we were very disappointed. Most of the animals were so well camouflaged that we only managed to see some pink flamingoes and a green iguana.

The entire 'quest' took around ten minutes. Just before 'disembarking', our boat was left under the midday sun and we were baking under it. My mum took out an umbrella to shield us from the heat only to be told by an attendant to close it. Out of curiousity, I asked the 'friendly' attendant why umbrellas were not allowed at that moment. She gave me an impatient look and explained that the umbrella could injure the animals. I asked her if that meant even the umbrella was so small that it didn't extend outside of the personal space (note: we were already at the disembarkation area where there were no animals)? She responded with a rude "yes". Granted that we did not have to pay extra for the boat ride but this experience has convinced me never to visit this place again if I could help it.

title: A Very Unique Safari Zoo
content: Out of the three attractions(SEA Aquarium and Gardens by the Bay) that we visited in Singapore, the kids enjoyed River Safari the most, as the animals and fishes attractions are all based along the river theme, except for the Amazon River Quest Boat Ride. We had to waited for 2 hours for the boat, firstly due to the thunder and rain storm(45 minutes) and then technical breakdown (45 minutes) of the boats in which some visitors were trapped in their boats! The main attractions of the River Safari are the Red Pandas (very active!) and the two giant pandas, as usual they were sleeping in the day time, one in the open gardens and the other inside. By the pandas are housed in the own air-condition enclosure and makes a nice cool break in the hot and humid conditions of Singapore!

title: Ok, but make sure your kids are tall enough!
content:
We visited the River Safari the same day we visited the Singapore Zoo.

When purchasing tickets, we asked at the counter if they could measure our youngest child to see if she would be tall enough to go on the boat ride (1.06m). The lady said that they didn't have anything to measure and we could only measure at the ride once we were inside. We took the risk, and she ended up being too short, so we had a very disappointed 4.5 year old and a parent that also missed out on the ride. This needs to be improved, particularly once they start charging more.

The panda attraction was great. One was asleep and the other quite active. The pathways were all undercover, which was great for shade on a hot day.

title: Land & sea creatures in one place
content: At the entrance of Amazon River Quest, guides warn you that the queue could take as long as an hour. We waited for about half an hour only. However, we had to hold on for another 1 1/2 hour for thunder & rain to subside. Then the earlier boat got stuck, so we got out of our boat & another hour is used to wait for technical fault to be fixed. The ride took about 10 minutes. Boat ride was a little fast for photo-taking. I had to alternate between protecting my phone from the splash & taking photos. About 3 low level splashes to be anticipated. The main highlight was seeing 2 jaguars tearing meat up for their meal. Rather gory for little toddlers to see red blood oozing out but this is often shown on National Geographic as well. Overall, the place reminds me of Australia's Sea World. Oh, we also chanced upon a live bat (not captive) in the cave for manatees & stingrays. This is definitely different from the zoo & Night Safari. They've got both land & sea creatures in here.

title: Great attratcion
content: You can't fault this place for a part of the grounds not being ready yet. What is open was great. Many animals that are not in the zoo. Yes just an extended zoo, but still very interesting. They house the famous pandas and red pandas. Recommend this place for all ages.

title: Nice but incomplete
content:
This is a good attraction, but the river attraction was not ready, so the fee was discounted by S$10. Without the river attraction this is nothing more than a smaller zoo of river critters. Best part was seeing the Pandas,... the red Pandas were the best.

Would recommend waiting until the river attraction is ready before visiting here.

title: A new experience
content:
The recently opened River Safari show cases the wildlife of several rivers such as the Mississippi River, Congo River, River Nile, Ganges River, Murray River, Mekong River and Yangtze River as well as Giant Panda Forest and Wild Amazonia.

The area is very much sheltered so in case of rain, you still can enjoy the attraction. The main attraction of this park is definitely the 2 Giant Panda - Kai Kai and Jia Jia. Try to be around during their feeding time at 12pm, and you will be treated with a view of these 2 much loved Pandas. However, depending on their moods, they may not be out to see you. So good luck!

The queuing time for the newly launched Amazon River Quest may take up to 90mins so be prepared to wait, though the trip lasted only 12 mins.

Come with a pair of good shoes (especially for the elderly) as it can quite a bit of walk around the park, there is no tram to move around the park.

title: Nothing more than a zoo
content: Repeating the same mistakes of the night safari, WRS management passed off this zoo as a safari, creating a fake safari. Anyone with common sense should know Singapore cannot have a safari, not to say two. What visitors would most likely want is just a simple zoo, not a safari! Creating the stupid boat ride, which nobody would appreciate is a great mistake. If you like long queues, a short boat ride, which lets you see very little, compared to a simple zoo with a proper walking trail, come here, if you prefer seeing some freshwater fishes and turtles more than seeing land animals, then come here, else go to the Singapore Zoo, you are better served there. The boat ride is not for the wheelchair bound or handicapped people but you pay the same fees anyway.

title: Boring..
content: Not worth the value. Especially bringing kids below 1.06m. They are unable to ride on the Amazon river boat ride quest. And half of the animals can only be viewed via the boat ride. Theres no live exhibition but only info signs along the broadwalk.

title: great adventure
content:
this new concept of river themed attraction is quite new and is a very good place to learn about the river and its ecosystem. animals are great but the tank is not decorative enough. it can be quite boring for teenager or adult that is not interested in animals. The design itself is phenomenal as they can bring visitors to the rivers of the world. the atmosphere really fits the area.

the show is not WRS quality.the show is the worst from the three other parks.

the amazon river quest is great. it really brings you the amazon river to Singapore. the presentation of the ride is great. it looks like the ride from universal studio. i think the amazon river quest should have more trees to make it look like the amazon. just one thing, in the jaguar enclosure, the glass should be clean to make the illusion of being face to face with the jaguar. the enclosure should be cleaned daily.

the giant panda forest is the best. it really recreate the bamboo forest. i just think it is too big for just 3 species of animals.

the zoo is nice but the park is so pricey. it cost a lot of money. the zoo is also small and it should be bigger.

title: Red Panda is so cute...
content: I love this river-themed safari park, there are many adorable animals such as red pandas, pandas, River otters, beavers, manatees and etc... nice place for family with kids, it is wonderful!

title: Good place to learn about the major rivers in the world
content:
The best thing about River Safari is that it is fully sheltered. Thus, you do not have to worry about wet weather.

The park is not very big and you will probably take 3 hours (depending on your speed) to visit the entire place. It is definitely worth visiting this place as you can learn about the various major rivers in the world.

Amazon River Quest is also ready though it is nothing spectacular about it.

title: Best of the 4 "animals/birds" park in Singapore, IMO
content:
Rate highly as I will re-visit even as a local. Best among the "park hopper" package of Zoo( big and comprehensive, but tiring, too hot when sunny or too wet when raining! haha), night safari (Too dark to see anything and part of the park can only be via a quick tram ride), Bird park (only birds and same problem like zoo being a outdoor park)...

River safari: Likes:-
- very well organised, u just follow the pathway and everything can be visited. Unlike the zoo where you need to decide which way to go to be more "efficient".
- "weather-resistant", it is mainly sheltered or indoor, so no worries for rain or shine!
- good mix of fishes, animals on land and water
- the river cruise boat ride is quite a good idea, with some gentle slopes to add to the thrill! (Do note that the boat ride is not officially opened yet, I happen to chance upon a trial run, should be opening soon)
- the finale of the big aquarium with giant Manatees is well placed, good resting air-conditioned area.

Cons: - it's a bit small, probably can be covered in less than 2hours.
- more animals or exhibits should be added
- parking at the area is too expensive!!

title: a big disappointment
content: went to see the river safari as it was the latest attraction in singapore and was disappointed as it had the giant pandas and a anaconda only other than the zoo-the amazon cruise was not operating

title: Nice "All weather" Zoo/Park
content:
When we booked our ticket which was a park hopper for both river safari and Night safari, the website already warned that the River cruise ride was not yet operational so the tickets were discounted. So that was not a surprise to us. The kids actually enjoyed the River Safari, because it included not only fishes and animals but also some amphibians and insects as well.

Everyone agree that the Panda display was one of the highlights, and even my toddler got excited when she saw the panda. My two other kids were so excited to see the Red Panda as well. After the Panda Exhibit, there was a big window/Aquarium which showed a big Polar bear, which wasn't in the map, might be a part of another zoo that was shared, but it was a hoot to see the polar bear swim, the kids said they enjoyed that as well. We also loved the Manatee aquarium, spent quite a lot of time there as well, first time for us to see these cute creatures, we even got to see them being fed.

As per the Title, I think that of all the attractions in Singapore that we visited this trip, this was one of the best "All weather" zoo, with the walkways all covered, allowing us to keep dry even when the rain was pouring badly that we almost can't see the other side of the park. The River cruise might not be protected from Rain though, so during downpours the river cruise might get stopped (when it becomes operational) but hey I might be wrong and the boats might have roofs! (TRIP ADVISOR should have an "All weather" rating so that reviewers can rate how good or bad a park is from inclement weather). If there is, I'd rate River safari as Excellent.

I highly recommend that you book to go to River safari in the afternoon, and time it so that when you finish, you go to Night safari and have dinner in their restaurants to wait for the 7pm opening time. This would time and cost effective, coz you save on transport cost as well as not need to go back in the same place to see the other on another day. Heck I'd say plan to get to river safari by 3 or 4pm and finish by 6pm then transfer to Night safari.

title: Its open, but not ready to be opened
content: We went to the Singapore Zoo, and decided to see the new "River Safari" attraction for a change. This was a mistake, because they have opened the site without finishing it! One ends up walking down a covered path with fish tanks on either side, ending at the Panda enclosure. And less face it, Panda's are only interesting because the Chinese have practically exterminated them. The River Cruise, representing over half the park, is not open. And even when it is, I suspect it will not be as good as Jungle Cruise in Disneyland. We tried to make the best of it, after paying $25 per adult for a ticket, but this place is basically a rip-off. One is much better off and happier staying with the Zoo (only $22 per adult).

title: Worth a visit once fully operational
content: Pandas are the highlight of the river safari! Won't be worth visiting until fully operational, slightly disappointing visit because of this...

title: Average Experience :(
content: Boat was not operational when we went there. We did not find anything really new after spending 3-4 hours earlier in the Zoo. Pandas were, I think the only saving grace for River Safari. We saw only one Panda & he too was sleeping. He looked pale & weak (contrary to the photos shown). Probably it will be a different experience while riding on the boat. Otherwise very average !!

title: Wait for river quest to open
content:
Once the river quest is open I believe it will be much better. The walk-through each river sone is really short. The Giant Panda house is a great air-conditioned relief from the heat and amazing to see the panda's. The flooded amazon part is huge and on the back of the river quest section will be even better.
Hold off until the river quest is open. If we are back in Singapore some day we might go again for the river quest.
We came here after the zoo and went through it quite quickly, not many people either and no queueing/booking to see the pandas.

title: So so experience
content: Ok I went before the river cruise was up and running, so I can't comment on any river experience. The big fish and sea manatees were a real treat to see! However I must say the panda enclosure is a real disappointment. Seeing what my taxpayers money paid 2million for, one would think that we could at least have a good view of a lazy panda. the enclosure was seriously too small for anyones comfort, ppl were pushing, shoving n trying to take pics of an overpriced panda. i wonder if the panda feels bad for all the money spent on them that couldve been used feeding hungry children etc. really not worth the visit if the pandas were what u wanted to see. there was no talks/shows/presentations etc. the enclosure with the large crocodiles were so murky u could only see the croc if u put ur head in its mouth. n its supposed to be newly built. i saw much larger crocs in australia. really hope they clean it up at least else someone is bound to get too close.

title: not finished but worth a visit
content: We enjoyed our visit to the park which we did following the zoo as the properties are adjoining. We loved the pandas and the walk through aquarium. Areas of the park are still under construction and the boat ride isn't operating as yet. I recommend purchasing tickets online as we did. You save money and don't have to queue up for entry. We took a taxi from our hotel and had a short wait when we left for another taxi back. Overall it's well worth a visit along with the zoo and once the next stages are operating would be a awesome day out. Loved it (especially the pandas)!

title: Highlights!
content: To be fair, this place is well mapped. I had a great time, it shows you history of great rivers. well just like the title, highlights!... 1. River Monsters 2. Panda 3. squirrel monkeys

title: Shoild be good when fully open
content:
It's a bit unfair and premature to be writing a report on an attraction that is not fully up and running. All the publicity material features images of happy and excited visitors in boats. The reality is different. There are no boats. Obviously the Zoo management have decided to open the attraction with only 80% of the display functioning (October 2013). Perhaps, in order to compensate, they have included two pandas in the tour.

The River Safari was very devoid of visitors on the day we were there. As we do not like crowds, this was a good thing for us but should have been worrying for management - maybe it's busier at weekends?

The safari consists of a linked route through thematically related displays of aquaria and animal compounds. The thematic link was the great river systems of the world (Europe excluded).
The first few displays seemed unimpressive but slowly the experience began to improve with increasing levels of display standard as one moved through the sequence.

We'd really not been too excited by the prospect of seeing pandas but quickly warmed to seeing these adorable animals going about their routine of eating bamboo like charming, animated plush toys. It all happened right in front of us and seemed so natural and captivating. We were very quickly won over and must have spent over half an hour watching and filming. Excellent and most enjoyable.

Moving onwards, we visited the spider monkeys. The novelty here was that we went into the monkey's enclosure. They were all around us and were fast and agile in their activities. Some came to within a metre or less and it was an intense experience.

Finally we were enormously impressed with the dugong exhibit where these graceful aqua-ballerinas floated effortlessly in a vast tank.

Although it was raining when we arrived, the entire River Safari is under cover. It also keeps you out of the heat of the sun.

Overall, whilst we were disappointed that the Amazon section was not fully open, the experience was good - so good that we were nearly late for our bus back to town. This was mainly due to the pandas. Overall a most enjoyable visit.

Just how long the River Safari can survive without its headline promise is a big question but knowing the Singapore drive for efficiency and perfection, I'm sure that it will all be sorted quickly and will become a top attraction.

title: Fruitful walk with good mixture of indoor and outdoor
content:
Located at out skirt of town, but however it is easily accessible by using bus or train, taking the bus will be much more economical and as public transport in Singapore does not require one to wait for long time, it is totally acceptable to use the bus as a mean of transportation. Upon arrival, we are bombarded with long queue from other tourist, purchase your ticket earlier give you an advantage, you may purchase your ticket here: http://www.riversafari.com.sg and trust me, you don't want to wait under the hot sun.

The river safari offer a fascinating walk, giving us good combination of outdoor and indoor walk, each offering different wild life experience. From the outdoor, front we are offered a range of wild life including monkeys, lizard, alligators and some birds. While for indoor, you get to see lot of fishes and some are real big fish, really big fish. The explanation and information displayed give us a good read on what the animals name is, and what they feed on, indoor had a good air conditioning system, it gives you the cold comfort as you walk, spending two hour is quite normal if you take your time to walk and look around.

In between you can see the giant panda too, named kai kai and jia jia. Both are asleep most of the time, thus if you see them moving when you visit them, it is a lucky day for you. The panda reside inside a air condition room with some birds around, so it is never boring with only one animal at one time. There is a restaurant using the panda as a theme, and there is a "Pao" labelled as must try, but it is not special at all, just a normal "Pao" with some red bean paste.

Transportation out of the safari is quite difficult even with taxi as there are long queue again, thus taking the bus again might be a better choice since both are going to wait anyway.

title: When it is finished, this place will be awesome
content: The River Safari may have not been finished yet, but judging by what I saw, it is already awesome. My favourite part was seeing Kai Kai and Jia Jia in their spacious and beautiful enclosure along with red pandas and golden pheasants. I also loved the Mekong River Area as well as the Amazon flooded Forest. Can't wait to see the River Quest. So excited.

title: Excellent!
content:
We were not sure if this would be a good attraction because we haven't heard much about it before. Our 7-year old son is a great fan of Jeremy Wade and the River Monster show so he insisted that we go. It turned out to be a great place and the whole family had a great time.

The place was nicely layed out with most areas shaded. It makes it bearable even in the middle of a sunny day.

Major rivers and the many special fresh water fish, reptiles and amphibians from each part of the world are represented. Unless you are an expert in the field which you may find the explanations to the exhibits superficial, most people should find the information provided educational and easy to understand.

The pandas seem a bit out of place in the River Safari. But it was nice to go through the air conditioned room. We saw one of the pandas very close up and took great photos.

The place is not big so if we stroll along in a normal pace, you probably finish in a bit more than an hour. But since our kid is a great fans of fresh water fish and he has read a lot about them before, this place was amazing for him. He said he liked it a lot more than the night safari. I can understand some people may find it not so interesting. Afterall fresh water fish are not as colorful and eye catching.

title: underwhelming!
content: The place doesnt match up to the promo that the place gets on the net ...the Sea Cows saved the day ....else it was a boring walk through the different river themes that are created out here....there is a amzon river sections that is still to be opened to public...hope that adds some punch to the place...there are a couple of pandas on show...hmm...well my tip is ..when you plan for the singapore zoo /night safari trip...squeeze this is on the same day if time permits...not worth spending another day just for the river safari...

title: Half baked
content:
Yet to fully get operational till the end of this year. hence not much of a thing to see. More of repeats.

Their major attraction are the 2 pandas, but this cannot be the only point to spend money and see the place.

If you are still interested than for your information the panda enclosure closes at 5.15 and the park max by 6.

title: Good arrangements of animals and fishes in accordance with famous rivers round the world
content: My family went to River Safari recently and enjoyed it very much. The big fish enclosures where all kinds of fishes can swim freely is simply amazing! I have been to Queensland recently and have seen their displays and they are no match! We like the way the exhibits are displayed and found it very educational! It is a pity that the Amazon River cruise is not ready. I will definitely go again when it is ready!

title: Excellent adjunct to Singapore Wildlife attractions ......
content: We REALLY enjoyed this attraction even though it is still the "soft opening period". It will be interesting to see how crowded and noisy it gets once all the attractions and river cruise are in place .... for once we did not emerge from a "zoo" exhausted by the heat and crowds.... the exhibits were excellent - you could see the creatures really close up and the information was helpful. I have not really focussed on freshwater creatures before. It is all covered too which makes for a much more comfortable experience. The Indian Gharial was pretty impressive and the squirrel monkeys took a real interest in my daughter's red toenails! The highlight for me were the manatees - we were lucky to catch the feeding sessions - both underwater and on the surface - one baby manatee seemed to be "hugging" the diver ... wonderful animals.... the Panda forest is good - loved the red pandas - fine healthy looking exhibits ... only saw one of the giant pandas as the other is rather shy! I was not keen on the cartoonisation/branding of the pandas but I am an old fuddy-duddy! Will definitely come again .....

title: It could be good if it is open 100%
content:
By the time we go there is almost same when we go there previously..

Panda is the 1st and a must see in this river safari
Plus some aquarium contain fish, aligator and some animals..

The boat not yet in operation..

Panda Bao is must try item here.. Is a panda head steamed bun with red bean filling.. so yummy..

title: Pandas saved the day!
content:
Deceived by the brochures showing boats filled with visitors passing through a river lined with freshwater creatures large and small, I wasted time and money on the River Safari. The boats were non-existent and the creatures were all in tanks and enclosures.

I must say that the displays were attractive.

I did see the Giant Panda and the lovely red pandas, and that was some compensation.

title: Disappointing and expensive
content: Not fully completed yet. So quite expensive and disappointing. Better go to the new Aquarium at Sentosa or focus on the Zoo or Night Safari.

title: Above average but not excellance
content: Compound is not as big as I had expected. It's still on it's soft launch phase, another 1/3 of animals have not been exhibited. Looking forward to the increase of collection of animals living around the river. Good concept river theme park anyway.

title: Average Visit
content: Park is not completed yet as the river boat isn't available till later this year. Not many collection. Highlight is the Panda, but seemed rather lonely.

title: Want to see more types of fish
content:
I thought I could watch many types of fish here but perhaps it was in construction so that there were a few kinds of fish. But the other animals made me interesting. Particularly the cute and giant panda.
The attraction was a very good outdoor scenery and nature reserve. This place was in good condition and kept clean well.
I wish they had finish the whole place so that I could be more enjoyable.
I think I will be back!

title: Good although not completed
content:
We went there in April this year, but they hadn't actually completed the actual river safari portion of the place, which takes about 1/3 third of the place. But the other exhibits were open, and its more like a hybrid between an aquarium and a panda zoo, although only two normal pandas. Luckily they discounted the price, the map of the place and the way they set it up is quite nice actually

I will definitely go back when the finish the river safari portion

title: Good outdoor scenery
content: The attraction has very good outdoor scenery especially the nature reserves, the forest and the swamps. However, not many exotic fish were seen up close. Some of which were placed in a big tank and the fish were faraway from the people. Liked some of the sectors which have aircons. When the river boat quest opens, hope is a better improved place of interest.

title: Still work-in-progress!
content:
This is my first visit to River Safari (10 Oct. 2013). The Amazon River Quest boat ride and animal exhibits along this ride is only ready at later part of the year, as stated in the map.

On the whole, I was underwhelm. Other then the Panda Enclosure, the whole park is more of a work-in-progress! 2 Red Pandas were around during our visit, but for Giant Panda, only Kai Kai was around (and appeared bore!). Jai Jai was sleeping in her dent. The enclosure is cool and appear comfortable for the animals.

The park suffer from identity crisis of whether it's a zoo or an aquarium! At the moment, it's definitely have more fish then animal! Yet, even the fish are not exactly enough, which make the park very boring! Many tanks are empty or with few fishes, as compare to SEA Aquarium in Resort World Sentosa, which are fill with fishes!

The few exhibits I like other then the Pandas, are the Golden-headed Lion Tamarin (very lively bunch of animals) and the Squirrel Monkey Forest, which the adorable monkeys running and playing around us! Cute!

At S$25/pax (Discount price as the boat ride is not ready!), I feel it's a little bit overpriced! S$15 is more like it. Better go to the zoo next door! In fact, I think it should be co-operated as part of the zoo instead of a separate attraction!

title: Great when it is will be finished
content:
We enjoyed our visit but it will be great when it is finished and you can go on the boat cruise through the Amazon.

The first part (before the pandas) was a little disappointing. I wasn't particularly impressed by all the different rivers of the world which only really had 2-3 aquariums for each river with a couple of river animals/reptiles/fish per tank. The pandas were nice but one was hiding as very shy. The other was gorgeous but a bit sad to see such a spectacular animal in a relatively small enclosure. Once we crossed the bridge we got a bit of a look at the Amazon exhibit but the boat ride is not operational until the end of the year. Our kids really loved the Squirrel Monkey enclosure that you get to walk through. They loved the monkeys jumping and playing around them as we walked through. Worth a visit but not as impressive as Singapore Zoo (next door) or Jurong Bird Park.

title: Not impactful.
content:
Visited the River Safari due to free pass. I think it isn't really worth it, unless you are a marine life enthusiast.

Since the river cruise is not operational yet, there were basically just many exhibits of marine creatures to watch. It gets boring after a while seeing these marine creatures. Because all they do is just, swimming around in their enclosures.

For now, I guess the giant pandas and red pandas are the only ones that are worth visiting. It's nice to see them rather close up in their own space eating, and hanging around. However, their enclosures seem too small for them to wander around. The pandas don't really seem happy and comfortable. They prefer to hide behind the leaves to facing the crowd. The pandas' butts were facing the crowd most of the time.

In conclusion, it was not an impactful or memorable visit to me. I would not think of going back again.

title: Pandas!
content: The entry fee is worth paying just to see the Pandas - they were lovely to see close up in their enclosures eating and eating and sleeping! This is a new attraction - the river section was not open at time of visit but the entrance price is reduced, hence the 4 star rating. Its still worth visiting to also see the aquarium and other wildlife though and the walk around the park and across the lake is lovely.

title: Good for all kinds of weather!
content:
I am a friend of the Singapore Zoo, so I wasn't too keen on paying extra for tickets to the River Safari. It's not cheap, but I dare say well worth the money. Some observations that might be helpful:

1. The Amazonia quest boat ride is not ready yet. If you can wait, wait till that is ready (end of 2013?) to get full value for your dollar. (Tickets are now discounted though, to make up for that)

2. All walkways are fully sheltered. It's a great place to visit even in the monsoon season. In fact, it might be better in the rain, given our recent hot weather.

3. The main attractions - the panda exhibit and the flooded amazon forest are indoors and air conditioned. Wow. The pandas are the closest I have ever seen, and both Kai Kai and Jia Jia were feeding and active when I went at noon. Fantastic. There are seating areas in the flooded amazon forest and make for great manatee viewing. V comfy, cool and nice. And the manatees don't disappoint. We had one pooping (sounds gross but hey, that's Mother Nature) and lots swimming around. :)

4. Need to eat? The panda tea house is the only one inside the park. the other one is outside the safari entrance. Both eateries are pretty small and get loooong lines at lunchtime. You might be better timing your visit so you eat before or after at the eateries outside the main zoo area. The pizza place does pizza by slice AND sandwiches that are great for kids and taste quite decent. The coffee shop will sell cups of fruit. :)

title: Panda is the only attraction
content: Agreed that it is a good attraction for kids. Pandas are the only reason why I brought my family to this place. For the price which pretty much similar to what they offer for Zoo, it is better to go Zoo. I would not visit any time soon unless more fun activities and attractions to be added. I notice the river cruise/ ride is not available yet. You may want to try the panda bun made of red bean paste which was quite cute and nice.

title: Very interesting and good for kids
content: Its opposite to the singapore Zoo. Now what you see in singapore Zoo are things you'd see almost in every other zoo, but with the river Safari you;d see the water wildlife in a manner I have't seen most aquariums do.

title: Giant Pandas
content: The star attractions at the River Safari are the giant pandas and red pandas. Located next to Singapore Zoo. Great for a look close-up of these animals (close as can be). They are star attractions here, and easy to see why. Comfortable viewing too, since they are housed in a cool climate house. The red pandas are almost within reach and are a real sight to behold. This is an attraction that should not be missed.

title: A MUST SEE ATTRACTION
content: River safari is one of the newest attraction in Singapore co-located with the zoo and night safari. Although some of it is not yet open but shows life around some of the famous rivers of the world specially the flora and fauna. It has been laid out in a beautiful way to fit into the natural surrounding. Whole day can be spent to see the nature by combining this visit with the zoo & the night safari.

title: Worth a visit
content: This is well worth a visit in combination with a trip to the zoo (next door). As some of it is not open you get a discount - good idea to get a combo ticket with the zoo. Like everything in Singapore it is well organised and clean. I felt the animals looked healthy which is a good sign. A guide took a small group of us around and gave us a chance to get up close and personal with a number of (small!) animals. The manatees and pandas are sooo cute. When you come in just keep your eyes and ears open to catch a guide.

title: Get the view of many famous rivers..
content: Good place to visit with family...kids would feel happy to see different type of fishes. We could see the Pandas as well...which is rare to see elsewhere .

title: Not fully open but liked what was available
content:
Visited in September with the price reduced to $25 as some of the park was not yet open. We actually purchased a ticket for the river safari and the zoo to make a full day of it.

Took about two hours to visit the park. Panda enclosure was good and there was plenty of river life on how.

Overall, well priced and well worth a trip; perhaps coinciding with a visit to the zoo or night zoo.

title: Worth it if you're set on seeing a panda
content: I had high hopes for the River Safari. Unfortunately, the experience hasn't lived up to my expectation. The ride portion isn't open yet. Once it does open children have to be at least 3 years old to ride. The highlight is the Giant Panda Forest. However, this closes before the rest of the park. The day I was there it closed at 5:30 and the park at 6. It's at the back of the park so plan accordingly if you're going later in the day. As much as we enjoy this part of the park I still can't get over the value for the money, especially when compared with the zoo. Perhaps I just enjoy colorful fish and therefore prefer the SEA Aquarium.

title: Disappointing... wait until river safari boat ride is operational.
content: We visited the River Safari as part of its soft opening and were sorely disappointed. We were aware that the river safari boat ride will only be operational at the end of this year, but we were not expecting the dearth of exhibits and animals, a large chunk of which are not yet open to the public. A series of water enclosures with various forms of marine life from rivers around the world are open. However, my 7-year old twins couldn't help but exclaim that the Underwater World and SEA Aquarium were much prettier and more enjoyable! They did enjoy the red pandas and panda bears in the Giant Panda Forest, but this wasn't enough to redeem the park in my kids' eyes. I intend to wait till the entire park is open before venturing there again.

title: To be avoided
content: I visited the new River Safari attraction as part of a company function. Having visited the Night Safari I was optimistic as to what would be in store. I was especially interested in seeing the pandas. First, the good things: the panda enclosure was done well. It was a joy to see the red pandas and we even managed to glance one of the two pandas. Pity that you had to walk through the tacky gift shop as you exited. Many of the acquariums were also very interesting though you could do better at one of the other two acquariums in the city. The rest of the attraction was non descript. That is until you get to the polar bear. I don't know whose idea it is to put an animal that usually lives in sub-zero temperatures in a tropical environment where the minimum temperature is 25 degrees centigrade. The sight of this wonderful giant in a pathetically small pool made me disgusted at the whole effort made here. I will not be going back and I would recommend anyone who cares for animal welfare to avoid this place.

title: Educational Trip
content:
It was well presented and very educational.
It's sad to see the pandas, they were in good condition and eating very well based on the displayed nutritional diet, they have a big enough enclosure...but they don't belong there, they should be in a sanctuary. While watching them you can't help but feel that it's just wrong.
The facilities are clean and spacious.
It was a nice journey through the different rivers of the world.

title: Getting Better as it approaches completion
content:
Its understandable why some people are disappointed in the River Safari as it is a work in progress. If you know this in advance then you can enjoy the extensive collection of fish and mammals from the worlds rivers which is the major design theme of the River Safari - with the obvious exception of the highly publicized pandas from China.

The best, and most economical, way to visit this is with a Park Hopper Pass. We chose the 3 in 1 Park Hopper with the Jurong Bird Park, Singapore Zoo and River Safari. At S$ 59 per adult the pass is a great value and effectively gives you entrance to the River Safari for S$ 17 if you were to purchase tickets separately. For parents with children the discounted ticket may be worth the price to see the pandas.

I very much enjoyed the journey through the world rivers and expect it to be even more interesting when it is fully operational. If you have already been to SEA then you may wish to bypass this until complete. We visited both the Underwater World and SEA and still enjoyed this as there is always more to learn.

title: Impressive - even if not finished yet
content: When we visited the park in August 2013 it was not completely finished, so parts were not accessible. But anyhow the aquariums and shows are very nice and impressive and we loved - of course - the Manates most.

title: Only if you really like fish and aquariums
content:
This park is sheltered all the way and you can still visit on a rainy day. However, it can get very crowded on weekends.

Exhibits are well maintained with lots of information. But you can complete the whole tour within Max 90mins (since almost 1/3 not opened yet).

Pandas are over rated. It was actually quite sad to see them being exhibited in a small area with lots of people taking photos of them. The pandas looked uncomfortable/scared.

I won't recommend this unless you have a free pass. Sea aquarium at sentosa is more worth it.

title: It's a let-down
content:
Nothing much to expect, it's just another aquarium but accompanied with two famous panda from China.

If this place is part of Zoological Garden, it's worth while....but to charge another fee for a new attraction, it's not worth it!

The entrance fee is too costly for what you get to see. I rather go to SEA Aquarium in Sentosa.

Never to return unless I got free pass.

title: I love the male panda,Kai Kai.beautiful and a lot of fresh water fishes.
content:
U must try it!i love the fishes that they put there.Pzzzzttt,be quite when once u enter the place of Kai Kai and Jia Jia!u will find Kai Kai(the male panda) alwaz eating or sleeping.but not for the female panda,she like to stay alone in her "room",u can see thru the CcTV that they put in her room.
if u can see her outside..means u r soooo lucky!i was shock once I enter the lil forest where is the pandas lives there,u can see directly what are they doing at the moment,without any wall,even glass wall!!feels like u r into it!

title: Cool Place To Be
content: Liked everything and the flora and fauna were superb. They have put together a bouquet of animals in a setting that would make some other countries in the region blush. When the river cruise actually opens out, it will be one great place to visit again and again.

title: Giant Aquarium
content:
2nd outing and still feel that it's a giant aquarium with panda outing. Panda viewing is quite packed even on off peak days, but was a joy to see pandas.
The giant fish tanks makes me want to rebuild my home aquarium and I wish that I could have a reservoir behind my home so that I can always get fresh water.

title: Better than expected
content:
I thoughts the pandas are the main attraction . Turns out that there were an excuse to make use of the natural reservoirs around the vicinity to a 'river safari' .
I had little expectation when I visited. But I found myself learning about the different rivers in the world. The setup around the reservoir is v scenic . Such views are not common in a busy city like Singapore . I was enchanted by the big aquarium with the manatees - sunlight filtering through and the low and unobtrusive sound of ocean
waves in the background ..
Oh yes - the pandas were there too !

title: not River safari but an Aquarium safari
content:
we have always admired the way the Singapore Zoo had operated. and particularly the Night Safari . visiting a zoo at night is just so different. and gave us a genuinely different experience.
so when we signed up for their River safari, we were expecting a surprising twist .

we were severely disappointed. when we booked for the river safari, we were told that for part of the tour was not available i.e. the boat ride through the Amazon. okay they were up front with us on that.
and we were given a discount for the minor inconvenience.

however what then remained of the River safari was nothing like we had expected.

it turned out to be a walk in a covered walkway, looking at an Aquarium . with lots of fishes in many tanks. some of the tanks were of course pretty huge. but nonetheless it would been better to call it the Aqaurium safari

adding a short boat ride and seeing animals in a faux pau Amazon wouldnt compensate for the disappointment of the long walk through the Aquarium.

i will try to visit again once the boat ride is available and to see if my original comments and impressions are correct.

title: Good to visit
content: This is pretty new and worth for a visit specially with kid, is like a small zoo and you can visit the Panda too. Normally people combine this with the night safai. You can get a 15% discount if you purchase ticket from the tourist centre.

title: Visit only when it's fully opened.
content:
Don't waste your time here! It is not fully ready yet. It's like visiting the sea aquarium except that this place is non aircond. Spent around 2 hours max. If you have time, visit the zoo or the night safari and come back only when it's opened.

Tips:
1. Not crowded. So don't have to come early.
2. Bring water and snacks, drinks are expensive.
3. Visit the panda enclosure, it's a nice place to cool down besides looking at the cute pandas.
4. Located 2 mins walk from the Singapore zoo. Combine river safari with the zoo.

Hope it helps.

title: Good walk in the safari
content: This is the only attraction I wanted to come before my arrival this time. The place is stiuated in the north side of the island and the surrounding is still remain the same as 10 years old, quiet and pleasant, especially after seeing so much changes for the country over the week. The selection of creatures is well done. I like how it divides by region. The description is informative too. I guess the only comment I have is, I was quite disappointed when being told that the Amazon River ride and half of this region is not ready until end of the year. I didn't see any detail on the website before. Only later I heard, you need to click inside the map in order to know the detail. They should include this vital information on the front page of the website. I would still come and be prepared without any disappointment. In addition, if you want to use the locker, please prepare three $1 coin. The staff at the service counter might need further training in the customer service skill. Last but not less, I was thrilled to be able to see the polar bear!

title: Brilliant, If not better than the zoo!!!
content: We loved this place, located next door to the zoo. We visited before we went in the zoo. It's immaculate, well designed. Even though the boat ride wasn't open yet, it didn't detract anything from our visit. It's mostly under covered walkways, so nice and shaded. The animals on show were great to see, especially the panda exhibit. Nothing like Edinburgh's terrible exhibit! It takes about two/three hours to walk around. We would definitley visit again!

title: River Safari - Not quite ready and not a safari experience
content:
It was entirely reasonable to have high expectations of River Safari. After all, Singapore has had a reputable world-class zoo for a long long time. To have opened the place when only half the place is ready is surprising. I really can't recall a tourist attraction in Singapore that was open when half of it was not done up.
Yes, it is located at a river but a safari experience it is not.
Instead you will see tanks and tanks of fish. Actually when I was looking at the manatee theatre-like tank, I can be forgiven when for a while I thought I was at the S.E.A aquarium of Sentosa.
There is something in the design of the place that I just find disappointing- it is just boring and not exciting, despite the tremendous potential the location offers, being located at a nature reserve area. Considering Singapore always gets the best brains to do things, this attraction can be a letdown especially for discerning visitors. Seriously, even the souvenir store within the park wasn't inspiring, to say the least.
So, expect to see a good exhibit of cute Kai Kai and Jia Jia and you won't be disappointed (come in the morning coz they are active in the morning) but the panda enclosure is not as big as I had expected. I can imagine mayhem if you come during the holidays and cannot have a proper look.
Seriously, we were out of the place in one hour.
If you are thinking of taking your overseas friends to River Safari, you might have to apologise for the less-than-satisfactory experience, so think twice especially if they have seen pandas before. They will have a better experience at the main zoo or even the Night Safari.
Tip 1 : Arrive by 8.50am at least coz there is a queue to buy ticket
Tip 2 : Bring your own food because the food outlets within the park are not quite ready

title: Hot ! Hot ! Hot !
content:
A present or was there to introduce some rare animal, fishes around 3pm, along the animal watching, it's only a warm wind blowing, we were all sweating like sitting in a sauna room until we got to watch panda, in air cond room, many refuse to move around as it's too warm, young children got pinkish cheeck, and adult seem to look very tiring.

Got to enjoy panda bun in the restaurant next to panda show, along the walk way before reaching panda showroom, I don't see a drink vending machine along.

No river boat and animal along to show that how we gotnamdiscounted ticket price

title: Pandas!
content: While the park is not fully completed yet (the Amazon River ride is still not open), the reduced entry fee (25$ instead of 35$) seems worthit for the Pandas. Go early in the morning, and you can (like us) spend hours watching these fascinating creatures eat, and pace around. What we did was skip everything,and head for the Panda Enclosure once we got in, then back track to take in the rest of the park. The rest of the part of also quite well done - it's also mostly shaded, so you are out of the elements if it rains. The Panda themed restaurant is expensive, but worth the visit for the Panda Pau - food was decent as well. The Panda exhibit was considerably better thought out than the San Diego Zoo equivalent, and larger. It's also fully climate controlled, which in Singapore is a godsend :) Woth a visit if you are a Panda fan, and want to see them up close and in action.

title: A very place to visit
content:
I visited River Safari on a Singapore public holiday with my 3 year old son. This was my first visit after purchasing an annual pass. As I am local and will visit it again, I just want to look over at the various attractions.

One of my first advice to visitors is to go very early in the morning if it is a long weekend due to a Singapore holiday. The car park was full at around 11:30am. And there were long traffic jams all the way from the attractions to Mandai Road (about 1km away) as the incoming cars cannot get to a car park. the taxis and buses are also trapped in the same jam.

Since we were there at around 11am, we are able to take one of the last parking lots. There were very long lines at the ticket counters. Luckily, we have an annual pass and breeze right in through the gates.

One of my observations is that there is a lot of 'water' related attractions, seems to compete with the Sentosa underwater world? Also, I noticed that the area is almost completely covered. As such, visits there are not vulnerable to bad whether. There was a bridge over a body of water. I really like that walk, felt so immersed in nature and it was also cooling as there is shelter from the sun and a light breeze.

The star attraction is the Giant Panda. This attraction is air-conditioned and was in a very good temperature. There was also an enclosure with two/three red pandas (they look like raccoons but red in color). I noticed that these red pandas seems so healthy and clean. They were also very active and was running all over and climbing the trees and branches. There was a branch overlooking the pathway for visitors. As such, you can actually look up and see the red panda walking above you. I thought it was pretty neat.

After the red Panda, we saw the two Giant Panda. There were quite a few visitors and I guess the visitors have to take turns. One of them Jia Jia, was pretty lethargic when I was there and there were fewer visitors.

The other Panda Kai Kai was very active and was walking around his enclosure. There was a small pool of water and we saw Kai Kai 'taking a bath'. Everyone went "ooohhhh" when Kai Kai shaked off the water (like a dog).

I like the fact that the people who designed the enclosure eliminate the need for any visible boundaries between panda and visitors. There was no metal bars or glass panels. The Pandas felt very close and the visit was very intimate. I felt almost as if I am paying them a visit rather than looking at a display.

I left right after this. I will come back again to look at the displays in more detail and to pay the Pandas another visit.

title: Good visit to see the pandas
content:
My sole purpose in making a trip down to River Safari is to see the pandas. Unlike the zoo, I felt the place was better positioned around the lake which gave the place a tranquil vibe. Other then that, the exhibits of sea creatures were pretty interesting and there were lots of air-conditioning (unlike the zoo). The enclosed full length area of the manatees resembled much of the one at Resorts World Sentosa.

Disappointed that only Kai Kai was out to entertain and Jia Jia as in her private quarters. Went back twice during the visit to see if Jia Jia came out but the second visit proved fruitless. Oh well.

Recommend to visit once the River Safari rise is open later in 2013.

title: Disappointing but not full open on our visit
content:
We visited the River Safari as we got a discounted rate by due to the fact that the boat trip wasn't open and because it was cheaper when buying it along with the Singapore Zoo ticket. I wish though that we had just stuck with the zoo as it only took about 2 hours to walk around and there was very little to see really.
The manatees were really cool to see in the Amazon flooded forest and the giant glass windows that surround it make for great viewing. Also, it was amazing to see a couple of giant Pandas which was the main reason for us visiting this particular attraction.
The information on the various rivers around the world was interesting but overall there isnt enough to keep you here for that long and we got a little tired of seeing endless amounts of fish.

title: not the standard you would expect (not fully opened when I went there)
content:
Singapore's delivers some of the greatest zoo experiences in the world with their Night Safari and the zoo itself so you should expect great things for their newest creation but the River Safari can't live up to the standards of it's prodecessors unfortunately.

Now as mentioned in the title the whole park wasn't opened yet and I would think that when the Amazon trail will be the park will get higher ratings but for the moment it's not worth the trip.

They do however have pandas so if that's on ones bucket list this is a great place to go! you get up and close with them once you've pushed your way through the crowds :)

title: Skip this until full attraction opens later this year
content: This is done very similar to the zoo, but in the absence of the actual river safari it is not worth even the $25, a discounted price since the river safari part isn't open. Skip this until they open everything towards the end of the year. Until then it seems like just another part of the zoo.

title: A new one to add to the ever growing list
content:
Singapore's newest animal attraction! Firstly, a word of warning (the river boat section has not yet opened and will not be a part of the part till late August, there is a reduction in the price because of this). The consequence is quite a long walk around the park taking up to three hours to walk from start to finish however, there are cafes and restaurants on route and beautiful locations to have a sit and rest at.

The park is extremely educational and a great experience to have. Highlights for me included the amazing dugong tank, and the massive enclosures for two giant pandas, it also has many unique animals form the Amazon to those found in the Congo, kids and adults will love. I would not recommend the three park hopper until the attraction is open fully. To get to the Zoo, River Safari and Night Zoo its a 45minute ride by bus from inner city Singapore, so you might be tempted to do two or more in one day. however, try to spread them over a few days as you will get a lot more out of them. Animal overload can definitely occur if its squashed into a shorter time period than this! Have fun hannah

title: A Return To Nature!
content:
An interesting attraction that brings various kinds of animals, reptiles and sea creatures closer to us humans and allows us the opportunity to learn more about them.
Besides the stars of the show, i.e. the very adorable pandas (but they were not very active at all but were just lying around enjoying the A/C I guess) we really loved the huge aquariums.
One of our favs must be the manatees and we wished we had the time to stay for the feeding but we missed it.
What is unfortunate is that the park is not fully opened with the river cruise being non-operational. But, the visit was still worth it as there were many other attractions to see.
Be sure to also have a meal at their themed restaurants, my personal favourite being the one after the panda exhibit. The food was actually rather good but make sure you order the 'panda bao' (only 200 pieces are made every day). It was sooo cute but also quite yummy with lotus seed filling.
All in all, it was a most enjoyable time and do remember to bring along the camera for many Kodak moments.

title: Beautiful and interesting & cute pandas
content: We loved the pandas - who does not? But the rivers were also very nice and explanations interesting. The aquarium with the manatees is impressive and the monkey forest fun. It will be even nicer when the boat ride on the Amazone is opened.

title: Exotic sea creatures, Amazing Manatees!
content: For wildlife / sea creature lovers, there is a great variety of exotic sea creatures, including those that appear on the River Monsters documentary. My fave was the gigantic "flooded Amazon" tank with the manatee families! We spent the longest time there watching the manatees lounging and relaxing we felt super relaxed too! TIP: after the huge manatee tank, so stop by the smaller viewing area as the babies love to hang around the surface near this glass viewin area! Up close and personal with the babies! TIP2: food at Panda restaurant is nice (Sze Chuan food) but lunch queues can be pretty long. Do go earlier or later if you wanna have lunch there. TIP3: the river boat cruise is only open at year end so ticket prices are cheaper now. If you are a resident, try to get discount packages from People's Association Community Centres or your Residents' Committee. We only paid $20 per adult ($15 per child) for ticket, buffet breakfast and 2-way coach transfers!

title: Can't wait for the fully open park!
content: Such a pleasant experience! The place is so beautiful, with the river in the middle of the park. The fresh water aquarium is so amazing, with a lot of fish that I had never seen before. Went ther on Monday, not so crowded inside, but the ticket queue was sooo loongg. But they also sell ticket without queue , just add 4 sgd, and they gave souvenirs too. Pandaaaa.. so cute!! Jia Jia and kai Kai both are so adorable ^^. The river safari boat still shut off, maybe next year they will fully open. Can't wait to experience the river safari boat..

title: Will be fantastic when fully open
content: The River Safari is the newest addition to Singapore's assortment of zoos/animal parks. The park is designed to showcase species who thrive in and around rivers throughout the world. Unfortunately, we visited before the park was fully open (the entire western half of the park was still shut off) so didn't get the whole experience. Despite that, the park is still definitely worth a visit. All of the fish tanks are open to view, showcasing animals from all over the world, including several species of alligator and a family of manatees. The main attraction to most will be the pandas. The pair live in a very well-designed climate-controlled exhibit alongside their red cousins. I saw signs saying that you are required to book a viewing time to see the pandas, however, we walked straight in on three occasions, so I guess this is just for peak times. The price is very reasonable aswell, especially if you buy the park hopper ticket. I have suggested that the visit will take 2-3 hours, however, this could be vastly different when the park is fully open

title: Go on weekdays for a better experience
content:
I dropped by the River Safari on a Friday afternoon and found it pleasantly quiet. There was no massive crowd, which made it very easy to move around and get decent views of the animals - especially when it came to seeing the pandas.

The River Safari is basically a river-themed aquarium. It isn't as big as the zoo and isn't completed yet, but for SGD25 I think I got a pretty good bargain. I unfortunately missed all the feeding times, but that was no big deal for me. They have a decent variety of fish and other river fauna, arranged according to the major rivers of the world - the Mississippi, the Congo, the Murray River, the Ganges, the Nile, the Mekong, the Yangtze, the Amazon.
Highlights for me were the two huge gharials (though their enclosure seemed on the small side for two large reptiles), the sturgeon, the pandas, and the manatees. The crab-eating macaques were amusing too, with their antics in and around the water. You may also get a glimpse of the polar bear in the zoo - there's a viewing panel for the polar bear's tank right outside the panda enclosure. That was pretty cool.

Freshwater fish are not nearly as pretty as saltwater fish, so if you don't have as much interest in fish or in zoos you might get bored rather quickly. (I can imagine that it is quite possible to see the whole place right now in less than 2 hours, if you just hurry through it.) But for those who do have an interest, the River Safari is quite worth the money!

The place should be more interesting when it's fully open, but for now, SGD25 isn't bad at all.

* Photography tip: Using the normal built-in flash on your camera doesn't really help if you want to take pictures of a fish hiding in a dim tank of water. You'd probably get a glaring white spot in the middle of your picture as the flash reflects off the glass. Best to revert to high shutter speeds, if your camera has that capability. (I had my camera with me, but found that my iPhone took fairly nice pictures, considering its limitations...)
The glare of the flash is also not good for the fish. So do take heed of the notices around when they prohibit flash photography.

title: Love it
content: It's very pleasant journey to saw all the beautiful animals there. My sons really impressed and learned a lot about the animals. The view of the lake were so peaceful. The panda bun and the panda cappucinno were cute. I'm sure the place will be more impressive after the boat ride open.

title: Do the night safari and zoo first until it's fully open
content:
The title pretty much sums up my impression with the caveat that it may be better once the boat ride opens. I've been to the night safari and zoo several times and would definitely recommend these ahead of the river safari, with night safari being the must do attraction. Both the zoo and night safari have set a very high standard so the river safari has tough acts to follow.

It took me a little over an hour to go round the river safari and many of the displays were still awaiting their occupants. As I walked round I did find myself wondering, 'where is the river, in this river safari?' Essentially you follow a path through various aquariums and displays. I had hoped for a winding route past running water....like a river? However, if you have visited an aquarium before and a zoo then this experience will not feel vastly different. The panda, yes singular, did save the day and as it was very quiet when I attended (mid-week mid afternoon). I had plenty of time and room to have an excellent view of bamboo being devoured.

Overall, the panda experience makes the river safari worth visiting in it's unfinished form, but if you have a choice and can live without the pandas do the zoo or night safari instead.

title: Wow!
content:
I went to this park today and I was totally impressed!!! There are SO many weird looking sea creatures that I never seen before and that totally blew my mind away. Some of the species really look like it belongs to the dinosaurs' family. Haha. I think the River Safari has done an excellent job in the layout of the park, ensuring it's eco-friendly but yet not exposing visitors to direct sunlight. With the huge water landscape and occasional wind, it does feel good and brings down the humidity level. Definitely work a visit and worth paying $25/adult per entry. Double the trip up with a visit to the Zoo!

Oh yes, they have strollers and lockers for rentals too.

title: Awesome
content:
I didn't expect to be wowed by this place since the entrance fees seem steep for an attraction that isn't fully completed yet. Reluctantly, I dragged my feet to visit this place for my children's sake and boy was I surprised.

We were greeted by friendly and helpful staff at the entrance who provided us with lots of information about the various ticket options and annual pass promotions available. As we entered the River Safari at 9.25am, we were just in time for the feeding of various species of fish. The children were enthralled by how some of the fish feed and I was amazed at how close we get to observe the sea creatures. For the first time, I was able to see right in front of me how the teeth, scales and eyes of an Indian Gharial (crocodile like creature) look like as it was just swimming behind the glass enclosure. Have you ever looked a crocodile in the eye? Well, now I can say that I have! The feeling of seeing such a magnificent animal so close was breathtaking!

The world's largest freshwater aquarium was simply mesmerising. As you walked into the dimly lit aquarium with soft music playing in the background, you seem to have entered a magical fairytale like surrounding with manatees swimming all around you. I could just sit there for hours to admired the manatees. We were very reluctant to leave the place.

My children enjoyed seeing the pandas but I wasn't wowed. Jia Jia was very shy and we were very lucky to have caught a glimpse of her. Otherwise, I would have felt a little cheated. What River Safari could do better at the attraction is to train their staff to be more polite and approachable to parents when advising them about keeping their children's excitement under control. If they are overly stern to a point of being impolite then it really spoils the fun.

On the whole, we really enjoyed the experience so much that we bought the annual pass right after we exited. Thumbs up to the designers and creators of this attraction as it gives a truly wonderful experience that is different from the Zoo!

title: Panda-monium
content:
We went here to see the pandas. They were as cute as expected. But we were disappointed that there was really not much else to see. The only other thing that intrigued our 8 year old was the manatees. The monkey exhibit looked cute, but we skipped it as we have one at our local zoo.
We had a light lunch at the cafe near the pandas - quite tasty and decent value.

title: Disappointing. May improve when fully complete
content:
As a family, we love visiting the Singapore Marine Life Park.

When the river safari opened up, we were really excited about visiting this new attraction.

First things first. As others have pointed out, this is a very small attraction currently.

Secondly, the boat ride isn't active which kind of defeats the purpose of a 'safari'.

Thirdly, the displays are small and on a typical hot day, one is left with the feeling of 'why did I bother...?'

Even tanks in the 'Indian' section were empty of any fish.

The Panda section is a welcome cool respite.

There is a show featuring some of the inhabitants from the safari and it can be easily missed. The show lacks the 'wow' factor of the ones in the bird park or the zoo (from a child's perspective).

Perhaps this will be a completely different experience when it is fully open but in my view, this is a complete miss currently.

title: Like it but to small
content:
I wasn't having much expectation to this new attraction after hearing from my colleague that how small is the place, but I was still thinking, cannot be that small. However, when I was there, I really know what they meant of small. The area is really not big if compare with zoo or there have same compound but zoo definitely has more stuff to see than river safari. The highlight of the river safari is the few important river species in the world, the panda and the amazon aquarium. It is not fully open, almost 40% still in progress so kind of not very worth for the visit now to me for paying $25(Discounted Price due to incomplete, original is $35, Thanks to my company I actually got the access for Free). i finished it within 2 hours(with 30 mins of show).

It is like going to aquarium with all the reptile keep inside, so most of the place consider indoor, best even if raining you will not get wet. I especially love the panda forest(depends on your luck, best to visit them during their feeding time around 12 noon) and the huge aquarium at Amazon area. The other 40% will be open end of the year, hopefully when I visit next year it will have more fun. The incomplete one looks like a boat ride and you will see some animals.

title: A breathtaking journey, but the enclosures can be bigger
content:
The river safari is a new addition to the zoo, but it's an attraction on its own with separate entrance fee from the zoo and the night safari. The giant pandas and the manatees are the main attractions here, but there are nice presentations along the way, with an educational tour of the different river ecosystems.

As of this review, the amazon boat ride is not available yet, so the entrance fee is reduced to S$25. But rest assured you can see about 70% of the exhibits, which is awesome.

After the giant panda enclosure there is a little cafe selling Chinese food and various panda-inspired snacks, e.g. panda bun and ice-cream, so you can have the energy to see the rest of the exhibits.

I personally think it is very very well done, but I also think the enclosures, although very well designed, should be twice as big to be comfortable for the animals.

To avoid spoilers all I'll say is prepare to be blown away at the end of the journey. I highly recommend this visit.

title: Superb visit
content: Just came back from the River Safari. The Amazonian part is still not open but from the current attractions, this experience was top notch. The Mekong River, the pandas and the manatees from the Amazon Flooded Forest were star attractions. Go during the feeding times. Highly recommended.

title: Packed, half closed and not much to see.
content:
When we went, we knew that half of the park was closed, and this was reflected in the ticket price, as we paid 2/3 of the ticket price.
