When we got in, it was packed, and there was no space to move around to actually see the animals.

The main exhibit was the pandas and it was a free for all when we got in, as there were about 100 people around the fence and would not budge so we rarely even saw the panda bears. This place would benefit from letting a few people in at a time so others do not have to suffer.

If you are tempted to buy 2 or 3 combination tickets to different parks, please leave this off of your plans, very disappointing.

title: River Safari beats Resorts World Sentosa's Oceanarium for experience
content:
My expectations for the latest attraction in Singapore, the River Safari, were all about the pandas but the beauty of the global River theme meant that the pandas were just one of many things worth seeing here.

It's a very pleasant experience all round with the way that the park is laid out and themed. All undercover and all set in a vast reservoir its a very relaxing and enjoyable attraction that compliments the neighbouring Zoo, Night Safari and Bird Park.

The manatee attractions were especially amazing. Enormous underwater whale like creatures related to the elephants set in a mighty amazon themed tank that showed off their beauty.

The attraction is great for kids and kids at heart alike with some very entertaining monkeys and the space to enjoy the mighty pandas from many different angles.

Although the attraction is not yet complete it was still a more relaxing and enjoyable experience than the competing Oceanarium at Resorts World Sentosa and I would recommend it very highly.

title: Pandas are the star attraction!
content:
This attraction is now a stand-alone attraction and you have to pay separately to the Zoo to visit. This is where they have a special enclosure for their star attractions the Giant Pandas Kai Kai & Jia Jia.
Unfortunately when we visited it is still not fully operational and the actual River Safari is not running yet. A small point they never mentioned when we were enquiring about it. Other than that it was worth the visit alone to see The Pandas. They are absolutely gorgeous even if the female Jia Jia is a little shy. You probably only need a couple of hours to do it so could probably visit the Zoo on the same day.

title: Excellent even for now! Can't wait for the rest to open!
content:
I visited with little expectation but instead found it to be much better and more enjoyable than the zoo (the zoo's exhibits are clearly showing its age). The concept of displaying the majors rivers of the world and its inhabitants provide an excellent overview of the diversity of the rivers' ecosystems - I think it will interest the adults more than the children. Certain exhibits such as the manatee blew my mind away!

There is a guide that provides free commentaries (just tag along with her) - she is lively and certainly did a great job!

For those who like pandas - note that the more shy Jia Jia seldom comes out to meet visitors - best to see both would be during their feeding times! That happens several times of the day (check with the guides inside the panda centre). Personally, I prefer the red pandas.

The river safari is an excellent back-up plan if it rains - by far a very promising attraction at this present moment and one that I don't mind visiting again soon!

Note: Plan 2-3 hours to cover the exhibits.

title: Just for the Pandas, it was worth it!
content: Even thought it is not fully completed, the main attraction for many families is the Panda. It is still worth going just to see the panda. Bring jacket along, it can be very cold in the Panda exhibition.

title: Just for the pandas!
content: Newly open and not many things to see. Panda is cute! Ticket is expensive and not worthy. The overall idea is good, shaded walk by the river. But I think this should be part of the zoo.

title: Mainly disappointing
content: Being a big zoo fan and knowing the Singapore zoo and night safari I was really disappointed by this one. The idea is nice, but the whole thing is so small that is took me less then an hour to see everything (I should be mentioned that parts of the park are still under construction). The panda exhibit is nice (but has nothing to do with the river theme) and the sunken rainforest is really fascinating, but besides these two hilights there is unfortunately not much. Would we a great extension to the regular zoo, but as an attraction on its on insufficient.

title: A riverside walk in the shade
content:
This is a newly added attraction right next to the SG Zoo. It is so new that about half of the safari is still under construction and they give you a discount for that.

Though it is hot in day time, the whole safari is well covered that you can enjoy breezy coming in once in a while! And it is natural breeze!! In here, we visited the panda house. The pandas are just cute. And do not miss the crocodile tank where they have two big crocodiles with one swimming all the time close to the tank window, and is always ready for you to take "group phote" with.

Worth visiting again when they have the whole safari completed.

title: River Safari
content: We have visited the zoo many times and love it, the setting is so lovely in a rainforest. The new attraction River Safari, we really enjoyed it, to see the panda's was amazing, we stayed quite a while watching them eat enormous quantities of bamboo. The river safari bit wasn't up and running, but they charged us a smaller amount with this not finished yet, so next time we are in Singapore we will go and have a look at that. It was amazing to see the Panda,s they are so lovely. It is a well thought out attraction, and very educational. Highly Recommended !

title: Shaded walk by the rivers
content: It was a hot hot Singapore day and we set out early so we could beat the heat, but to our pleasant surprise it is mostly covered, breezy and even air con in few places. So it was a pleasant and easy 2 hour walk. The river quest is to open later this year and so the fees is reduced by 10 SGD. Amazon region was the best though the pandas were adorable too. Some rare creatures, like beavers, manatees, squirrel monkeys were there to be seen. Overall enjoyable trip for me and my 20 year old son, but I will visit again when it is fully operational. Best combined with a trip to the zoo, bird park and night safari.

title: Adorable giant pandas
content: The river safari showed the major rivers in the world, although part of the park was closed. The highlight are the cute giant pandas. It's an easy walk around the park, but attractions are limited.

title: TOTAL WASTE OF TIME AND MONEY
content: It is newest attraction in Singapore. It is from the house of Singapore zoo. It is basically a zoo with some part as aquarium. It is below average as per Singapore standard and it is only half operational and they are charging full fare. Singapore zoo or night safari are 100 times better than this. Only a panda is worth seeing otherwise total waste of time and money.

title: River Safari
content: Not upto mark as expected. No safari as such, only display of sea animals. Although set up was good. I pity the poor panda, don't think they liked staying there. Not recommended by me.

title: Great place dor children
content: Nice environment, very clean, good job from Singapore goverment. Nice place for learing about river species and environment. But it still not finish all yet. Also have Panda. Will back again when in Singapore. A very good concept

title: Great park but wait for the boat ride
content: I love the park layout, its open, breezy and easy to walk around, given that I had 2 old folks with me. The main attraction was clearly the Pandas, though other wildlife are also worth its salt, such as the Indian Gharials, the Manatees, the Red-bellied Piranhas and etc. One tip, make sure that you clear your bowels before entering the park as the next toilet is located after the Panda viewing gallery which is quite a distance away from the entrance.I am quite sure that once the Amazon River Quest Boat ride is operational, it will bring the River Safari to greater heights. Glad to have such an attraction in Singapore as it adds some excitement to our urban city.

title: Enjoyed ourself even though not fully opened, mostly covered walkways
content:
We visited end-June. Although the River Safari is not fully opened, we still pretty much enjoyed ourself. We had a toddler so the covered walkways really helped shelter us from the heat.

The signboards with clear explanation as we move along. Overall it's a well organise river safari.
Will definately be back once the whole park is ready.

title: Beautiful environment
content: We felt refreshed when we entered River Safari for the first time a week ago. This was saying a lot as we went on a Friday morning where the PSI level hit 400 by 12 p.m. that same day! It was uncharacteristically quiet that day, with only another 2 local families and a family from Philippines, I believe. We went that morning as I had a voucher I needed to redeem to get our family membership for River Safari before it expired, and we knew we would not spend more than a couple of hours there. We were surprised by the fact that the entire place was sheltered and several parts of the attraction was enclosed / air conditioned. The kids (aged 4 and 9) were overjoyed to see the piranhas, the manatees and the giant sea lions. They had seen the pandas a number of times overseas so they were not too impressed by that, though Kai Kai (the male panda who is the drama papa) was really adorable. Jia Jia (female panda) was nowhere to be seen (again! the first time when we went to see just the pandas, entrance from the zoo, she was MIA too) but you could see her in her room, taking a nap, through the CCTV. There was an enclosure for the squirrel monkeys where you could enter and the monkeys are just going about freely. The Filipino family was stroking a monkey that appeared tame enough, but before long, we heard cries from their teenage daughter. Apparently, the monkey had bitten her and she must have been shocked, the poor dear. So, tourist (both locals and foreigners) tip: do not attempt to touch the monkeys. We had a snack at the Panda Cafe (ok, I forgot its actual name) and the kids enjoyed the salt and pepper chicken (two servings!) as well as the deep fried lotus root, I love their panda bun (filled with one of the smoothest red bean paste I had ever had) and hubbs had the panda coffee. A little over priced as you can expect from tourist attractions but at least the quality is not too bad =) The "aquarium" area was lovely, where it was air conditioned and you could sit comfortably and gawk at the manatees that were swimming at their own pace - very therapeutic! When the entire place is ready in December (with the boat ride), we expect it would be even better! Must go!!!

title: Panda attraction
content: Main attraction would be the Panda, the river cruise is not ready yet so maybe it would be better when it is fully completed. Admission charges is on the high side as I would say there are more things to see in the Singapore Zoological Garden

title: River safari without river safari...
content:
We visited River Safari after th Zoo. I suppose, it will be great attraction after opening of boat ride and it'll be real river safari. Unfortunately, now it is not.

Some of the animals, we already met in the Zoo. Few water tanks were not very good cleaned.There is the green coat on the glass. I know that it is the typical issue for fresh water aquariums, but it must be cleaned!

However, it is worth to visit for following reasons:

1. Pandas. My opinion it is one of the best worldwide
2. Water tank with manatees. Great possibility to view manatees both through the glass and from the open top of the tank
3. Squirrel monkeys. You will get a lot of fun watching them
4. Small animal show near future boat ride. It was at 16.00 and we didn't find any announcement, so visited it accidentally. Nice interaction with animal in short distance. Interesting not only for kids.

title: Novel way to learn about rivers and the life within
content: An attraction with nuggets of information about rivers and its creatures and life around the world, presented in an interesting way. Very educational especially for nature and environment lovers. Thoughtful how it has been built with a sheltered walkway so visitors are not inconvenienced by rain. The humid weather in S'pore however still made the air-conditioned enclosures eg where the pandas are, more comfortable to linger. Happy to get a glimpse of one panda although the other was hidden. Too bad the planned river cruise to emulate a ride on the Amazon river wasn't open yet when we visited.

title: Great way to spend a couple of hours
content: We visited in mid April, not long after it opened, and although not all attractions were yet finished, we had a great time. My recommendation would be to spend the morning at the zoo ( right next door) then pop over to the river safari for a couple of hours in the afternoon. You can buy combo tickets to make it more affordable. We enjoyed learning about the major river systems of the world and seeing some wild life we had never encountered before. We particularly enjoyed the giant pandas. ( We were lucky enough to see them very close up!) the other highlight was the squirrel monkeys. They literally roam free in an enclosed area that you walk through! Beware of them trying to take stuff from your bags though! Very cheeky but very cute! Very impressive enclosures and viewing areas. I can only imagine it will be quite spectacular when finished!

title: When completely up and running will be fantastic!
content: We went to the soft opening in April and the boat ride wasn't yet working. It was still great though with lots of wildlife we hadn't seen (and we've seen a LOT!). If you are at the zoo, this place is well worth a visit and you can buy combo tickets that make it affordable!

title: Cool although yet to be opened fully
content: The River Safari is worth paying a visit to although it is yet to be opened fully. We did see some exotic animals at the park and a tank full of manatees. We walked among the free-ranging spider monkeys too. We are waiting for the park to be fully opened to go on the boat ride.

title: Singapore River Safari a con job
content: Don't even try to go on the River Safari as it is highly overpriced at S$29 for adults and S$20 for children. Most of the exhibits are not open and you just walk on the boardwalk most of the time. The boat ride is not open either and it would have been much better to wait till all th attractions are ready. If you want to see the pandas, which is a huge draw, you only see one as the other one is tto shy to come out. You can see Kai Kai hiding under a table on the screen. There are lot of fishes but then if you have seen the Marine Water Park, which you would as a toruist, this is a complete waste.

title: Wait for the boat ride to open
content: Went on a weekday to River Safari on a 2-in-1 park hopper. The general sense is being underwhelmed and over-charged for a park that generated so much interest and anticipation, mainly because only half the park is open. The highlights include the giant tanks, with manatees, gars, some pirahnas and some river fishes, and of course the panda enclosure. However, most of the trails are dotted with signboards and picture illustration (musuem like?) and exhibits such as arrowanas, turtles, angel fish fails to wow visitors. There are also no shows or special Lets wait for the full park to open.

title: Exotic animals
content: The animals in the River safari were all exotic animals and we were so lucky that those animals were still exist, despite some maybe endangered. We hope that Singapore zoo continue the conservation for those exotic and endangered animals.

title: Fabulous experience!
content:
As other advisors have mentioned the river attraction of the river safari is not yet available however this does not spoil the adventure!

20 minutes by taxi from marina bay sands and roughly 22SSD fare.

There is lots to see and experience even for people like us who are not really zoo or safari people but it definitely gave us inspiration for other attractions or maybe even a safari holiday at some point!

The highlight of the trip was seeing the giant panda, just amazing! Fabulous creatures, although to be fair all they really did was eat bamboo and the odd carrot, but so very well worth watching and waiting for people to move around so you can get an excellent view of them.

It's a crowded experience with lots of other tourists wanting pictures etc but just be patient and loiter. Others will leave and you will have your clear photo opportunity within a couple of minutes of standing around

Tip for other visitors... We did the experience in about 2.5 hours and got a park hopper, electing for the night safari later in the day. Go around 2pm if you just want to do the 2 safari parks. But if you want to do all 3, which can be done, arrive early morning when the zoo opens. Start with the zoo, head to the river safari and then night safari later in the evening.

Another tip - the food area around the river safari closes around 6:30 but don't panic... Head up to the night safari area where there are ore food outlets which are open later.

title: Fun & interesting
content: Despite the boat ride not being available, it was a fun and v enjoyable experience. Esp loved the Amazon flooded forest, so peaceful and happy just watching the aquatic animals. Next attraction i enjoyed was the 2 pandas. Super cute pandas and you can learn how the menus are prepared for the 2 pandas. Didnt complete the river safari as we arrived late, it closes at 6pm. Get the park hopper ticket - its value for money. Will visit again if i do visit Singapore on my next trip.

title: The River Themed Zoo
content:
The River Safari is a river themed zoo located in Singapore and is just next to the Singapore Zoo and the night safari. It comprises of mainly freshwater attraction and of course, the highlight which is the giant panda forest.

It was a pleasant outing for me. However, i didn't find the place fantastic. I felt that the giant panda forest was pretty similar to the Giant Panda Adventure which i saw in Hong Kong Ocean Park. The pandas were cute but if you are talking about value for money, you definedly have lots more to do and see in HK Ocean Park.

My comments ... just alright!

title: Gorgeous attraction
content: The only reason this attraction does'nt get 5/5 is the fact that the amazon river part was still not open, which we were aware of prior to our visit though. The walk around is beautiful and everything is build to high standards; seeing the pandas was a lot of fun as well as walking around with free-ranging monkeys in one area.

title: Best Experience together with Parks
content:
The River Safari is the Zoo's latest attraction, and it is located next to the Zoo and the night safari. Don't make a special trip just to visit the River Safari, as it is only 80% complete. The boat ride will only be complete after July 2013 (estimated).

However, if you get the Park Hopper, visiting all 3 parks in a day will be worth your money, and the trip out of the main city area. This is the only place outside of China, yet in Asia, which gives you an opportunity to see the famous China Pandas. Head to the River Safari at 930am or 230pm for Free guided tours. It does not bring you to all the exhibits, but it is comprehensive enough considering it is FREE

Another exhibit I loved is the Flooded Amazon Forest. 6 months of the year, the Amazon is flooded. The Zoo replicates this eco system, as you will see the forest submerged and interactiing with marine life. My kids enjoyed it

title: Rip off!
content: After the pleasant and interesting experience that was the Night Safari, I looked forward to seeing the newest attraction in the Zoo cluster. Unfortunately, it turned out to be deeply under-whelming and an outright disappointment. The attraction is only half completed and, while the concept may prove to be successful in the future, at present it consists of a few riverine creatures shifted over from the neighboring zoo and an awful lot of signage displaying information I could have sourced at home, in comfort. Far too many of the enclosures and tanks bear photographs and a strap banner saying "coming soon"! The entrance fee is currently discounted because of the incomplete nature of the attraction, but is exorbitant considering the paltry offerings. The marketing and advertising of this so-called attraction is misleading, bordering on duplicity, and does Singapore no credit. At present, I strongly recommend that it is avoided. Take a slow stroll through the Botanical Gardens - it is far more rewarding and won't cost you a cent.

title: Interesting place but boat ride was not available during our visit
content: We bought park hopper specials which cost S$39 per person for Zoo and River Safari. You get to see Red Panda, Panda and a lot more interesting animals. At the end of the walk there is a big big aquarium where you can sit back and relax while watching Manatee swim.

title: Unique River-Themed Park in Singapore
content:
Surpisingly, we enjoyed River Safari recently. Why?

-its concept is new in asia as it features world famous rivers and river-dwelling land and aquatic animals. so it's not all-aquariums and/or all-cages, but it highlights mississipi river, river nile, ganges river, yangtze river, murray river etc.

-informative, educational, promotes awareness and love for environment.

-the Giant Panda Forest section doesn't only highlight the Giant Pandas, Jia Jia and Kai Kai but a couple of red pandas or firefox too. It's a delight to simply watch them move in seemingly huge environment.

-there are airconditioned areas and spots with electric fans providing good ventillation and comfort under the hot Singaporean sun.

-accessible via bus 138 after you alight at Ang Mo Kio MRT station.

-included in the list of theme parks on the package of iVenture card that we availed that save us money, effort in waiting in long queue, and offers lots of options.

-location is a few steps away from night safari, and just beside singapore zoo.

-downside of experiencing it early : the second zone, called amazonia, apart from rivers of the world remains a work in progress. but that's one reason to go back to river safari singapore.

title: Not worth the price eventhough not the full price
content:
Although the price charged was not the full price, I still felt I did not get my money's worth. It was still more expensive than the Singapore Zoo and yet, there were less animals to see.

To potential visitors: I suggest to wait until the whole safari is opened before visiting the place or you might just leave disappointed.

title: Wait till the boat ride!
content:
Went to river safari on Vesak day and actually the crowd was not a lot. Maybe the safari is still not fully opened, some of the exhibits were closed and we did not saw some of the animals which were listed on the map. Nevertheless we had a good day especially for my 19mo toddler.
Kai Kai n Jia Jia were expectedly most popular among the visitors. Jia Jia was sleeping in her cove when we went to visit them. At least Kai Kai still was active walking around his area. Food wise there were only 2 restaurants there. Nothing fantastic. Btw this place is really stroller friendly and the staff were friendly too! Will make a trip down again after the boat ride is up!

title: Five stars attraction.
content: This is really a great tour of all the great rivers of the world. There is 3 big aquarium throughout the tour in both airconditiong & outdoor. Of course, there's the red panda, giant panda & squirrel monkeys to add to the fun. The only set back is that the river ride is only open at the end of 2013.

title: Rivers of the Continents in Singapore
content:
This is an educational place for children and also a great eye opener to all!

Accessibility: Have to go by taxi/cab as it is most convenient. Public transport with shuttle bus to Khatib MRT available at certain operating hours.

It is wheelchair friendly and pram-friendly. Pathways suitable for prams and it is not for bumpy surfaces.

Value of money: Currently, in this month May,2013, some sites are not available yet, not even the boat rides, so the cost is about $25. With a group of adults I have been with recently to this place, we took 3 hours to explore the sites comfortably. When all sites are opened, perhaps, 4-5hrs there would be the average. But if you only spend 1 hour breezing past the place without stopping by to admire the creatures or listen to the guides along the way, it might be a bit too expensive for a short trip.

Time: The morning period was cool and comfortable. With light rain, it posed no problems to the trip as most areas are sheltered and you will not hesitate to walk in the open even if it drizzles, provided you have an umbrella or a cap. This is because the open spaces takes you to the next zone which is back to a sheltered zone. So all is well-covered.

Cleanliness: The toilets are clean. That may be important for people concerned over the use of toilets. At certain places, I see vendor machines selling bottled drinks. I saw one 500ml of coke cost $3. So come prepared with some coins if you run out of drinks.

Big Aquarium - the flooded forest : There is a grand spectator stand for people to sit and watch the giant creatures (manatee) swim. You can also go up to the second level to watch them eat from the giant basket of vegetables. Second level has no seat. Just to watch from another angle.

Entire concept: Classification by rivers in different continent was very systematic. It's not putting all the fishes of the worlds together or monkeys together like the zoo. Thus, you get the experience what you can see in River Mekong, River Nile, Amazon etc. Very suitable for school trips!

title: Still under construction
content: This seems to be the newest addition to the parks around the zoo. We spent 1.5-2 hrs here. There were some nice aquariums -some quite large with Dugongs, and arowanas. The Panda enclosure was a nice escape from the heat. Many of the tanks were empty and the boat ride was not yet operational. It was rather disappointing as not everything was ready (and we were paying full price for entrance). I think it will be a good visit once it is actually finished.

title: Go on a River Safari in a busy urban city!
content:
The recently opened River Safari SIngapore (officially opened in April 2013) is a refreshing new attraction in SIngapore. Part of WIldlife Reserves Singapore, the River Safari is unlike any zoo you may encounter anywhere in the world.

Built into the natural surroundings of the secondary rainforest of the Seletar/Mandai area, the River Safari features flora and fauna in their natural habitats in the major rivers of the world such as the Amazon, the Ganges, the Mekong and the Yangtze. Of course, any man-made replicas can never truly capture the immense natural wonders of these great rivers but I would say that these small replicas featured in the River Safari is as good as it gets, short of actually visiting these natural wonders individually.

The flora and fauna among the exhibits in the River Safari include rare and highly endangered species such as the famous Giant Panda and the Red Panda. The number of freshwater fish species found in the River Safari is astounding. These include the giant Arapaima, Garfish, Giant Tigerfish, Paddlefish, Chinese Sturgeon and Giant Mekong Catfish.

And the best part of it all? The River Safari is easily accessible using public transport. Public buses and taxis will get you there from the city centre in less than an hour. And it is also nestled together with its more popularly known sister attractions such as the Singapore Zoological Gardens and the Night Safari. A "Park Hopper" pass will grant you access to all 3 parks plus the Jurong Bird Park and is a cost-effective means for tourists to visit all these attractions. Enquire at the Pass Office and the friendly staff there will advise you on the costs and other administrative details.

title: proud to be a singaporean more after i visited river safari
content:
I went to river safari on 17/5/2013 Friday and its not very crowded . I will come back again because not all of the wildlife are there yet. Those that are there are adapting very well and I am very please that all the staff are very caring , informative and interactive with visitors about the wildlife in their respective stations. Big thumbs up for them . The whole place is wheelchair and pram friendly . I hope river safari will make the boat ride an optional choice because I wont want to board the boat, I am happy with walking .I was studying in an international school for all my life and I am multilingual, I heard some visitors(from neighboring countries) said they are not very willing to try the boat ride due to some phobia from flood face in their countries and other personal reasons.Viewing from the view decks I actually can see some beautiful kingfisher and I feel that the boat ride open in year end is going to be an amazing one too ,please hold your excitement for a few months more ,if you really want to board the boat.
The most important thing to prepare for this trip is mineral water ,you really need at least 2 bottles to hydrate yourself.
I feel that you need to have some patience when viewing some wildlife .Not all are visible at a glance ,some are hiding in corners ,therefore time is needed to find and see them. The longest was 50 mins ,just to find the green anaconda .I actually had mix feeling when viewing the piranha, I actually quite disagree with breeding and protecting piranha , however in river safari I learn that not all piranha are human flesh eating, some are animal eating. The human eating on surround the human like you are in the middle of a tornado while the animal eating just look at you in a flock. You can move your hand in front of the fishes ,some actually follow your hand motion. Top 4 animals you must visit (1) Indian gharial (they are really enormous ).
(2)Giant Panda kaikai and jiajia I was told that kaikai (male) was more active then jiajia (female)by the staff there.Jiajia actually smile for the cameras before she had her lunch. Very cute Pandas. Giant panda area have air con in their area,very cooling and have more crowd than other areas.
(3)Manatee and(4) giant river otters .That is where I feel so proud to be a Singaporean ,you have to really see for yourselves ,if you think Conrad hotel Rangali Island Resort at Maldives is beautiful ,you will hope and want more that you can build a house in river safari and watch the manatee and giant river otters every single day . For food ,you must try is the cappuccino and bamboo rice set B from Mama Panda kitchen, I am not very impress with the panda bun but the cappuccino was really good. overall ,worth every penny even incomplete,a must go in Singapore!!

title: Don't go there...yet...
content:
Visited River Safari at the end of April and was disappointed because half of it wasn't completed yet and many exhibits and animals in the completed half were missing. The reason I wanted to go to the River Safari was because they advertised giant otters and manatees, but I didn't see either of those animals there, so I was really bummed out. I was quite sure neither of the animals had arrived yet but looking at the other reviewers, it seems like the manatees were already there - I don't see how I could have missed them though...

They shouldn't have advertised exhibits that have not arrived yet. Was not worth the time and ticket price this time round.

It'll probably be a great place to visit once it's properly completed, but in the meantime, try Singapore Zoo or the Night Safari instead.

title: Brilliant
content: The newest of the parks here this is a great facility and definitely worth a visit. Not all parts of the park are operational yet but that doesn't matter. The viewing tanks throughout are amazing you almost feel like you are underwater. The pandas are a highlight we were lucky that the male was particularly active when we visited which was great. Highly recommend the park.

title: Great concept - still unfinished. Go back when Amazonia is ready
content: We visited with kids and friends on a Saturday afternoon. There were no crowds at all. The park is not fully ready yet, and the star attractions in the Amazon area and the boat ride open only end of the year. Great concept to showcase habitats based on rivers of the world. The red pandas are really cool and so is the Squirrel Monkey walkthrough habitat. Unlike typical shows, the one at the River Safari was very "touch-and-feel" and intimate, as watchers were encouraged to touch the animals to learn about them. The setting is very nice, with the bridge over the mouth of the reservoir making a perfect spot for many pictures. Almost the entire park is open-air i.e. no aircon, but sheltered. Makes for a very natural experience. Lack of creatures in some exhibits and the Amazon section still to open, are the drawbacks of visitng before end of the year.

title: Nice to finally see pandas and manates in Singapore
content:
It was a last min decision for me and my husband to visit the River Safari. We have no idea what to expect although we read a little about the place online before we arrived. Went straight to the ticket counter, and the lady was very nice to inform me that the river cruise attraction was not ready and instead of the regular ticket price of $35, the ticket is now at $25. Which to me was fine when things are mentioned upfront.

The place was huge. Very well organized. Although we had a map on hand we didn’t really refer to it as we just followed whichever the path took us. The place was is amazing! The panda enclosure was very nice. We only got to see Kai Kai as I did not expect to see Jia Jia anyway as it was mentioned on their website that Jia Jia is rather shy and like to stay indoors. We saw her inside sleeping through the CCTV that they had place outside, to me which was a very nice gesture.

I was more amaze when I entered the Manatees "zone". It was phenomenal! There were so many of them and it was my first time to see them in real life. I was totally mesmerized by the entire peace and calmness. We sat there for like 30mins just watching them. It was really cool.

title: A bit of a disappointment!!
content:
We were looking forward to visiting the River Safari after all the hype that was created around it, but were quite disappointed after the visit.

Most of the rivers have only been given a space of 5 meters with 2-3 aquariums in them which barely gives a feel of things. On top of that at least a third of the displays / aquariums were empty (with coming soon signs).

The only major attraction is the Panda enclosure, which in my opinion has no link with the rest of the river safari and instead should have been in the zoo next door. The enclosure seems to have just been put there as a way to generate revenue for the river safari.

There were a few positives though. The Manatee area is really nice and has a calm and zen feel to it. The area with the bridge connecting the two sides of the park looking over the reservoir is nice. And of course the Panda enclosure was lovely, especially the red pandas.

title: We need the river cruise!
content:
This is river safari and they offer river cruise. But the river cruise was not operated! What a ripp off! I told the staff that they have to infrom it at the ticket outlet. They just asked for apologize without giving any compensations.
All I experienced was only saw fishes in the aquarium. What a waste. But thanks god, they have Panda.

title: Some new animals!!
content: Good to see some new animals, if you have already been dozen of times at the zoo, bird park, etc. It is still not fully open yet, but most of the animals are already in place to be admired. Some of the fish I have never seen before, and very nicely done, presenting the major rivers of the world. The Pandas...presented as usual in the cuddly way, with cute little pictograms and branding of the whole exhibit. One could really start a debate. These are BEARS, and the way they are being pampered, they just degenerate, fat and lazy. There is simply no way one of these animals is ever going to be released anywhere. Would not survive. Pure tourist attraction, to, BTW, extract quite a high entry price. Still, also the birds, the monkeys are really well done. The aquarium with the Manatees towards the end is truly impressive. A nice addition to the Zoo complex.

title: Not fully functional yet
content: The park is still under development till end of 2013 .Yet you can still appreciate the beauty of the lake and nature surrounding it and watch the birds fly above in the peaceful surrounding.Main attractions will be the 2 panda's ,fishes ,squirrel monkeys,red panda and crocodiles .Explanation regarding the worlds rivers are good and educational and each of it has an conservation message .Great for kids to learn .Will be good to pay a visit next year to see the full potential of the river safari .

title: River Safari - Total Rip Off
content:
Just went there yesterday. I would say River Safari is really quite a rip off, for $25 per adult and something which you can essentially complete in 2hrs! This is a far cry from its neighbour, the Singapore Zoo which I will talk a bit later on.

River Safari is segmented into different zones, eg Ganges River, Amazon, Mekong River, et etc. In ea ch zone, you can expect to see different river creatures. A couple of zones have got those big tanks for the bigger creatures such as the manatees. Don't expect each zone to be big. If you are not on time for the feeding times, and you are on your own, essentially you can finish one river zone in about 15mins.

What I find odd is that the name River Safari gives one the impression that it is about river life and creatures right? But I'm very baffled by the presence of other animals such as the overrated pandas (jia jia and kai kai), plus the many other exhibits which are yet to be unveiled such as the howler monkey, jaguar, macaw etc. Even the show itself reflects this strong lack of theme. It is merely a showcase of hornbills, binturong, and some others which do not live in or near rivers. In addition to that, the show area has ONLY got 2 benches available for seating with each bench seating at most 6 adults. So go there very early to get a seat otherwise be prepared to sit on the floor.

About 40% of the exhibits are not there yet but even if they are, it is really not a large and interesting place to visit. And I say it's a rip off because this admission charge of $25 per adult is even more expensive than a Zoo ticket!

I'm a Singaporean and thus have been to the Zoo numerous times with my kids because it's a large place with hoardes more exhibits than the River Safari. It has a variety of animals to see thus making it interesting. I've also been to quite a number of other zoos but nothing comes quite as close to the Singapore Zoo in terms of the natural rustic enclosures which the architects have so cleverly done up. They do not look anything like a cage! They use the animals' natural fears to demarcate its boundaries.

My take is if you've got a day, visit the Zoo and the Night Safari and give River Safari and Jurong Bird Park a miss. These attractions just scream BORING. If the River Safari can bring in more river related creatures and STAY TRUE to its theme, I may consider going back there but in the meantime, don't bother. Besides, the pandas aren't very interesting.

I'm just very very glad that I got free tickets to the River Safari otherwise I would have been a very grumpy person at the end of yesterday!

title: Potential but Amazon section not yet open
content:
We are Friends of the Zoo and bring our kids there regularly. We've been waiting for the River Safari to open sine we saw all the construction going on, and decided to go one Saturday.

I agree with the previous contributor who said that it has potential but will likely realize it in a year or so, especially when the Amazon section opens, which includes a boat ride around that section. So prices are going at a discounted $25 instead if what they say is the normal price of $35.

I decided to sign up for the Friends of River Safari, as it was also discounted (at $210) and would still be valid when the Amazon section opens.

I guess the main stars would be Jia Jia and Kai Kai, giant pandas from China. Not sure how they fit into the river theme though. The pandas are housed in a special enclosure which is air conditioned, so that made it nice to get out of the heat. Jia Jia is the shy one, who stayed in the 'house' throughout the 20mins I was there. I guess the zoo knows, so they installed a CCTV for visitors to see her sleeping in her house. Kai Kai was outside eating his bamboo shoots. The website says you need to book a viewing times lot, but that Sat they were trying out a new system whereby you didn't need to book. I think this is better as you don't have to rush.

The exhibits near the entrance houses a very large aquarium, and has a colony of manatees which I really liked. The viewing panel must be at least 2 storey high and you'd could clearly see the manatee feeding. I also saw 2 seals (or were they sea lions) frolicking in the water and playing with some kind of floating ball.

There was the mandatory animal show, but my compliant is that there are no chairs, no crowd control and more importantly, is held in the open which was so so hot. Luckily we got there early at 330pm (show starts at 4pm) and managed to sit on the lone bench (which could sit maybe 3 families?). Has some birds flying back and forth, and some animals coming out (porcupine, dingo, stock, etc). At the end of the show, we queued to take a picture with the stocks, and were allowed to pet the porcupine.

The whole design is very green, with shaded walkways. I believe you should be able to cover the current exhibits in 2-3 hrs (compared to at least 1/2 day if not longer for the Zoo).

title: Main Attraction is Kai Kai and Jia Jia !
content:
The river boat will only be ready in later part of the year 2013. If you go to the park now, you will only see 1/2 the park which is sheltered under shade or in aircon.

It is not a big park. Without the river ride, we were done in less than 2 hrs, taking our own sweet time. There are quite a few tanks but not much of a sight. Maybe a few fish in a tank, 3 snakes in a tank, a frog in a tank etc. The sting ray pool is a failure. Cant see much. Sentosa Underwater does a better job on their Sting Ray pool.

The main attraction is The Panda Kai Kai and Jia Jia. Cool enclosure and we get to be up close with the panda. Kai Kai was quite reserved and quiet when we were there. But Jia Jia put up quite a show. She was very active and was happily slidding down muddy slopes for more than 10min.

The next honorable mention is the Manatees Tank. It was enchanting and has a mermaid underwater look.

There is a small food court in the park and along the way, there are small kiosks for drinks and chips.

When River boat is ready, the park definitely will be more crowded.

title: Already wonderful, going to be even better when fully completed!
content:
The River Safari is the newest addition to the family, the others being the Singapore Zoo, Night Safari and Jurong Bird Park. In my opinion, the River Safari has the potential to be the best attraction of the 4 when it becomes fully operational by end of 2013; currently there is no Amazon River boat ride and I think only about 60% of the planned wildlife. According to their info, when completed the 8 river region displays should have about 5000 animals from 300 species, including one of the world's largest collection of freshwater creatures (most aquariums concentrate on saltwater displays).

The major attraction is certainly the pair of Giant Pandas, Kai Kai & Jia Jia, on loan from China. But currently the female panda Jia Jia is being shy or moody and doesn't come out from her den. Which leaves Kai Kai to soak up all the adoration from ecstatic kids & females of all ages swooning over his cute looks. He on the other hand is only intent on filling his belly! The pandas are in their own climate-controlled, delightfully cool "Giant Panda Forest" together with Red Pandas (can be seen at really close distance compared to other zoos) and Golden Pheasants.

As for the water creatures, freshwater aquarists can only dream about owning such huge aquariums that could house enormous fish like araipama, Mississippi paddlefish, alligator gar, Chinese sturgeon, Mekong giant catfish etc. The 2 largest aquariums for the Mekong and Amazon Flooded Forest really takes your breath away, especially the latter which includes the manatees. One can easily lose time sitting at the Amazon Flooded Forest area, spellbound in watching the slow but oddly graceful "sea cows" and end up feeling very relaxed while listening to the soothing background music.

A few creatures like the Chinese giant salamander, American beaver, electric eel and jaguarundi wildcat were either not very responsive or snoozing away at that time. Some others were very "public-friendly" by swimming very close or remaining in one spot long enough for good photos: ducks in Mississippi area, Yangtze alligator, piranhas, squirrel monkeys and of course Kai Kai the panda when sitting on his fat bum! Many of the fishes swim pretty fast so you need correct camera settings to avoid blurred still shots or just shoot videos. My favourites are the Mekong display, red pandas, free-range Squirrel Monkey Forest, giant river otters and Amazon Flooded Forest.

When one goes to a zoo or other wildlife park, I think you should slow down, take your time to observe the animals and relish the opportunity to be relatively close to creatures that you would only read about, see on TV or have to trek out to the wild to see. There is no point in rushing things or be only interested in capturing photos and videos in a few seconds then rushing off like the wind to the next attraction. Initially I also thought the River Safari would be only worth 1-2 hours and had considered visiting the zoo next door later. At the end of my visit, to my surprise I had unknowingly spent more than 4 hours including lunch at the Mama Panda Kitchen restaurant. If a work-in-progress place already has so much captivating appeal, can't imagine when it is finally fully operational. In my opinion it is already fully worth the currently discounted $25 adult fee. And I would certainly visit again, especially when more creatures and the Amazon boat ride become available. River Safari, possibly the jewel in the crown for Wildlife Reserves Singapore?

title: Lots of Potential but give it a year
content:
I am generally a big fan of singapore zoos. I think they did a magnificent job with the zoo and night safari. So when the latest addition - the River Safari - has its soft opening a few weeks back, I couldn't wait to check it out.
The River Safari is a showcase of animals, fishes and birds that inhabitat in or around the great rivers of the world. So you get the Amazon, Nile, Mekong, Mississippi, Ganges, Yangtze etc. It is an interesting and novel concept. It is kind of like a zoo, bird park and acquarium rolled into one. Oh yes, for some reason it also houses the Giant Pandas from China although I doubt they lived anyway near the great rivers. But that is doubtless the star attraction.
The setting is nice as to be expected. Concept is good. And so was the way the animals were display. Aside from the Giant Pandas, I particularly like the Indian Gharial tanks and the Manatees aquarium which is the largest freshwater acquarium in the world.
So why did I give it only 3 stars. Well the park is only 50-60% opened. I was told it will only be fully operational in a year's time. As such - many of the animals cannot be seen and zones not accesible yet. You only need 2 hours to see everything. The S$25 entrance fee seems steep when one consider it is only S$22 to visit the much larger Singapore Zoological Park (right adjacent to it) - which you would need at least 4 hours to complete. Do get me wrong, for what they have, it is quite attractive - but you just have to manage your expectation for what they do not have yet.
I would probably go again in a year to see it in its full glory and hopefully by then it should deserve a 4 if not 5 stars. In the meantime, for those unlikely to be in Singapore then - a visit to this safari is interesting, but if pressed for time - go to the main zoo or the night safari instead where you get better value. Unless....you must see your Panda before your leave.
